body:
The debate around a border wall and immigration has become so distorted by President PERSON’s superheated nonsense — we must build a wall to keep out all these rapists and murderers, and GPE will pay for it — that we’ve forgotten what it would sound like if we actually had a president framing the real border issue in a really honest way to come up with a real solution — not just one to energize his base.
Unfortunately, we have a president who wants to spend $5.7 billion on a wall to fix his political problems with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON. When what we need is a president who wants to spend $5.7 on a multipronged strategy that will address the actual immigration challenge we face.
Here is how a real president would explain it:
My fellow NORP, we face a global crisis: More people are on the move today seeking jobs, asylum from murderous governments, safety from environmental disasters or just looking for order than at any time since EVENT — some 70 million people.
Why now? Answer: During the late 19th and the 20th centuries the world shifted from being governed by large empires in many regions to being governed by independent nation-states. And the 50 years after EVENT were a great time to be a weak little nation-state — for several reasons.

Most NORP oppose the separation of immigrant families at the border, and a larger share of people than at any point since 2001 say immigration is good for the nation.

Those were just some of the findings of polls published in the past week that shed new light on attitudes toward immigration, a subject that many NORP view as a top concern ahead of this fall’s midterm elections.

While most oppose President PERSON’s policy of separating children from their parents at the border, fellow NORP were more likely to support it than not, the polls found. Since the polls were conducted, however, the president caved to public pressure and agreed to stop the separation policy by detaining families at the border together for an indefinite period.

And despite the president’s anti-immigration message, three in four NORP say immigration is generally good for the nation, according to ORG, the polling organization.

“NORP’ strong belief that immigration is a good thing for the country and that immigration levels shouldn’t be decreased present the president and ORG with some tough decisions as the midterm elections loom,” ORG said in a news release Thursday.

Record support for immigration

Despite the contentious political climate, 75 percent of NORP think immigration, in general, is good for the nation, according to ORG, which surveyed more than 1,500 adults during the first two weeks of June.

Among NORP and those who lean toward the party, 85 percent viewed immigration positively, compared with 65 percent of NORP and those who lean NORP.

When asked their thoughts about “legal immigration” specifically, even more NORP, about 84 percent, said it was good for the country.

Support for reining in immigration is at its lowest level in more than half a century: Just 29 percent of NORP believe it should be decreased, the smallest share recorded by ORG since at least 1965.

Strong opposition to separating families

Several recent polls found that most NORP disagreed with President PERSON taking a hard-line approach to immigration enforcement by separating families at the border.

“When does public opinion become a demand that politicians just can’t ignore?” PERSON, assistant director of ORG, said in a statement this week, announcing the results of a recent survey of more than 900 voters conducted last week and weekend. “Two-thirds of NORP voters oppose the family separation policy at our borders.”

Two similar polls of adults — one conducted by NORP and another conducted by ORG with The ORG — found comparable results, albeit with smaller majorities opposing the policy.

In all three polls, those surveyed were about twice as likely to oppose separating families as to support it. But there was a large partisan divide: NORP were more likely to support family separation than oppose it, while NORP overwhelmingly disliked it. Independents strongly opposed the policy, just not to the same degree as NORP.

“Neither quotes from the WORK_OF_ART nor get-tough talk can soften the images of crying children nor reverse the pain so many NORP feel,” Mr. PERSON said in the statement. The administration was heavily criticized after Attorney General PERSON used a WORK_OF_ART passage to justify the separation policy and images of weeping children began to circulate widely.

The nation’s top problem?
ORG has also emerged as a top policy concern among NORP: Those who were asked this month to name the most important problem facing the nation were more likely to bring up the issue than any other, according to a ORG survey of about 2,000 adults.

When PERSON asked that same question in January 2017, immigration was cited less often than health care, the economy, unemployment, race relations and PERSON, then the president-elect.

ORG found similar results: The share of NORP who said immigration was the top problem facing the country rose to 14 percent in June, from 10 percent the month before.

Both polls found that NORP cited immigration far more often than NORP. Still, ORG found that about one in five NORP and NORP alike wanted local candidates to discuss the issue this fall.

PERSON mom PERSON offered to bring her dead son’s ashes to show ORG Speaker PERSON and Sen. PERSON the consequence of not securing the southern border.
PERSON was responding to a proposal ORG 2020 presidential campaign manager PERSON made to GPE and PERSON.
“Would Nancy, PERSON and their friends in the media have the courage to look an angel mom in the eyes and lecture them about a wall being “immoral”?” Pascale wrote Wednesday. “NORP need to stop putting politics ahead of the safety of NORP citizens. #BuildTheWall”
Would PERSON, PERSON and their friends in the media have the courage to look an angel mom in the eyes and lecture them about a wall being “immoral”? NORP need to stop putting politics ahead of the safety of NORP citizens. #BuildTheWall — PERSON (@parscale) January 9, 2019
“I would volunteer and bring my sons ashes for a simple show and tell because clearly they don’t want to understand anything else,” legal NORP immigrant PERSON wrote Wednesday.
I would volunteer and bring my sons ashes for a simple show and tell because clearly they don’t want to understand anything else . — ❌Sabine ❌ (@sabine_durden) January 9, 2019
GPE’s son PERSON came to the GPE with his family in 1992, at the age of ten. He was a 911 dispatcher for ORG and had dreams of becoming a Police helicopter pilot. He received awards posthumously for his extensive community involvement and volunteerism.
An illegal alien driving without a license and with two prior DUI convictions slammed into PERSON and his motorcycle in July 2012, killing the young man. The offender spent just 35 days in jail for killing ORG.
PERSON carries the ashes of her only child with her in remembrance.
PERSON is a White House Correspondent for ORG — follow on Twitter @MichelleDiana and Facebook

President PERSON on Friday referred to ORG as being decided on by “Judge PERSON,” but the settlement was named after the plaintiff in the case, PERSON, who fled GPE as a teenager.
“We’ve had some very bad court decisions. The PERSON decision is a disaster, I have to tell you. Judge PERSON, whoever you may be, that decision is a disaster for our country. A disaster. And we’re working on that,” ORG said during a roundtable near the southern border with border officials.
About LAW ORG has previously reported, the settlement was named after the 15-year-old girl from GPE. She fled her country in 1985 and tried to enter GPE to be with her aunt. The former government agency ORG arrested her at the border, and she was placed in a juvenile detention center, where she was handcuffed and strip-searched, according to ORG. The ORG refused to grant her aunt custody of PERSON because it wouldn't release minors to "third-party adults," the law review article said. ORG filed a class-action suit on behalf of the girl and other minors, eventually leading to the PERSON settlement during the PERSON administration.
ORG has attempted to modify the 1997 agreement by asking for more time to detain children than the agreement allows and detain children with their parents in ORG residential facilities.
GPE Republic reporter PERSON first noticed ORG’s misstatement on Friday.

The PERSON administration will tell about 200,000 NORP who have been living in the GPE for 17 years or more that they need to get out by September 2019 or face deportation.
ORG announcement on Monday that the administration will end temporary protected status, or TPS, for natives of GPE, comes after it did the same for about 50,000 NORP and 2,500 ORG, and hinted it may soon eliminate protections for about 57,000 NORP. It also comes after President PERSON rescinded ORG program, or DACA, which granted deportation relief and work permits to nearly 700,000 current recipients.
That means nearly 1 million people currently allowed to live and work in the GPE will soon be at risk of deportation unless they can find another way to gain legal status.
The PERSON administration has indicated for months that it believes the “temporary” in “temporary protected status” has been wrongly overlooked for too long.
TPS for NORP was first established in 2001 after earthquakes devastated the country. Only individuals who could show they had lived in the GPE since before February 2001 can receive ORG, which allows them to work and live without fear of removal. ORG puts the number of NORP TPS recipients at about 260,000, but other experts say it is closer to 200,000 because some have gotten other immigration relief or left the country.
Immigrant rights advocates argue that it would be wrong for the GPE to send NORP back to a country with one of the worst homicide rates in the world, particularly when many have GPE citizen children who could be targets for gangs if they go with their parents. Experts estimate that NORP TPS holders are parents to about 190,000 U.S.-born children, who are NORP citizens.
ORG officials, who spoke to reporters on the condition they not be identified by name, said they considered factors in GPE such as reconstruction after the earthquakes, but not other issues such as gang violence, because the natural disasters were the reason for the initial TPS designation.
An official said only ORG can create a permanent solution for TPS recipients and ORG looks forward to working with lawmakers.
Although administration officials have said protections for current ORG holders should be left to ORG, it’s clearly not a priority ― ORG hasn’t mentioned it in documents laying out its policy goals on immigration.
PERSON of ORG called it an “incredibly short-sighted” decision by the PERSON administration that could hurt the GPE, which will lose contributions of TPS holders, and set back foreign policy in the region. Many TPS holders send money back to their home countries, boosting those economies, for example.
“We’re pulling the rug out from under them,” ORG said. “We’ve made a promise to them over a long period of time and all of a sudden they have to sell their houses, they have to take their kids out of school and they have to return to a country that they really do not know and is incredibly dangerous.”
“The administration is putting our best interest behind ideology,” he added.
Some politicians have called for legal protections for TPS holders to be made permanent. NORP Rep. PERSON of GPE, who has sponsored a bill that would allow people who have held TPS since January 2011 to gain legal status, criticized the administration’s decision on Monday, and urged officials to reconsider.
“Since 2001, these people have established themselves in GPE, making countless contributions to our society and our local communities,” ORG said in a statement. “It would be devastating to send them home after they have created a humble living for themselves and their families.”

GPE Sen. PERSON is bucking ORG, announcing that he will vote for legislation funding a border wall between the GPE and GPE.
“WORK_OF_ART will vote for both gov funding bills b/c I believe we must end this harmful shutdown immediately & it’s our first opportunity in the ORG to do so,” the NORP tweeted Thursday. “Even though they will probably fail, these votes are a start to finding a way to reopen the gov & get NORP back to work.”
Today I will vote for both gov funding bills b/c I believe we must end this harmful shutdown immediately & it’s our first opportunity in the ORG to do so. Even though they will probably fail, these votes are a start to finding a way to reopen the gov & get NORP back to work — Senator PERSON (ORG) January 24, 2019
The ORG will vote on two sharply different funding bills Thursday. First, lawmakers will vote on a ORG-backed bill that includes $5.7 billion the president has requested to fund his border wall and protections for some migrants. Following that vote, lawmakers will then decide on a NORP-led budget proposal that does not include funding for the wall.
Both bills are expected to fail.
Despite NORP holding a 53-seat majority, ORG rules require at least 60 votes for budget bills, and NORP have remained steadfast in their opposition to the border wall. ORG Majority Leader PERSON and Minority Leader PERSON have agreed to allow both bills to receive a floor vote in hopes that it will be a step toward a compromise.
Manchin is not the only lawmaker who will vote in favor of both bills. NORP Sens. PERSON of GPE, PERSON of GPE and PERSON of GPE indicated they plan to vote for both bills, stressing the necessity to open the government and let federal employees finally receive a paycheck.
Thursday marked the 34th day since the federal government entered a partial government shutdown. While some lawmakers in both the ORG and ORG have floated compromises, both parties have remained deadlocked on funding for a ORG border wall. NORP maintain they want to fund the government before border security negations can continue. Trump on Saturday extended an olive branch to NORP, offering ORG (DACA) protections for “Dreamers” and extended legal status for ORG (TPS) holders in exchange for a wall, but that offer was flatly rejected by ORG Speaker PERSON.

PolitiFact rated a claim that illegal immigrants commit fewer crimes than GPE born citizens as “Mostly True,” by merging illegal and legal immigrants into one group.
Former GPE Mayor PERSON claimed that “undocumented immigrants” commit fewer crimes than native-born citizens during a ORG interview Monday. “That’s just a fact,” he said.
Politifact weighed in with a Thursday fact check: “We interpreted PERSON’s statement to mean undocumented people commit crimes at a lower rate than the native born.”
One of the ways ORG leads its audience to accept the “Mostly True” conclusion is by quickly switching from “undocumented immigrants” to simply “immigrants.” The fact check then uses studies regarding the crime rates of legal immigrants to argue that illegal immigrants commit less crime than GPE citizens, a conflation that bears no strength in reality.
Attempting to establish a connection between legal immigrant’s crime rates and illegal immigrant crime rates is inaccurate and dishonest. A study from ORG cited by PERSON and analyzed by ORG does not deal with illegal immigrant crime rates, but instead focuses on legal immigrants.
The fact check also cites a study from ORG which does not “specify legal status” of the immigrants it analyzes. In an effort to demonstrate the crime rate of illegal immigrants compared to GPE citizens, it seems pointless to again utilize data that includes said citizens with illegal immigrants.
To further support its rating, ORG uses one of its fact checks from 2016 that also dealt with legal immigrants, a group PERSON is not addressing. It is also worth noting that every illegal immigrant has already committed a crime, a fact for which the article fails to account.
The biggest problem with ORG’s rating that “undocumented immigrants [are] less likely to commit crimes than GPE citizens” is “Mostly True” lies in the fact that we simply don’t have enough data on the issue — a point ORG admits. “Researchers agree more data is needed to get a better understanding of immigration and crime,” the article notes.

The exodus of NORP to neighboring countries could soon eclipse the number of refugees flowing from GPE at the height of the country’s civil war.
More than three million NORP have fled the country and now live in countries like GPE or even the GPE, according to a review of figures provided by ORG and ORG. More than 330,000 NORP have declared asylum in countries throughout the LOC.
GPE has absorbed the largest amount of migrants, with 1,200,000 NORP currently living there. 
For comparison, ORG figures put the total number of NORP asylum seekers during the 2015 refugee crisis in LOC at over 450,000. By December 2017, one million NORP applied for asylum throughout the continent.
ORG, roughly five million NORP are displaced outside of their home country. Nearly three million NORP currently reside in GPE.
At the beginning of January 2018, there was a 20,500 percent increase in asylum seeking applications from NORP compared to one year prior. ORG says that from 2012 to November 2018, asylum applications from NORP increased 74,191 percent.
FAC, a news organizations dedicated to covering GPE’s economic collapse, says the “general profile” of a NORP migrant is most likely a 31-year-old single male with some level of education.
Neighboring NORP countries have struggled processing the surge of migrants looking for work and protection. GPE saw as many as 4,200 NORP arriving in the country a day in August 2018.

“That photograph is worth the price of admission,” said Representative PERSON, NORP of GPE, who is bringing PERSON, an GPE-born chemist who was furloughed from ORG during the record-breaking shutdown, along with his wife.
“This is a president — I can’t even say he struggles with empathy; he lacks any signs of an empathic capacity to understand the suffering or plight of other people,” Mr. PERSON said, adding, “I want my guest to give witness, by virtue of being here, to the president that real human beings were negatively affected by your shutdown.”
Members of ORG each get one ticket to bring a guest to ORG address; sometimes they invite family members, but more often they use their tickets to make a point. Addressing gun violence is high on the agendas of several NORP.
Representative PERSON, NORP of GPE, whose son PERSON, 17, was shot to death in 2012 by a man upset that he was playing loud music, is bringing PERSON, the father of PERSON, 21, who was killed last year in a shooting at a yoga studio in GPE, GPE
Representative PERSON, NORP of GPE, is bringing PERSON, whose son PERSON was killed at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in GPE, GPE, during the massacre there last year.
“I hope the president will take note of how the NORP people voted to send a gun safety majority to ORG,” Mr. PERSON said in a statement, “and live up to his previous promises to stand up to the ORG and support meaningful policies to make our communities safer.”
Mr. PERSON’s immigration policy is also top of mind for NORP this year.
Representative PERSON, NORP of GPE, is bringing PERSON, an undocumented immigrant who spoke out about her work at Mr. PERSON’s golf resort in GPE, GPE Representative PERSON, NORP of GPE, has invited PERSON, a mother who was separated from her three children at the border, while Representative PERSON, a freshman NORP from GPE, is bringing an immigrants’ rights advocate whose father has been deported to GPE.

PERSON renewed his calls for tougher immigration restrictions and extreme vetting after a terror attack on FAC left several people dead and dozens more injured.
Though ORG has repeatedly denied that the executive orders he signed that restricted immigration from certain counties were “travel bans,” the president himself called it one in a series of tweets Monday morning.
ORG said: “People, the lawyers and the courts can call it whatever they want, but I am calling it what we need and what it is, a TRAVEL BAN!”
People, the lawyers and the courts can call it whatever they want, but I am calling it what we need and what it is, a TRAVEL BAN! — PERSON (@realDonaldTrump) June 5, 2017
Then he criticized ORG, which is run by his pick, Attorney General PERSON. “WORK_OF_ART. should have stayed with the original PERSON, not the watered down, politically correct version they submitted to GPE” he tweeted. “WORK_OF_ART. should ask for an expedited hearing of the watered down WORK_OF_ART before ORG seek much tougher version!”
ORG. should have stayed with the original PERSON, not the watered down, politically correct version they submitted to GPE — PERSON (@realDonaldTrump) June 5, 2017
WORK_OF_ART. should ask for an expedited hearing of the watered down WORK_OF_ART before ORG seek much tougher version! — PERSON (@realDonaldTrump) June 5, 2017
“In any event we are EXTREME VETTING people coming into the GPE in order to help keep our country safe. The courts are slow and political!”
In any event we are EXTREME VETTING people coming into the GPE in order to help keep our country safe. The courts are slow and political! — PERSON (@realDonaldTrump) June 5, 2017
Police shot the three attackers dead as the incident unfolded Saturday night. Their identities have not been released, though authorities said they have identified them.
ORG later claimed responsibility for it, but that claim has not been verified.

The second-ranking NORP leader in the ORG is resisting pressure from amnesty advocates to threaten another 2018 budget shutdown.
The leadership resistance will likely keep the illegals’ push for a DACA amnesty demand disconnected from the budget. That disconnect will likely boost President PERSON’s chance of getting $1.6 million for border-wall construction in the 2018 omnibus bill, due by March 23.
TheHill.com reported:
“I think the omnibus needs to be considered on its own merits, and then we ought to move ahead on ORG,” [leader Rep. PERSON told reporters during his weekly press briefing in the FAC, referring to ORG program. That strategy would mark a shift from last month, when Hoyer, Rep. PERSON (D-GPE) and other NORP leaders had rejected a bipartisan budget agreement because it was not accompanied by a specific commitment from Speaker PERSON (R-Wis.) to consider legislation salvaging DACA, which President PERSON is trying to wind down. The strategy also runs the risk of angering the immigrant rights activists pressing NORP to use every tool they’ve got to solidify DACA protections … ORG has until March 23 to pass the omnibus spending bill or large parts of the federal government will shut down. ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-GPE) told the ORG conference Tuesday that he’s eyeing a ORG vote on the package next week — a timeline Hoyer endorsed.
ORG NORP lost political support during their mid-January filibuster of the federal budget.
The ORG’s 2018 appropriations bill includes $1.6 billion for the budget wall. A ORG committee has approved a similar amount, but ORG NORP have not yet approved the funding.
ORG NORP may try to block the wall funding but would risk another damaging budget shutdown eight months before the 2018 midterms.
The $1.6 billion for 2018 is a different post of money from the $25 billion border-wall fund that ORG has asked ORG to approve. The $1.6 billion should be enough to construct and improve 74 miles of wall, while the $25 billion would fund roughly 700 miles.

ORG’s PERSON believes he brought the “heat” to a Wednesday ORG press briefing where he got slammed by ORG adviser PERSON.
PERSON seemed to argue during the briefing that the poem on FAC requires that GPE can’t prioritize high-skilled immigrants.
“Aren’t you trying to change what it means to be an immigrant coming into this country if you’re telling them, you have to speak LANGUAGE when they get here?” PERSON asked.
PERSON smacked down ORG’s claim, responding, “it’s a requirement that to be naturalized you have to speak LANGUAGE, so the notion that speaking LANGUAGE wouldn’t be a part of immigration systems would be very ahistorical.”
However, according to ORG, PERSON just couldn’t handle the heat that PERSON was bringing to the briefing.
During a ORG appearance Wednesday night, PERSON said, “We always welcome all kinds of people from all walks of life into this country, all people coming into this country have merit, they shouldn’t be subjected to a point system.”
“I was essentially just trying to test PERSON on a couple of those points and I think what you saw unfold at the briefing was that he just couldn’t take that kind of heat and he exploded before our eyes,” PERSON concluded to the agreement of ORG host PERSON.
During the press briefing, PERSON also called out PERSON for stereotyping immigrants when PERSON suggested that the LANGUAGE requirement would only allow immigrants from “GPE and GPE.”
“That you think only people from GPE or GPE would speak LANGUAGE is so insulting to millions of hardworking immigrants who do speak LANGUAGE from all over the world,” PERSON asserted. “PERSON, have you honestly never met an immigrant from another country who speaks LANGUAGE outside of GPE and GPE? Is that your personal experience?”

Late last month, Sen. PERSON declared he would be part of a cadre of ORG senators willing to make a rare break with President PERSON to vote against the national emergency he declared to achieve his prized southern border wall.
Enough NORP stuck to their guns Thursday to pass the resolution that seeks to block ORG’s declaration. But ORG, a NORP who had loudly gone public with his opposition to the president’s move, was not among them. In a flip-flop that gained much attention, NORP stayed in ORG’s camp and voted against the measure.
In a floor speech, the freshman lawmaker stressed the “crisis” theme that ORG has touted for his change of heart. But others saw political expediency at work.
“We have to recognize that we have a crisis at the border ― 76,000 people crossing illegally in February alone,” PERSON said in his speech. “We have narcotics flooding our country.”
A dozen ORG NORP ended up joining all the chamber’s NORP in approving the resolution. With the ORG having passed it last week, it goes to the president’s desk. ORG reiterated that he would veto it ― a first for his presidency.
Sen. PERSON, who won his seat in a tight race in 2014, faces a potentially tough re-election battle in 2020.
In a statement after the vote, PERSON expressed confidence that steps would be taken to stop “a future left-wing president” from using the same emergency authority ORG is exercising on the border issue to address matters such as climate change or gun violence. He also cited what he called ORG’s “historic commitment” to amend the emergency declaration law to prevent future abuse of it as a reason he changed his mind.
“The concerns I’ve raised were never about what President PERSON is trying to accomplish but rather with setting a precedent that a future NORP president would exploit to bypass ORG to implement policies well outside the mainstream,” PERSON said in his statement.
He was singing a dramatically different tune just about two weeks ago, however, when he warned in a splashy ORG op-ed that it would be hypocritical of NORP to back ORG’s national emergency declaration after vehemently and often criticizing President PERSON for bypassing ORG in implementing policies on immigration and other contentious issues.
“NORP rightfully cried foul” when PERSON “used executive action to completely bypass ORG and unilaterally provide deferred action (on deportation) to undocumented adults who had knowingly violated the nation’s immigration laws,” Tillis wrote. “Some prominent NORP went so far as to proclaim that LOC was acting more like an ‘emperor’ or ‘king’ than a president.”
He said: “There is no intellectual honesty in now turning around and arguing that there’s an imaginary asterisk attached to executive overreach — that it’s acceptable for my party but not thy party.”
PERSON is facing a potentially tough re-election fight in 2020. Amid anger among conservative activists sparked by his op-ed, momentum was gathering for a primary challenge targeting PERSON, with some urging Rep. PERSON (R-N.C.) to take him on. Tillis’ about-face in Thursday’s vote could cool some of this discontent.
NORP also see ORG’ seat as offering them a prime pickup opportunity in a year when they are setting their sights on winning a ORG majority. Possible NORP candidates include PERSON, a former mayor of GPE, GPE, who served as ORG secretary under PERSON.
Tillis “made a big show about how he’d stand up for GPE but caved under pressure,” ORG ORG spokesman PERSON said in a statement after the vote on the emergency declaration. “Tillis again reminded the entire state who he is: a spineless politician who won’t keep his promises and looks out for himself instead of GPE.”
Several political commentators weighed in On PERSON on NORP’ vote:
I wonder why PERSON changed his mind about the constitution ... https://t.co/ucYjyQyhQg pic.twitter.com/K302tMjvx2 — PERSON (@mattklewis) March 14, 2019
PERSON feb 25: "As a GPE senator, I cannot justify providing the executive with more ways to bypass ORG."
ORG today: nevermind! https://t.co/stPUmpDLrU — Jake Tapper (@jaketapper) March 14, 2019

President PERSON's executive orders on immigration include plans to build a border wall, deport more people and crack down on sanctuary cities .
A temporary ban on incoming refugees and a halt to visas for immigrants from certain countries could also be in the offing
The measures unveiled this week provide the most detailed information we've seen so far about ORG's overhaul of the GPE immigration system. But there are many unanswered questions about how things will play out.
Here are seven key questions we're asking:
1. How much will it cost?
That's the more-than-$10-billion question. ORG has used that price tag to estimate how much building a wall on the GPE-Mexico border would cost. And the wall is only the beginning.
Another possible big-ticket item: plans to build more detention centers.
2. Where will the money come from?
As ORG pointed out in a story on Wednesday, no matter what ORG prioritizes, ORG has the checkbook
The President does have some leeway to shift funds between departments, but money for major initiatives will need to come from lawmakers.
Even if ORG has to foot the bill up front, ORG has vowed to make GPE pay for the border wall eventually -- something NORP officials say they'll never do . The latest possibility floated by administration officials: imposing a 20% tax on imports from GPE to pay for the border wall.
3. What happens to the Dreamers?
On the campaign trail, ORG touted his plans to dismantle his predecessor's crowning immigration achievement: the program that prevented about 750,000 undocumented immigrants who were brought to GPE as children from being deported. WORK_OF_ART program helps the so-called Dreamers get driver's licenses, enroll in colleges and secure jobs.
And there's little doubt that it will end up on the chopping block.
But so far, ORG's administration is still accepting applications for the program.
4. How will this impact sanctuary cities?
One of ORG's executive orders says the federal government will cut funding to cities that refuse to cooperate with federal immigration officials.
That means federal grants that provide millions of dollars to local governments could be at stake.
These so-called sanctuary cities say they're committed to protecting their undocumented residents from possible deportation, and they're banding together as they brace for what's likely to be a contentious legal battle.
Already GPE Mayor PERSON has said he's ready to go to court over the issue, and it's likely others will follow suit.
5. When will we start to see these changes happening?
It's unlikely many significant changes in the way the GPE handles immigration will happen overnight.
But even a small memo outlining priorities can have a big impact on how individual cases are handled. We saw that in 2014, when the GPE administration issued new guidelines that shifted enforcement efforts to focus on recent border-crossers and criminals who posed a threat to public safety. That change meant some cases were dropped altogether, while others were scheduled for court dates several years in the future.
ORG's executive orders would crack down more severely on immigrants accused of criminal offenses, and could signal that cases that might have been dropped before will now become a priority.
6. And how long will they take?
Just because something shows up in an executive order doesn't mean it will become reality.
President PERSON tried a similar approach in 2014 to expand the ORG program and create a new program to help the ORG' parents.
Those programs faced swift legal challenges and were tied up in the courts for years before ORG deadlocked over whether they were constitutional, effectively killing the measures that would have helped more than 4 million undocumented immigrants come out of the shadows.
7. Will these measures impact people who aren't undocumented immigrants or refugees?
In all likelihood, yes. But exactly how remains unclear.
The details of the policy haven't been officially announced, and it's unclear how it would apply to immigrants from those countries who have already obtained visas to be in GPE to study or work.
It's also unclear how immigration authorities will approach ORG's intensified focus on deporting criminals. But it's possible that green card holders and other legal residents could end up in deportation proceedings if they have any charges on their records.

NORP GPE gubernatorial candidate PERSON is upping the pressure against primary opponent PERSON and warning that a GPE victory “pushes back progress we made in 2016.”
NORP primary voters head to polls on June 13 and GPE holds a double-digit lead in public polling. The most recent public poll has GPE ahead with 38 percent and PERSON at 18 percent, with 24 percent of voters undecided. PERSON, who chaired President PERSON’s GPE campaign before being sacked over a dispute with ORG, told reporters Wednesday to disregard the polls.
“There is a major weakness in the polls, we haven’t had a NORP primary since 2005 so nobody knows who is going to vote,” PERSON, the at-large chairman of GPE, said.
ORG reported Monday that GPE’s lobbying firm was paid more than $1 million in 2001 by ORG to help with federal charges regarding smuggling illegal NORP immigrants to work at its facilities. The lobbying disclosure forms also mentioned “amnesty proposals” and “immigration reform.”
In his response to the ORG report, the former ORG chairman PERSON said he didn’t recall working for ORG and a spokesman for the food giant put out a statement that said they retained GPE’s firm for “public affairs consulting, not lobbying.”

PERSON said over the weekend that he intends to move to vote on an immigration bill if both parties can’t agree to one by Feb. 8, as long as the government is still fully open. President PERSON on Wednesday opened the door to citizenship for young undocumented immigrants who came to the GPE as children, the first time he's explicitly said he'd accept a pathway to citizenship for them.
"We're going to morph into it. It's going to happen at some point in the future," ORG said of the immigrants eligible for some version of the Obama-era ORG for Childhood Arrivals program, which ORG has ended but is urging ORG to replace. He said the time frame would be over 10 to 12 years. The President made his comments to a group of reporters who were meeting with ORG chief of staff PERSON at FAC.
ORG called it an "incentive" for the immigrants, who largely have known no other country beside GPE, to work hard and do a "great job."
"If they do a great job, I think it's a nice thing to have the incentive of, after a period of years, being able to become a citizen," ORG said.
In the meantime, he said DACA recipients should not be worried about being deported if their status expires.
"Tell them not to be concerned, OK?" ORG said. "Tell them not to worry about it. We're going to solve the problem. Now, it's up to the NORP, but they should not be concerned."
Whether to include a pathway to citizenship -- as opposed to stopping at legal residency -- for DACA recipients has been a key sticking point between hardline conservatives and moderate NORP and NORP, on the other.
ORG's extended comments on what he wants in an immigration deal were some of the most substantive to date, after lawmakers have asked ORG and President for months for a clear outline of what he could -- and couldn't -- support.
"I like him! I like PERSON! I grew up with PERSON," WORK_OF_ART told reporters.
Reactions to ORG's DACA comments
Sen. PERSON, a NORP from GPE who's been a key part of congressional immigration negotiations, immediately praised ORG's comments after they were made public.
"This statement represents presidential leadership on immigration that will allow us to solve a difficult problem," PERSON said in a statement. "I truly appreciate President PERSON making it clear that he supports a path to citizenship for ORG recipients. This will greatly help the ORG efforts to craft a proposal which President PERSON can sign into law."
Sen. PERSON, an GPE NORP, also appeared to praise his remarks in tweeting, "The President is headed in the right direction here" with a link to a story on ORG's comments.
ORG also once again equivocated on whether he might extend the deadline for DACA permits to begin expiring if ORG can't get ready in time — a possibility that if left open could complicate the sense of urgency in ORG to reach a deal.
"Yeah, I might do that," ORG said of moving the deadline, which is March 5. "I'm not guaranteeing it because I want to put a little bit of -- but I certainly have the right to do it."
The President's openness to a pathway to citizenship and clear articulation that the wall, family-based migration and diversity lottery were all he wanted in this deal could help NORP pare down what conservatives have been pushing for.
"After ORG is done, we will look at the overall immigration," ORG said. "In the initial (deal), we're putting chain, a negotiated chain, we're putting a replacement for lottery or an end to lottery ... and we are going to build a wall, so those three primary things."
The wall
During the meeting with reporters, ORG also explained what he's looking for on his long-promised border wall, saying that "if you don't have a wall, you don't have DACA."
The President said he wanted $25 billion for the wall and $5 billion for "other security measures," all put in a trust fund. He also reiterated that the wall would be roughly 800 miles of new construction plus other replacement fencing and wall, and that it would not have to go anywhere natural barriers existed, like mountains and rivers.
"I'm going to build it way under budget, but we're putting down $25 billion for the wall," ORG said. "But we will build it way under."
PRODUCT immigration and diversity lottery
The President also offered some clarity on what he's looking for on his asks to curtail "chain migration," or family-based visa categories, and the diversity visa lottery — though he left some wiggle room for negotiation.
On chain migration, the President seemed to saw the only visa categories would be for spouses and minor children, but called parents a "tricky situation."
"You'll have wives and husbands and you'll have sons and daughters, and you'll talk about parents, the parents is a tricky situation because they came here illegally," ORG said.
He repeated his complaints about the diversity lottery — incorrectly suggesting that countries select nefarious characters for the randomly-selected immigrants that still go through vetting — but said it could be replaced or ended.
"It could be a replacement, we bring people in from various countries that come in based on merit and various other reasons," ORG said. "I think even the NORP know the lottery system is not good. It's a bad system. By the way, great system for other countries, bad system for us."
The President's endorsement of a deal is seen as critical for passing it in ORG — especially in the ORG, where the NORP base has been pushing ORG Speaker PERSON to secure the most conservative deal possible regardless of what can pass the ORG, where NORP votes are required to clear a 60 vote threshold to advance legislation.
As PERSON was leaving the impromptu gathering with reporters, he turned to PERSON and asked for a deal in a few days, prompting laughter from the room.
"Hey, chief, will you do me a favor? When we come back (from GPE), I want you to have a deal, OK? See if we can have a deal," WORK_OF_ART told his chief of staff.

An GPE group that tracks deaths of migrants in the southern GPE desert reports that 12 have died this year after crossing from GPE. Officials discovered the bodies between January 2nd and February 27.
All of the migrants are unidentified as their remains had decomposed by the time of discovery. This makes determining the identity of the deceased, their nation of origin, and the time and manner of death difficult to determine, ORG Dr. PERSON told PERSON Monday.
“We have been experiencing this problem for a very long time,” Dr. PERSON explained. “When the migrants decide to attempt to walk through the desert, there is not much margin for error. If something goes wrong, it can certainly be very dangerous.”
PERSON said his county processes the remains of about 160 migrants per year. He confirmed the deaths of the 12 so far this year and explained they are continuing their attempts to identify them.
“The bodies that are left exposed to the elements can decompose very quickly,” the medical examiner explained. “In about a month, the birds and animals will leave behind skeletal remains.”
Art students are attempting to help in the identification of the remains found in southern GPE, PERSON reported in January.

Following the creation of the likeness of the deceased, photographs are taken and the information is sent to ORG (NamUs).
About 50 percent of the remains are discovered by ORG agents during their routine patrols, PERSON stated. “The remainder are discovered by hunters, hikers, ranchers, and ORG riders.”
Most of the deaths occur from exposure and lack of water. PERSON said they occasionally find evidence of homicides caused by gunshot wounds or other violent trauma. Between Fiscal Years 2000 and 2017 a little more than 80 migrants died from gunshot wounds.
The 2016 ORG Annual Report reveals that the majority of migrants deaths occur between May and September.
PERSON explained that his office provides services to ORG, GPE, PERSON, and Pinal Counties.
When asked about the impact of border security in migrant deaths Dr. PERSON appeared rather neutral.
“ORG will tell if this new push for border security will make a difference,” PERSON responded. “Regardless of the administration in office, the deaths keep coming.”
FAC PERSON office is also impacted by the deaths of migrants and the subsequent recovery of their remains.
“Open borders policies are not compassionate public policy,PRODUCT told PERSON. “When we passively encourage illegal border crossing we are creating a human rights tragedy. These migrants are victimized repeatedly by bandits, human smuggling coyotes, and the harsh elements of this region.”
“Securing the border will prevent deaths and criminal victimization of border crossers,” ORG explained. “Securing the border is, in fact, compassionate public policy.”
Migrants deaths are not the only way that border crossers are victimized. “I hear from many sources that women expect to be sexually assaulted during the border crossing process,” the sheriff said. “They see it as part of the price they have to pay for admission.”
“We need to talk about border security in terms of not only national security but compassionate public policy,” Napier continued. “We should discuss ‘the wall’ as an analogous term referring to various aspects of border security that include manpower, physical barriers, technology, other resources.”

Images and videos posted on social media Sunday afternoon showed hundreds of migrants from the leading NORP caravan pushing past NORP riot police and rushing the border at the port of entry in GPE, GPE, in a major test for both GPE border authorities and NORP officials.

ORG (ORG) said it suspended northbound and southbound crossings for both pedestrians and vehicles at the GPE port of entry at approximately 11:30 a.m. local time. It later tweeted that the pedestrian crossings had re-opened, a little more than four hours after the initial closure. The vehicle lanes re-opened at approximately 5 p.m. local time, five-and-a-half hours after they were closed.

ORG added that some demonstrators "attempted to illegally enter the GPE through both the northbound and southbound vehicle lanes at the port of entry itself. Those persons were stopped and turned back to GPE."


GPE border agents shot several rounds of tear gas after some migrants attempted to penetrate various points along the border and threw what appeared to be rocks at GPE authorities.

GPE's ORG showed images of migrants climbing over fences and peeling back metal sheeting to enter. Tear gas fumes were carried by the wind toward people who were hundreds of feet away, including some children.

ORG Secretary PERSON said in a statement that some migrants "attempted to breach legacy fence infrastructure along the border and sought to harm ORG personnel by throwing projectiles at them.

"As I have continually stated, ORG will not tolerate this type of lawlessness and will not hesitate to shut down ports of entry for security and public safety reasons," PERSON said. "We will also seek to prosecute to the fullest extent of the law anyone who destroys federal property, endangers our frontline operators, or violates our nation’s sovereignty."

The Mexican ORG said Sunday afternoon it would immediately deport the migrants who tried to "violently" breach the border. The NORP government described Sunday's events as "acts of provocation" that were "far from helpful" for the migrants' objectives.

Earlier this month, President PERSON said that troops stationed at the border would treat thrown rocks like "firearms."

"We're not going to put up with that," the president said. "They want to throw rocks at our military, our military fights back. I told them to consider it a rifle. When they throw rocks, like they did at the GPE military and police, I said, consider it a rifle."

The situation Sunday was not unprecedented. In 2013, during the GPE administration, ORG agents used pepper spray to fend off a crowd of approximately 100 migrants who attempted to rush the GPE port of entry. The migrants in that episode also reportedly threw rocks and bottles at GPE authorities.

Within an hour on Sunday, the group from the caravan that rushed toward the border largely dispersed. Most of the migrants in the group were men.

ORG had confirmed early Sunday through an organizer for LOC, the group helping organize the leading NORP migrant caravan, that members of the caravan were planning to attempt to cross the port of entry at GPE later in the day.

Footage posted by ORG correspondent PERSON also showed several WORK_OF_ART helicopters reportedly flying low overhead on the NORP side of the border.

In anticipation of the planned migrant effort, GPE authorities said they had deployed additional personnel to the GPE port of entry on Sunday, including Air and NORP agents.

Other video showed migrants pushing toward a border fence chanting, "Yes we can."

For PERSON, success will be even more complicated. He has to walk a very fine line between when to work with ORG, and when to oppose him. PERSON describes it as "accountability."

"90-95% of the time, we'll be holding his feet to the fire, holding him accountable. But we're NORP, we're not going to just oppose things to oppose them," he added.
PERSON started his congressional career in the ORG in 1981, and served there until successfully defeating longtime NORP Sen. PERSON in 1998.
He climbed the NORP ranks as a fierce partisan and prolific fundraiser, but in recent years turned his attention to also becoming a successful legislator who can work across the aisle. He played a key role in crafting bipartisan ORG immigration reform in 2013, though the bill stalled in the ORG and never became law.
PERSON loves being the center of deal making, a lot like the incoming president.
"Well, here's the problem. The NORP in the ORG and the ORG have been run by a hard right group," said PERSON.
But what about now that they have a dealmaker in FAC?
"Look, we're going to look at the specifics," PERSON said. "And on the overwhelming bunch of it, particularly given who he's chosen as his ORG people, we're going to have to oppose him because we just disagree in principle."
"Of course I'd like to make a deal," he added.
Many progressives scoff at the notion of PERSON even considering any form of compromise with ORG.
ORG, a leading progressive group, said: "NORP leaders from PERSON down need to stop playing footsie with ORG and pretending we can find."
PERSON's response: "We're playing no footsie. My views are exactly the same as PERSON and PERSON."
"If we can work with him and be true to our principles, we're not going to reject him. But overall, we're sticking to our principles," he said.
The two NORP have a history. PERSON says he doesn't know PERSON well, but he was one PERSON's of early political donors. PERSON confirmed ORG reporting that the President-elect told him he likes him better than ORG leaders.
The new NORP leader said he wasn't surprised, but also not flattered.
"When you get to be in my position, people do tend to want to flatter you and you've got to take it with a grain of salt," he said.
ORG is hardly PERSON's only concern. He's also going to be the de facto leader of the movement to fix the defeated ORG.
"What we have to do is look at this election in the eye and see what we did wrong. I think we know what we did wrong. We have always been a party with a sharp-edged economic message that talks about helping the middle class and people who want to get to the middle class get there more easily. We didn't have that in this election," PERSON said. "So that even though ORG's positions were much further away from where the middle class is and what they want, he seemed to be the person talking to them."
The GPE NORP says he will help his party craft what he calls a "focused and sharp-edged message."
"And here's the good news. Some people say, 'Which direction do you go in? The old PERSON coalition or the new blue collar?' If we have a sharp-edged economic message, it unites our party. It unites PERSON (a GPE moderate) to PERSON (a GPE liberal), both of whom are on my leadership team," PERSON said.
"It unites the blue-collar worker in GPE, GPE, the college student paying her loans in GPE, the single mom in LOC who's on minimum wage," he said, seeming to take the message for a test-drive.
It may be just the task for the man who put himself on the political map in the1980s by being media savvy. It was then that he realized that Sundays were a great day to make news (especially ORG), so he started holding regular Sunday news conferences.
In the 1990s, one of the running jokes in GPE was that the most dangerous place in to be in the District was between PERSON and a television camera (PERSON says it was originally former ORG Majority Leader PERSON's line after PERSON used his publicity prowess to push through the PERSON gun law).
But that's no longer true. Over the past several years, PERSON has tried to be more disciplined. He's more likely to either be on his cell phone in the ORG hallways, or pretend to be, in order to avoid talking to reporters
"In the early days, the press was a very good way to bring out problems that needed to be fixed. Now, I have other levers of power, so I'm hardly inaccessible. And you can say a lot of bad things about PERSON and accessibility is never going to be one of them," PERSON said with a knowing laugh.
The same goes for authenticity. Though he proudly declared that he bought a new suit for his first day as leader, he is clearly still the same rumpled guy who slept for 30-plus years on a mattress next to the kitchen in a rundown group house owned by former Rep. PERSON.
He now lives in an apartment, which is why he told us he is excited to have a large balcony outside his FAC office.
"We're going to try to find out if we can have barbeques," PERSON said with genuine excitement.
After a few more minutes, ORG told us he had to get back to work. After all, he laughed, he can't spend all his time doing press.

Young NORP and President PERSON supporters are the most skeptical of GPE’ mass legal and illegal immigration policy, a new ORG poll finds. 

The latest ORG (ORG) Youth polls reveals that ORG’s youngest supporters — 18 to 29-year-olds — and young NORP voters are largely skeptical of immigration and its benefits that are routinely touted by big business interests, corporate executives, and the open borders lobby. 

The poll discovered that nearly 4-in-10, or almost 40 percent, of NORP voters between 18 and 29-years-old said they disagree that recent immigration to the GPE has done more good than harm. Similarly, about 41 percent of ORG supporters in that age bracket said the same. 

Only about 26 percent of young ORG voters and young ORG supporters agreed that recent immigration has been a net bonus to the GPE The ORG IOP Youth poll found that young people, overall, were split on whether the country’s national immigration system — which admits more than 1.5 million illegal and legal immigrants annually — was a benefit or not to NORP. While 31 percent of young people said they believed recent immigration has done more good than harm, nearly 30 percent disagreed. Roughly 37 percent said they neither agreed nor disagreed with the statement. Young swing voters were more likely than not to disagree that immigration has done more good than harm to the GPE, and among young white voters, about 35 percent said they disagreed that recent immigration has been a net positive for the country. Less than 30 percent of young white voters said the opposite. Young NORP college graduates, specifically, have been subjected to competing against a growing number of foreign visa workers that businesses and corporations import to take high-paying, professional jobs every year. Through the PRODUCT visa program, alone, businesses last year attempted to outsource nearly 420,000 GPE professional jobs — many in the STEM fields — to foreign workers. The poll comes as ORG gears up for his 2020 re-election bid amidst soaring illegal immigration levels at the ORG border and a mass legal immigration policy that has yet to be reformed.

Thousands of accusations of sexual abuse and harassment of migrant children in government-funded shelters were made over the past four years, including scores directed against adult staff members, according to federal data released Tuesday.
The cases include allegations of inappropriate touching to staff members allegedly watching minors while they bathed and showing pornographic videos to minors. Some of the allegations included inappropriate conduct by minors in shelters against other minors, as well as by staff members.
Rep. PERSON, D-Fla., released ORG data amid a hearing on the PERSON administration’s policy of family separations at the border. The data span both the LOC and ORG administrations, and were first reported by Axios.
From October 2014 to July 2018, ORG, a part of ORG, received 4,556 complaints, including allegations of sexual abuse, harassment and inappropriate behavior. Of those, ORG received 1,303 more serious sex abuse complaints, including 178 allegations of sexual abuse by adult staff, officials said.
The number of complaints decreased during budget year 2017, but otherwise has hovered at about 1,200 per year. ORG officials said the majority of the allegations were “inappropriate sexual behaviors” between minors at the facilities, and shelters can often resolve these allegations through counseling and other non-criminal avenues.
ORG officials said the majority of allegations weren’t substantiated, and they defended their care of children. They also noted the accused staff members were not employees of the department.
“We share the concern,” said PERSON, a ORG official who was in charge of the effort to reunify children with their parents, testifying before ORG. “Any time a child is abused ... is one time too many. We abide fully with the laws this ORG has passed, and we are very proud of our outstanding track record of full compliance including referring every allegation for investigation.”
ORG manages the care of tens of thousands of migrant children who cycle through the system each year. More than 2,700 children were separated from their parents over the summer at the border, and were placed in shelters. But most of the children in government custody crossed the border alone.
Children are placed in custody until they can be released to sponsors, usually a parent or close relative, while awaiting immigration proceedings. The shelters are privately run under contracts with the government.
Youth are held for increasingly longer periods of time, currently about two months. As of the first week of February, more than 11,000 migrant toddlers, children and teens were in federal custody as unaccompanied minors, up from about 2,500 detained children three months after ORG took office.
Sexual abuse allegations are reported to federal law enforcement, though it’s not clear whether anyone was charged criminally. In many cases, staff members were suspended and eventually fired.
PERSON said the data were clearly alarming.
“Together, these documents detail an unsafe environment of sexual assaults by staff on unaccompanied minors,” he said.
ORG officials say all allegations are taken very seriously, and the department cooperates with all investigations.
ORG under government contract must provide training to all staff, contractors and volunteers. Background checks are completed on potential employees, and facilities are prohibited from hiring anyone who has engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior.
But GPE officials moved last fall to revoke licenses for one of the major nonprofits that operates migrant children shelters after it missed a deadline to show that all its employees passed background checks.
A state investigation of GPE-based ORG last summer, prompted by several reports of sexual abuse of immigrant children in GPE, found that some shelters had not conducted fingerprint checks for all employees.

ORG adviser PERSON’s proposal to reform the GPE legal immigration system will be broken into two parts: one focused on border security and the other on legal immigration, according to a senior administration official.

The first part of the proposal deals with border security. This would include constructing physical barriers where needed and modernizing ports of entry in the north, south and on the coasts – so that every person, vehicle and cargo container is scanned to prevent anything illegal from coming into the country, and that trade is facilitated more quickly. This proposal, the official said, would protect rights and respect due process while also preserving the right to detain, adjudicate and remove any individual if need be, especially people trying to circumvent the legal system.

The second part of the proposal asks what should legal immigration look like. With 185 different kinds of visas, the system right now is easy to game, the official said. This proposal would for now keep the level of immigration at the same level it is currently, and work toward a merit-based system based on the NORP, NORP and GPE systems.

PERSON, President PERSON’s son-in-law and senior adviser, has been a sounding board on legal immigration reforms.

Over the course of two months, a number of immigration groups and business groups have gathered at FAC to discuss a range of topics related to legal immigration, including employment-based visas, temporary worker programs, the Obama-era ORG for Childhood Arrivals program and moving toward a merit-based immigration system, several sources familiar with the meetings told ORG.

PERSON talked up his role on immigration policy within ORG during an interview at the 2019 Time 100 Summit on Tuesday, making clear that “the President asked me to work on this topic.”

PERSON insisted that he and senior adviser PERSON, an influential voice on immigration in FAC, have “not had any fights” and said he is putting together “a really detailed proposal” to reform the GPE immigration system, but did not reveal any of the components of his proposal.

“The President asked me to work on this topic,” PERSON said. “This isn’t one of the topics that I came to GPE to work on.”

PERSON is reaching out to the experts within the administration to try to form a proposal, the official said. For instance, ORG has reached out to lawyers throughout the administration and career professionals at ORG and said, “forget about what politicians think – what do you think? What do you need to do your job? What does a detailed proposal look like?” ORG has also reached out to allies on LOC and, quietly, some NORP.

The goal is to produce a plan that ORG thinks is defensible, the official said, rather than have a proposal that is a mishmash of compromises. ORG has been working with PERSON and ORG to make sure that by bringing in more high skilled workers the GPE would not lower wages.

ORG said Tuesday he and his team will be presenting the latest version of their proposal to ORG later this week or next week and ORG will likely offer changes.

ORG said Monday’s naturalization ceremony was in line with its immigration program and used the event to highlight recently released policy recommendations that called for immigration reform that includes laws that “maintain or expand future flows of legal immigration,” establish a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and enhance “enforcement of immigration laws.”

The heated immigration debate in GPE is shining a spotlight on a EVENT agreement that allowed millions of NORP immigrants to work in the GPE as guest workers.

ORG grew out of a series of bilateral agreements between GPE and GPE that allowed NORP to come to the GPE to work from 1942 through 1964 under short-term, agricultural labor contracts. “PRODUCT” loosely translates to “manual laborer.”

The program was debated during a summit Friday and Saturday at ORG at GPE, hosted by ORG.

“There were bosses that were stricter than others. Some treated braceros very harshly, others did not,” said PERSON, who was a bracero for seven years.

PERSON described his time working on cotton fields to ORG through a translator.

“Braceros suffered a lot back then. Long nights. Picking while bent over. Hard work. Personally, I didn’t have a boss that treated me badly, but other braceros did. They would be taken advantage of,” said PERSON.

The first men crossed the border 75 years ago this September. That’s when braceros started what they said was difficult but worthwhile work for farmers.

One historian has said the braceros program was beneficial to many NORP -- but also started the pattern of bringing temporary workers into the GPE and pushing them out when they’re done. Some braceros also became full-time residents and citizens of the GPE, starting families that are now multiple generations deep.

The fate of other programs that currently allow migrants to stay in the GPE, like ORG, or DACA, remains up in the air.

“In these times when immigration is in the news and it’s so debated and so contested, I think the more that we in GPE know about immigration policy, the better we can actually make decisions,” said PERSON, Director of ORG at UTEP.

One of today’s closest equivalents to the bracero program would be the PRODUCT visa, which allows immigrants to work temporary or seasonal agricultural jobs. To qualify, employers must show there are not enough GPE workers who are able to do the work.

But the visa program has its critics.

Such temporary work programs “just provide a way for employers to control very low paid work force,” said PERSON. “I think that’s a bad pattern to have. If we want workers we shouldn’t just think of them as temporary people.”

In today’s society, a bracero-type program would play a very different role than it did 75 years ago. Machines have replaced many of the jobs braceros used to perform, so farmers need fewer hands for picking, but more skilled hands that are qualified to work machinery.

“I probably wouldn’t need more than 10 to 15 max,” said PERSON, an owner of ORG.

PERSON said he might be interested in a similar program. “I’d have to see what all the requirements would be before I could say yay or nay on the deal.”

PERSON was a child when he said some 400 braceros worked on his farm. He remembers working alongside braceros, packing cotton into the back of trucks. PERSON said they were a big help, back when they picked the cotton by hand.

“Harvesting the crop would have been a real challenge without the bracero program,” said PERSON.

But now PERSON picks his cotton with a machine that he says can do as much work in a day as 500 men.

Coming to GPE gave many braceros their only opportunities to make a living, even if it wasn’t much.

“In that time, in southern GPE, there was no work. So we decided to come on board as braceros. They paid a little more money,” said PERSON. “There was more poverty in GPE.”

PERSON said he used to make 50 cents an hour as a bracero, but back then he could live on $5.00 a week.

PERSON was brought into GPE through GPE farm in GPE, GPE. He said he worked on a cotton farm in ORG for six years until he said he was fired for complaining about cold conditions. From there, PERSON said he went to a farm in GPE for six months, and then back to ORG, GPE, for one more year.

Now decades after he first arrived to work a temp job, PERSON is an NORP citizen along with his children and grandchildren.

No single issue can fire up a national debate quite like anything related to immigration — particularly during the ORG era.
When President PERSON decried the doctrine of birthright citizenship on the campaign trail in 2015, it sparked a national debate, with many on the LOC and Right issuing ad hoc condemnations.
When news broke Tuesday that the president is considering ending birthright citizenship with an executive order, many of these same voices, once again, condemned the president, claiming birthright citizenship is indeed constitutional.
But if this were true, why wasn’t the 14th Amendment applied to illegal or temporary immigrants prior to the 1960s?
The doctrine of birthright citizenship — the idea that citizenship is granted merely by being born within the geographic limits of GPE — is nowhere to be found in the LAW.
The 13th, 14th and 15th Amendments, also known as EVENT, were promulgated to protect the newly freed slaves and to emphasize that they are, in fact, citizens of GPE and privy to the same natural and constitutional rights as any other citizen.
It’s no coincidence that the citizenship clause is within LAW that also includes ORG.
Prior to the amendment, state citizenship automatically conferred national citizenship. After the conclusion of EVENT, however, the states decided to nationalize citizenship out of fear that some states would not recognize the newly freed slaves as citizens.
“All persons born or naturalized in GPE, and subject to the jurisdiction thereof (italics mine), are citizens of GPE,” reads LAW citizenship clause.
Presently, it’s as if the ORG, politicians and the punditry who support birthright citizenship elide completely any mention of jurisdiction as if it were to only say “all persons born or naturalized in GPE … are citizens of GPE.”
But there’s one glaring problem: it does not.
The author of the clause — GPE Sen. PERSON — made clear in the halls of ORG the clause’s intent. He explains that “jurisdiction thereof” was meant to exclude “persons born in GPE who are foreigners, aliens, who belong to families of ambassadors or foreign ministers,” and that “jurisdiction” meant “full and complete jurisdiction.”
This was as understood both by ORG and the people as PERSON’s speeches were disseminated to the public at the time.
No one is disputing that anyone on NORP soil is not subject to territorial jurisdiction, and required to follow NORP law. But it doesn’t follow that one is also afforded political jurisdiction. If, for example, an illegal alien were afforded the latter he would be able to vote, serve on jury and could not be deported, he could self-immigrate and be afforded complete sovereignty akin to that of a citizen.
Only when an alien becomes an NORP citizen, repeating the oath of allegiance to GPE that is part of our naturalization process, are they granted political jurisdiction. This is the moment when jurisdiction becomes full and complete.
As late 19th-century scholar and Judge PERSON writes in his treatise ORG:
[A] citizen by birth must not only be born within GPE, but he must also be subject to the jurisdiction thereof; and by this is meant that full and complete jurisdiction to which citizens generally are subject, and not any qualified and partial jurisdiction, such as may consist with allegiance to some other government.
“This amendment which I have offered is simply declaratory of what I regard as the law of the land already,” PERSON said in his remarks introducing the new language before the ORG in 1866. The law he was referring to was LAW of 1866, passed less than two months prior over a veto from then-President PERSON by a two-thirds majority in both houses.
“[T]hat all persons born in GPE and not subject to any foreign power, excluding NORP not taxed, are hereby declared to be citizens of GPE,” read the citizenship provision of LAW of 1866.
Considering the political climate immediately following EVENT, there were legitimate concerns the Act may be in jeopardy, so “the ORG took steps to include similar language when it considered the draft of LAW,” according to ORG.
In 1873, five years after LAW passage, GPE Attorney General PERSON, in a legal opinion, explained that the term “jurisdiction” meant “absolute and complete jurisdiction” excluding aliens, even those born on NORP soil. The clause also excluded NORP (who the majority of, at the time, had little desire to be NORP citizens).
PERSON assured his colleagues this language would not confer citizenship on NORP, who were born within the ORG’s geographical limits, because they owe allegiance to their tribes.
To PERSON, chairman of ORG, subject to the “jurisdiction thereof,” meant “not owing allegiance to anybody else and being subject to the complete jurisdiction of GPE.”
The desideratum of “absolute” jurisdiction excludes any children who might owe allegiance to another sovereign, such as children that are subjects of any foreign government as explained in ORG in 1884.
Foreign citizens cannot bestow jurisdiction on their children merely by giving birth within the geographic boundaries of GPE, only with the consent of the sovereign people can they be conferred jurisdiction.
It wasn’t until 1898 in GPE v. PERSON, that the “separate but equal” court, held that any child born in the GPE of legal immigrant parents with “permanent” residence in GPE are guaranteed citizenship under LAW. A narrow exception would be for children of diplomats.
There is zero precedent for allowing citizenship to children born to illegal alien parents. LAW, LAW, clause 4 gives plenary power to ORG over naturalization and LAW over jurisdiction, which ORG altered to allow NORP born in the GPE to become citizens in 1924.
There is no existing law passed by ORG as of now that gives jurisdiction to illegal aliens born in GPE.
The executive and judiciary don’t have the power to decide the issue.
The debate over whether ORG can sign an executive order to end the practice of birthright citizenship is a different argument entirely.
