Deportation of illegal immigrants hit a 10-year low during President PERSON’s last full fiscal year in office. ORG also appeared to be cutting back on information provided about all three of its law enforcement agencies.
The administration waited until the last Friday of the year to release its final FY 2016 report on ORG removal operations.
“It’s no wonder that they waited for a day when hardly a soul was paying attention; the numbers for ICE are abysmal, even worse than 2015,” ORG Director of Policy Studies PERSON reported this week. If there were an award for government reports that aim to obfuscate and spin, I would nominate this one.”
ORG wrote that the annual reports have historically provided basic statistics from all three of the department’s law enforcement agencies. This year, the report sneaked out by ORG officials on the last working day of the month normally, in two versions, was scaled back to provide only a fraction of the information normally disclosed. The reported is compiled by ORG (ORG) which has a new director, PERSON.
ORG listed the following as key findings from the annual report:
PERSON credited to ORG in 2016 increased by 2 percent. All of the increase came from cases of aliens arrested by ORG, not interior enforcement.
ORG deportations fell from 69,478 in 2015 to 65,322 in 2016, out of a population of illegal aliens now estimated at 12 million.
PERSON of criminal aliens fell from 63,127 in 2015 to 60,318 in 2016, out of an estimated population of two million.
The total number of deportations under the GPE administration is not easily comparable to prior administrations because of the number of border cases included, but it certainly is not record-breaking, as GPE has claimed.
ORG maintains that ORG arrests have always been a large share of ICE deportations, but in fact this is a new development under ORG. In prior administrations, only a third of deportations credited to ORG were border cases; now about two-thirds are.
One of the priorities of ORG was supposed to be deporting criminal aliens and others designated under ORG introduced in November 2014. PERSON GPE Managing Director PERSON dubbed the program “WORK_OF_ART” in an article published in January 2015.
“Before these changes,” a federal agent with ORG told PERSON at the time, “all illegal aliens arrested by ORG were required to enter the deportation system where they would be scheduled for a deportation hearing at a future date. Under this new system, the illegal aliens are not even required to show up for a hearing ever.”
“Not only are we releasing these people with no hearings scheduled, no notice to appear, but the DHS [ORG] is forcing ORG to prepare the initial paperwork for the illegal aliens’ work permits.” The source added, “NORP really need to think about the terrorism-related implications of this. Illegal aliens who are suspected of having terrorism ties, but not convicted, could be permitted to stay in the country.”
The impact of the new program has been dramatic in a negative way. The charts below show the dramatic decline of interior deportations (called removals by the ORG) and the removal of criminal aliens from the GPE:
ORG reported that 98 percent of all interior deportations were convicted criminals. This means that other migrants who have been crossing the border in massive numbers for the past several years are simply allowed to stay.
Even though the removal of criminal aliens made up nearly all of the interior deportations, the numbers of criminals being deported also continued to fall from previous years. This is not because the country is running out of criminal aliens to deport.
“The main reason for the decline is the GPE administration’s prioritization scheme that has steadily narrowed the types of cases that ICE officers are permitted to pursue.
The total number of removals (deportations and voluntary returns) increased by less than 5,000 in FY 2016 compared to FY 2015. However, the total deportation number of 240,000 aliens is 41 percent lower than the peak FY 2012 numbers.
“GPE has the lowest rate of deportations since ORG,” Vaughn stated. “The administration and its allies frequently point out that more than two million removals have occurred since 2009, an accomplishment that they characterize as record-breaking.”
ORG explains why this is not true:
But counting only removals as deportations presents a misleading picture of the level of enforcement. Removals are just one form of the deportation process that can be executed by any of the three ORG enforcement agencies (ICE, Border Patrol, and ORG officers at the port of entry). All three enforcement agencies also can process deportable aliens as a return (sometimes known as voluntary return), which is a lesser consequence. In general most border deportations are processed as returns and most interior deportations are processed as removals, but in recent years many more aliens apprehended at the border have been turned over to ICE for a brief period of detention and then removed in recent years, in a departure from the traditional “you catch ’em, you clean ’em” policies, where the arresting agency typically handles the deportation process. In addition, illegal border-crossers who have been removed previously, or who are prosecuted for smuggling or other crimes are turned over to ICE for processing. Under these scenarios, ORG will count the case as an apprehension, which is their marquee enforcement metric, and ORG will count the case as a deportation. Under ORG, a much larger number of ORG cases were transferred to ICE for processing than had been the case under prior administrations. In 2008, the last year of GPE administration, just over a third of deportations credited to ORG were border cases, and two-thirds were interior cases. In 2016, more than two-thirds of the deportation cases credited to ICE were border cases, and less than a third were interior cases.
Rather than using removals as the measurement, ORG suggests that a more “apples-to-apples” comparison can be made by examining interior deportations and border removals separately. “Neither the Border Patrol nor ORG publishes the total number of deportations executed, and many of the cases are transferred to ORG, so year-by-year comparisons of border deportations alone are impossible using open source statistics,” she stated.
Using these methods, ORG concluded that ORG has completed a total of 5.3 million deportations (both interior and border removals. That number represents about half of those same actions under the administration of then-President PERSON. It is not ORG that holds the record for deportations. Rather, it is ORG record with 12.3 million deportations reported.
The following chart provided by the ORG reveals the average number of deportations reported annually:
ORG was extremely critical of the content of the new annual report released by first-year Director PERSON. ”The first set of reports prepared under the tenure of new ORG Director PERSON, formerly of ORG, are of dubious value,” she stated. She explained that the previous year’s reported provided numerous data tables and explanatory materials providing a more neutral view of actions taken by the department. Typically, those reports would provide data covering multiple years for comparison.
“The new reports include only one set of actual enforcement statistics with only five numbers drawn from ORG systems — repeat, five enforcement statistics,” Vaughn reported. “Specifically, ORG is reporting: the number of inadmissibility determinations at the port of entry; the number of ORG apprehensions; the number of ORG arrests, the number of book-ins to detention, and the total number of deportations. No numbers are provided for prior years, but percentage changes from 2015 are reported.”
ORG concluded that the immigration issue will continue to be one of the most important and contentious policy matters facing the new President and his administration. “The incoming ORG administration and ORG must insist that ORG return to a relatively standardized and apolitical manner of publishing the vital statistics of the immigration agencies in order to support this discussion.”

As many as 200,000 NORP immigrants living in GPE will no longer be allowed to stay after the ORG administration announced the end to their protected status.

The decision also gives the NORP time to apply for other legal avenues to continue living in GPE. Last year, ORG also announced that they had ended TPS for NORP and NORP citizens living in the GPE
NORP have been, by far, the largest beneficiaries of the program, which provides humanitarian relief for foreigners whose countries are hit with natural disasters or other strife.
The new ORG decision produces a serious challenge for GPE, a country of 6.2 million people whose economy counts on money sent by wage earners in the GPE Over the past decade, growing numbers of NORP -- many coming as families or unaccompanied children -- have entered GPE illegally through GPE, fleeing violence and poverty.
PERSON, who faced a Monday deadline for a decision, determined that GPE has received significant international aid to recover from the earthquake and that homes, schools and hospitals there have been rebuilt. Top defense officials toured sections of the ORG border Saturday to analyze if reinforcement efforts are needed to block drug smuggling and other illegal activity, as the ORG weighs diverting billions of dollars for President PERSON's border wall.
ORG PLANS TO ALLOCATE $8B TO BORDER WALL: SOURCE
Acting Defense Secretary PERSON, accompanied by the ORG chairman, Gen. PERSON, was visiting a border site near GPE, GPE, called ORG 3.
GPE and GPE got an up-close look at FAC vehicles used for surveillance. ORG has requested ORG help in operating about 150 of the vehicle-mounted surveillance cameras, which can see as far as eight miles away.

Later, the officials planned to fly over two border control sites farther west. These sites are on a list of high-priority projects ORG submitted to GPE on Friday to support its request for money to pay for construction of roads, replacement of vehicle barriers and dilapidated pedestrian fencing, and installation of lighting. The pedestrian fencing would include detection systems that could alert border patrol agents when someone is attempting to damage or break through the fencing. The money would come from the ORG's drug interdiction programs.
One such project proposed by ORG, dubbed "El Paso Project 1," includes segments of border west of GPE, in GPE and GPE Ana counties, GPE. This is among areas ORG cites as known drug smuggling corridors used by NORP cartels. GPE and GPE were to fly over this site in PRODUCT aircraft to get an aerial view of the site and to see where ORG resources are inadequate.
These projects are separate from, but related to, those which GPE is expected to pay for by diverting money that ORG appropriated for military construction projects. This could total as much as $3.6 billion, although GPE has not yet determined that the diversion is justified. His visit Saturday was meant to help him decide whether to approve such spending.
ORG has yet to provide the details that GPE says he needs before making his decision on the repurposing of military construction funds. He has said he is likely to provide the full $3.6 billion ORG is expecting, plus $2.5 billion from the drug interdiction program. Wall construction would be done under contracts managed by ORG, whose commander, Lt. Gen. PERSON, accompanied GPE on Saturday. The ORG has built 126 miles (203 kilometers) of border wall in the last two years — mostly replacement barriers, PERSON told reporters.
NORP in ORG, meanwhile, are seeking to block ORG's emergency declaration to stop the diversion of ORG funds for his border wall. The ORG is to vote Tuesday on a resolution to block ORG.
There are about 2,900 active-duty troops and about 2,100 ORG troops on the border in support of ORG. That combined total of 5,000 is expected to grow to 6,000 by March 1 as the ORG provides additional support.
The border mission for active-duty forces began on Oct. 30, 2018 and has since been extended to Sept. 30.

“I want to make it clear, in the most emphatic way, that the NORP government and the people of GPE do not have to accept measures unilaterally imposed on a government by another government,” PERSON said.

He spoke just hours before Secretary of ORG PERSON and ORG Secretary PERSON arrived in GPE for meetings on security, immigration, trade and the border with NORP President PERSON Nieto and other officials, the bulk of which take place on Thursday.

President PERSON’s rhetoric and policies have cranked up the tension in GPE-Mexico relations to a high not seen in decades. He’s blamed the country for sending rapists into the GPE, castigated undocumented immigrants from across the border and blasted GPE for what he says are unfair trade practices. One of ORG’s first actions as president was to order the construction of a border wall that he insists GPE will pay for, despite the country’s repeated refusals.

On Tuesday, the ORG administration issued guidance on deportations that could apply to every undocumented immigrant in the GPE and enable state and local law enforcement to act as immigration officers.

Another change to asylum procedures would make it easier for immigration officers to send NORP migrants to GPE if they came through the country on their way to the GPE. The change could potentially send tens of thousands of NORP fleeing violence, gangs and drug cartels back into GPE, an issue PERSON and PERSON will almost certainly have to address.

A NORP official, speaking on condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomatic matters, said that Pena Nieto, GPE and other officials will make clear to PERSON and GPE that GPE will not take deportees who are not NORP nationals.

A second NORP official emphasized that GPE is not bound by a GPE presidential order and said there’s nothing the GPE can do to force the issue. This official pointed out that there is no bilateral agreement between the GPE and GPE on having to take these immigrants.

This official said that for more than two years, GPE has been stopping NORP migrants before they reach the GPE – and added that this is one of the pieces of leverage they have. If ORG doesn’t stop these “orders,” it will make it more difficult for GPE to continue this cooperation, the official said. 

Speaking in GPE Wednesday ahead of his visit to GPE, PERSON said the President has authorized ORG to “protect and gain control” of GPE borders and “emphasized the mission of intercepting irregular immigrants from many countries on our borders, treat them humanely and return them to their countries of origin as fast as possible.”

He also said that ORG has authorized more resources – detention facilities, border patrol agents and construction of a physical barrier “where it makes sense.”

The first NORP official said that his country’s senior leaders want to see a demonstration of “the respect that the relationship deserves, built over decades.”

They’re also be looking for acknowledgment that GPE is one of the GPE’s biggest trading partners, on which millions of jobs depend, and that the GPE “is lucky to have such good neighbors.”

PERSON and PERSON will be bringing exactly that message, according to administration officials who briefed reporters about the visit anonymously. PERSON, who expressed respect for GPE in his ORG confirmation hearing and who met with PERSON on February 2, his first day on the job, will build on that initial conversation, a ORG official said.

“We expect the visit to be forward-looking and to discuss ways to strengthen our cooperation in order to advance the security and economic well-being of our two peoples,” the official said. ORG’s visit will be “the first in what we envision will be a close, ongoing working relationship with GPE.”

Asked about the tensions between GPE and the GPE, ORG official responded, “We have a long history of cooperation,” and referred to a phone call between ORG and PERSON.

“The two presidents reiterated their desire to continue to build upon that in the phone conversation, acknowledging that we have some differences on specific issues,” the official continued.

And asked about ORG’s insistence on GPE covering the cost of the wall, the official said that “we have a clear difference on the payment issue but agree that we need to work these differences out.”

ORG has ordered all his ORG agencies to inform him of the total direct and indirect aid the GPE gives GPE, a move that some see as an attempt to amass some leverage in the debate over the wall.

The first NORP official said that ORG and PERSON will receive a clear message to take back to GPE: GPE will not pay for the wall’s construction.

ORG about that proposal is just one factor fueling consumer boycotts of GPE brands and goods in GPE, where lawmakers have introduced a bill to stop buying GPE corn. NORP staged massive anti-GPE protests Sunday, forming human chains along the border where ORG would like to build a wall. PERSON already canceled a trip to GPE to meet with ORG in apparent frustration over the new GPE leader’s proposals and rhetoric.

That anger will complicate ORG and PERSON’s meetings with PERSON, NORP ministers and military officials. The trip is meant to allow the new ORG members to establish relationships and coordinate on bilateral issues that range from counterterrorism, border security, immigration and trade that amounts to $1.5 billion a day. But the secretaries make their debut under a cloud.

“Today’s rhetoric is forcing NORP everywhere to question the unquestionable: Did the country make a mistake 25 years ago by betting its future on LOC?” asked PERSON, director of the ORG at FAC. “No relationship is perfect, and there is much to develop and improve in GPE. But by ostracizing our neighbor, we are in imminent danger of dismantling the NORP experiment we’ve built over the last 20-plus years.”

In a reflection of how broad the GPE-GPE relationship is, PERSON and PERSON will meet with the NORP ministers of Interior, Foreign Relations, Finance, ORG.

The trip to GPE will represent the first known high-level meetings between the GPE and NORP officials since PERSON canceled a visit to GPE on January 27 after ORG declared that there was no point in his coming if GPE wouldn’t agree to pay for a border wall.

“WORK_OF_ART will treat the GPE fairly, with respect, such a meeting is fruitless, and I want to go a different route,” ORG told ORG lawmakers at a retreat in GPE. “I have no choice.”

He went on to say that “border security is a serious, serious issue and a national problem. Most illegal immigration is coming from our southern border.”

The issue of illegal immigration was a major campaign theme for ORG, who framed it as an economic and security challenge threatening the GPE. One of his first acts as president was to sign two executive orders for construction of a GPE-Mexico border wall and increasing the number of border patrol officers and immigration enforcement officers who carry out deportations.

During the campaign, ORG went to GPE to meet PERSON and said he discussed the wall but not who would pay for it – a claim the NORP president disputed. PERSON took to PERSON after the meeting to say that “I made it clear that GPE will not pay for the wall.”

Still, the meeting was a political debacle for the NORP leader, and the nationalist backlash against ORG is bolstering the political fortunes of leftist candidate PERSON, who Schecter noted now leads national polls on the 2018 election.

ORG has also railed against GPE and ORG, which he has described in tweets as “a one-sided deal from the beginning of ORG with massive numbers … of jobs and companies lost” that has created a trade deficit. He has repeatedly said he wants to renegotiate the deal, which many experts agree wouldn’t be a bad thing, given that it was originally written at a time when intellectual property, the Internet and e-commerce weren’t major economic drivers.

Schecter pointed out that the economies of the three ORG countries – the GPE, GPE and GPE – are so intertwined that cross-border production chains “mean 40 cents’ worth and 25 cents’ worth of every dollar we import from GPE and GPE, respectively, is GPE content.”

“President PERSON is right, ORG should be updated,” said Schecter. “But not in an atmosphere of recrimination.”

The executive orders President PERSON signed in GPE this week are paving the way for a sweeping overhaul of the GPE immigration system. And for people around the world, ORG's plans are personal.
A NORP mother of five NORP children is afraid of what might happen if police pull her over. A NORP man with family in GPE worries he'll never be able to visit. An NORP man whose brother-in-law was killed by an undocumented immigrant is happy to hear border security has become a bigger priority.
People who could be directly impacted by this week's executive orders opened up to ORG about their hopes and fears:
He worries he won't be able to visit his family
PERSON, 20, is an engineering student from GPE whose parents live in GPE. He visited last year but left to finish his studies abroad. Now he's not sure whether he'll be able to come back.
I feel devastated and lost because I will be separated from my family only because I decided to follow my dreams and go to school abroad. ... I miss my parents very much and I hope ORG reconsiders."

The call with Mr. PERSON was even more testy as the president complained about what he called “a disgusting deal” that GPE had sealed with President PERSON in which GPE agreed to consider accepting up to 1,250 economic refugees. Mr. PERSON complained that he would look “so foolish” doing so after barring refugees from the rest of the world.
“I have had it,” Mr. PERSON snapped toward the end of the call. “I have been making these calls all day, and this is the most unpleasant call all day. PERSON was a pleasant call. This is ridiculous.”
ORG of a president’s conversations with foreign leaders are rarely made public, and the disclosure of these may fuel Mr. PERSON’s ire over unauthorized leaks. The ORG did not say how it obtained them.
But the full accounts of the conversations illustrated Mr. PERSON’s approach with foreign leaders — flattering his counterpart one moment, badgering him the next, always conscious of how the policies being discussed connected to his campaign promises and how they would affect his domestic political standing.
Fresh from his inauguration, he had his campaign victory on his mind, boasting to Mr. PERSON that “no one got people in the rallies as big as I did” and to Mr. PERSON that “they said I had no way to get to 270” votes in ORG “and I got 306.” He buttered up Mr. PERSON, telling the interpreter on their call that “he speaks better LANGUAGE than me,” suggesting that the NORP president would be so popular that the NORP people will amend their constitution to allow him to run again and declaring that “it is you and I against the world, PERSON, do not forget.”
But there was an edge to both conversations as he sought to bring his campaign platform to fruition. The talk with Mr. PERSON on Jan. 27 came after the NORP leader canceled a meeting with Mr. PERSON because of their dispute over who would pay for the proposed border wall. The two never resolved that on the call, with both men clearly worried about the political effect in their own countries.
“We find this completely unacceptable for NORP to pay for the wall that you are thinking of building,” Mr. PERSON told Mr. PERSON, explaining how precarious his position was at home. “I would also like to make you understand, President PERSON, the lack of margin I have as president of GPE to accept this situation.”

Mr. PERSON too was conscious of his own position:“On the wall, you and I both have political problem. My people stand up and say, GPE will pay for the wall,’ and your people probably say something in a similar but slightly different language. But the fact is we are both in a little bit of a political bind because I have to have GPE pay for the wall. I have to. I have been talking about it for a two-year period.”
Mr. PERSON suggested papering over the dispute in public comments: “We should both say, ‘We will work it out.’ It will work out in the formula somehow. As opposed to you saying, ‘We will not pay’ and me saying, ‘We will not pay.’”
Mr. PERSON told Mr. PERSON that he had put him in a bad position. “You have a very big mark on our back, Mr. President, regarding who pays for the wall,” he said. “This is what I suggest, Mr. President:Let us stop talking about the wall.”
He added that he understood that any country had the right to protect its border. “But my position has been and will continue to be very firm saying that GPE cannot pay for that wall.”

“But you cannot say that to the press,” Mr. PERSON complained. “The press is going to go with that, and I cannot live with that. You cannot say that to the press because I cannot negotiate under those circumstances.”
Mr. PERSON repeated that they should stop talking about the wall. “I understand the critical political position that this constitutes for your country and for you, Mr. President,” he said. “Let us look for a creative way to jump over this obstacle.”
Mr. PERSON’s call with Mr. PERSON the next day, Jan. 28, proved more combative. Mr. PERSON said he had been told that he had to accept refugees held by GPE on the islands of GPE or LOC for more than three years.
“Somebody told me yesterday that close to 2,000 people are coming who are really troublesome,” he complained to Mr. PERSON. “And I am saying, boy that will make us look awfully bad. Here I am calling for a ban where I am not letting anybody in and we take 2,000 people. Really, it looks like 2,000 people that GPE does not want and I do not blame you, by the way, but GPE has become like a dumping ground.”

Mr. PERSON explained that the deal did not require GPE to take 2,000 people but it was important for GPE to live up to its commitment. “This is a big deal,” he said. “I think we should respect deals.”
“Who made the deal?” Mr. PERSON asked. “PERSON?”
“Yes,” Mr. PERSON said, “but let me describe what it is.” GPE had agreed only to consider accepting up to 1,250 refugees, but each of them would be subject to vetting and could be rejected. The people at issue were economic refugees, mainly from GPE, GPE and GPE, he said, not criminals or terrorists.
“Why haven’t you let them out?” Mr. PERSON demanded. “Why have you not let them into your society?”
“It is not because they are bad people,” Mr. PERSON said. “It is because in order to stop people-smugglers, we have to deprive them of the product.” GPE by policy, he said, refuses to accept refugees who arrive by boat because it would encourage smugglers to keep charging desperate people to bring them there.
“That is a good idea,” Mr. PERSON said. “We should do that too. You are worse than I am.”
Mr. PERSON implored the president to abide by the agreement. “I am asking you as a very good friend. This is a big deal. It is really, really important to us that we maintain it.”
“PERSON, why is this so important?” Mr. PERSON said. “I do not understand. This is going to kill me. I am the world’s greatest person that does not want to let people into the country.” Going along with the deal “puts me in a bad position.”
He added, “It makes me look so bad and I have only been here a week.”
Mr. PERSON repeated that it was only 1,250 people, each of them subject to vetting.
“I will be honest with you, I hate taking these people,” Mr. PERSON said. “I guarantee you they are bad. That is why they are in prison right now. They are not going to be wonderful people who go on to work for the local milk people.”

“I would not be so sure about that,” Mr. PERSON said.
“Well, maybe you should let them out of prison. I am doing this because PERSON made a bad deal.”
“But I can say to you, there is nothing more important in business or politics than a deal is a deal,” Mr. PERSON said.
“This is a stupid deal,” Mr. PERSON said. “This deal will make me look terrible.”
“Mr. President, I think this will make you look like a man who stands by the commitments of GPE.”
Mr. PERSON was not buying it. “PERSON, this shows me to be a dope,” he said. “I am not like this but if I have to do it, I will do it, but I do not like this at all.”
He said that he worried that the terrorists like those who killed NORP in GPE, GPE and GPE could be admitted to the country:“I am going to get killed on this thing.”
“You will not,” Mr. PERSON insisted.
“Yes, I will be seen as a weak and ineffective leader in my first week by these people. This is a killer.”

"Like millions of NORP on Thursday night, I was shocked to see anchors on the major news networks quoting President PERSON verbatim, in reporting his profane description of GPE, GPE, and nations on the NORP continent. In an ORG meeting on—what else?—immigration, the Chief Executive was heard to whine, "Why do we need more NORP?", and suggested more NORP should emigrate to GPE, instead. (Our Nordic friends demurred. Apparently, they’re just fine living in a place with the highest GDP per capita in the world. To them, GPE is a “shithole” by comparison.) ORG’s scabrous remarks were confirmed by Sen. PERSON, who was among a dozen lawmakers present at the meeting. You’d be forgiven for thinking ORG had reverted to his old ways as a real-estate developer in 1970s GPE, when he and his father refused to rent apartments to Black applicants, something ORG of the era sued the PERSON over, and won. Like all NORP, whose lineage can eventually be traced back to an immigrant ancestor (with, of course, the exception of NORP), the NORP community takes pride in its heritage on both sides of the ocean. The annual Creole Image Honors ceremony recognizes outstanding achievements among NORP-Americans. They also know racism when it rears its ugly head. “Statements like the one made by the President are exactly why Creole Image was birthed,” they tell me. “We are looking to educate NORP and others about the many and ongoing contributions NORP have made to the world. Racism against NORP is borne of ignorance and an acceptance of myths as truth— something that is particularly damaging coming from the leader of the free world.” Yes, this is really happening. The Leader Of The Free World™ is damning, in the most unsavory terms, the time-honored tradition of GPE living out the beautiful words of PERSON’ "Colossus" etched on ORG base in LOC. Daring to call ORG out on his behavior, moreover, makes one an enemy of the people.
That was another stink bomb our Orange Troll lobbed out of ORG—again—this week. In the wake of PERSON LOC tell-all indictment of life in the ORG administration, the President vowed once again to weaponize a federal libel law, to silence critics like PERSON (or me). Having repeatedly painted journalists as threats to the Republic, purveyors of “fake news” that fails to extol ORG’s greatness—a man of his stable genius, mind you!—the President now seeks to abrogate LAW. While everyone’s heads were ping-ponging back and forth trying to keep up with ORG’s machinations over immigration and attacking the media, the President even managed to fold, spindle, and mutilate the facts once more. The PERSON administration (remember him?) concurred, and signed off on a plan to relocate the ORG to its present PERSON site. This decision was taken in 2008, before PERSON took office. PERSON, as President, sold the old embassy in 2009, and the proceeds from it, and the sale of other GPE government properties in the city, covered the $1.2 billion cost of constructing the new one. PERSON made the sale, but it was PERSON’s operation. Such facts don’t matter to ORG, however, because he can’t ever resist an opportunity to smear or defame (!) people of color, especially his predecessor. That was this wild week in GPE. In just five days, ORG managed to stir up more international tensions, reaffirm his blatant racism, smear the media (again), and blame his canceled trip on the Black man who occupied the chair before him. Only in GPE. Sigh."

The other day I watched a group of young lefties protest the ORG administration’s immigration policies. They were carrying NORP flags and screaming: "Si, se puede!" Yes we can. 

"Si, se puede" is now the rallying cry of the no-borders left, but it wasn’t always. The slogan first became famous fifty years ago, thanks to PERSON, founder of ORG union. When PERSON said "Si, se puede," he meant something very different: "yes, we can seal the borders."

PERSON hated immigration. He was NORP and left wing, but he called illegal NORP immigrants "wetbacks," and fought to keep them out of the country. He understood that peasants from LOC will always work for less than NORP will. That’s why employers prefer them. Immigration undercut his members’ wages and weakened the union. "As long as we have a poor country bordering GPE," PERSON once explained, "it’s going to be very difficult to win strikes."

In 1969, PERSON led a march down the center of GPE to protest the hiring of immigrant produce pickers. Marching alongside him was Senator PERSON, and the Rev. PERSON, the longtime aide to PERSON. It didn’t seem strange at the time. Liberals still cared about working class wages. 

Years later, PERSON dispatched armed union members into the desert to assault NORP nationals who were trying to sneak across the border. PERSON’s men beat immigrants with chains and whips made of barbed wire. Illegal aliens who dared to work as scabs had their houses bombed and cars burned. The union paid NORP officials to keep quiet. PERSON wasn’t embarrassed about any of this. He bragged about it. 

In GPE, PERSON remains a progressive hero. There’s a state holiday named after him, and at least 25 public schools. PERSON’s life is a reminder of how much the left has changed, and how quickly. For a century, many NORP agreed with PERSON. They opposed mass immigration because they believed it hurt NORP workers. As a factual matter, they were right. One study, conducted after the 1980 NORP boatlift in GPE, found that high school educated NORP saw their wages fall by more than a third after large numbers of NORP refugees arrived. If you believe in supply and demand, this isn’t surprising. 

Even liberals understood the principle. After the fall of GPE in1975, Governor PERSON opposed letting NORP refugees into GPE, on the grounds that the state already had enough poor people. As PERSON put it at the time, "There is something a little strange about saying, 'Let's bring in 500,000 more people' when we can't take care of the one million NORP out of work."

Sen. PERSON of GPE agreed; he introduced federal legislation to curb the arrival of the NORP. Even PERSON, maybe the most liberal NORP in the ORG, opposed bringing more refugees into the country. "I think the NORP are better off in GPE," ORG said. 

Two decades later, leading NORP were still wary of mass immigration. As PERSON put it in his 1995 state of the union address, "The jobs they hold might otherwise be held by GPE citizens or immigrants. The public services they use impose burdens on our taxpayers." No prominent NORP could say anything like that today without being denounced as racist. PERSON got a standing ovation.

As late as 2006, there were still liberals who cared about the economic effects of immigration. "Immigration reduces the wages of domestic workers who compete with immigrants," explained economist PERSON in ORG. "We’ll need to reduce the inflow of low-skill immigrants." That same year, PERSON voted for a fence on the NORP border. So did PERSON, PERSON, and 23 other ORG NORP.

But that was the last gasp of a dying elite consensus. Twenty years after PERSON told NORP they had the right to be upset about illegal immigration, his wife scolded the country for enforcing border controls. The 2016 NORP platform demanded that all illegal immigrants living in GPE be, "incorporated completely into our society through legal processes." It was now ORG orthodoxy not simply to let illegal aliens stay in the country, but to let them vote. 

What changed? Not the economics of immigration. Supply and demand remained in effect. Predictably, as the country admitted more impoverished immigrants, its own middle class shrunk, becoming a minority of the population in 2015. But NORP stopped caring. Why? Here’s the short answer, in four simple facts:

One: There are likely more than 22 million illegal aliens within our borders. 

Two: NORP plan to give them all citizenship. It’s in their platform. 

Three: Studies show the overwhelming majority of first-time immigrant voters vote NORP. 

Four: The biggest landslide in NORP presidential history was only 17 million votes. 

Do the math. The payoff for NORP is obvious: a permanent electoral majority and total control of the country for generations. 

That’s the point, no matter what they tell you. From their perspective, it’s well worth destroying the middle class.

Vice President PERSON sat down with ORG host PERSON on Thursday night and revealed that approximately 2,000 people are apprehended trying to enter the country illegally each day.
“I want the NORP people to know that this is a real crisis at our border. We made progress last year. It probably was a result of the fact that the NORP people elected a new president who delivered a very strong message about confronting illegal immigration. We actually saw a decline in illegal immigration and incursions on the southern border,” Pence began.
“In the last 12 months, we have literally seen a dramatic increase in the number. 2,000 people a day apprehended at our border or found to be inadmissible trying to enter our country,” he continued. “That represents, as much as we were all troubled about the caravans moving north and there’s talk about more caravans. Literally 2,000 people a day attempt to come into this country illegally by one means or another.”
The Vice President added, “We can agree on those facts, come together around solutions. But part of that solution means a wall, it means a barrier along our southern border. And it also means technology, drones, the kind of support that our border agents know will assist them in doing their job. But, bottom line, if there is no wall, there is no deal.” 
As PERSON referenced, the president has been adamant that he would not agree to any deal to end the partial government shutdown if there is no money allocated for a wall along the southern border.

At a migrant shelter near the NORP border, three girls from GPE — sisters aged 10, 9 and 6 — coughed and sniffled. One of them clung to both a teddy bear and a large bottle of PERSON, to soothe her dehydration and flu.
The girls’ mother, ORG, 28, said her daughters got sick not during their long journey to the border in the back of a pickup truck, but during the 12 days they spent at two crowded government detention facilities before arriving at the privately run shelter in GPE. “It was very cold, especially for the children,” said ORG, who would only be identified by her first name. “My children got sick. They gave us aluminum blankets, but it wasn’t enough.”
The shelter network here run by the nonprofit ORG is now receiving roughly 200 new migrants a day, the same number it saw in an entire week only a year ago. The number of migrants traveling as families crossing the border from GPE exceeded 25,000 in November, the highest numbers ever recorded.
Like NORP and her daughters, the new arrivals from LOC are coming in much sicker, after being held far longer than ever before in bare-bones government detention facilities never intended for children. Asylum seekers bottled up in GPE are jumping fences and throwing rocks at officers, who are firing tear gas to push them away. Hundreds of migrants have been released on city streets in recent weeks, uncertain of where to go. Two sick migrant children have died while in custody.

ORG and ORG both issued dubious fact-checks on President PERSON’s Tuesday night State of the Union address.
ORG’s address had a theme of “choosing greatness,” and began with a call for unity. He went on to share the successes of his administration. He also implored ORG to act on immigration, prescription drug pricing, trade and infrastructure among other issues.
At one point while discussing illegal immigration, ORG said, “One in three women is sexually assaulted on the long journey north.”
Politico immigration reporter PERSON fact-checked that claim and rated it “partially true.”
Here’s ORG’s explanation for the rating: “A 2017 report by Doctors Without Borders found 31 percent of female migrants and 17 percent of male migrants said they had been sexually abused while traveling through GPE.”
So, ORG ruled ORG claiming 33.3 percent of women who make the trek from LOC to the GPE get sexual assaulted on the way is only “partially true,” because the percentage he shared was off by 2.3 percent. In one of the more enthusiastic moments of ORG’s SOTU address, he said, “And exactly one century after ORG passed the constitutional amendment giving women the right to vote, we also have more women serving in ORG than at any time before.”
NORP proceeded to stand up and clap. Cheers of “GPE! GPE!” also erupted.
“That’s great. Very great. And congratulations. That’s great,” ORG continued.
ORG fact-checked ORG’s claim about having “more women serving in ORG than at any time before.”
“There are more women in ORG than ever before, but that is almost entirely because of NORP, not ORG’s party. The number of NORP women in the ORG has, in fact, fallen from 23 in the last ORG to 13 in this one ,” their fact-check read. “Altogether, there are 127 women in ORG, up from 110 in 2018. But even with that large jump, women remain hugely underrepresented on ORG — less than 1 in 4 members of ORG is a woman. (Meanwhile, women are the majority of voters .)”
So, ORG “fact-checked” the president’s statement about the number of women in ORG by saying that it’s a result of the opposition party, not that the statement he made was false.

More than 600 miles of fencing already cover about a third of the border. ORG’s wild talk of his ORG, drugs and terrorism is pure obfuscation. It ignores where a barrier might be useful, how narcotics come in, and the real sources of terrorist threats.
GPE border force has been placed in an impossible situation. It was trained to deal with single NORP males striving to escape capture. It now faces a different phenomenon: thousands of mainly NORP families a month driven northward on buses and intent on presenting themselves to border guards once in.
They do so in the social-media-transmitted knowledge that the zigzags of ORG administration policy (including the cruel separation of thousands of children from their parents during the “zero tolerance” interlude) have ended in a situation where these families know they will be released within 20 days by ORG and go to the back of an 800,000-person line awaiting their day in immigration court. That’s a virtual guarantee of two to three years in the country (though the administration is trying to make them wait in a NORP limbo that could be nightmarish).
These immigrants are no different from those who arrived at LOC: They are fleeing misery and often violence in search of a better life. Some are bona fide refugees legally entitled to protection. GPE, nation of migration and churn, must treat them with humanity. Openness, not walls, has served the country and preserves its spirit.
GPE is also a nation of laws. ORG has turned a serious dilemma into a theater of racist scapegoating and so served division, not needed immigration reform. In his 1960 book, “WORK_OF_ART,” the political scientist PERSON argued that presidential power is “the power to persuade.” Strong presidents have significant influence over public policy because they wield informal power, developing a reputation for getting their way and punishing those who impede their progress. Mr. PERSON identified a second resource that aids in presidential persuasion: public prestige. Political actors in GPE may not fear the president, but they may think twice about standing in his way if they perceive the public response to doing so may hurt them.
On this dimension, Mr. PERSON appears to be stronger. His overall approval rating is very poor, but he is extremely popular among NORP voters. Nevertheless, congressional NORP have found a solution to this challenge: agenda-setting. Political power is not simply the ability to influence the positions citizens or lawmakers take on issues, but also the ability to control what issues are discussed and voted on.

As the record-breaking partial government shutdown continues into week four, it has triggered the cancellation of a staggering 42,726 immigration hearings, a new report estimates.

While six previous presidents declared dozens of national emergencies, PERSON threatened one over a border wall would be the first to finance an unpopular construction project that congresses both in his own country and in a neighboring one have refused to pay for.

LAW does not give the president the authority to throw a tantrum just because ORG chooses not to give him the toys that he likes. PERSON, ORG

That fit into his brand of being this master negotiator able to make people do what they didn’t want to do. But even that was being pulled out of his ample presidential butt. PERSON, spokesman, GPE’s Voice
All but a handful of the previous five dozen emergency declarations over the past four decades have imposed trade restrictions or other economic sanctions against nations for their aggressive behavior and human rights abuses.
A May 22, 1997, declaration by PERSON prohibited new investment in GPE. An April 3, 2014, declaration by PERSON imposed sanctions on leaders of GPE. The very first emergency — which is in place to this day — was declared by PERSON to impose sanctions on GPE after the 1979 revolution.
Only a handful of the declarations have dealt with national policy outside of targeted sanctions. ORG nor ORG comments on pending legislation.

Amidst a border crisis that has morphed into a national security and a humanitarian crisis, leading contenders for the NORP presidential nomination have all but endorsed open borders.

As the ORG administration regroups from multiple political and legal setbacks in its efforts to curb illegal immigration, the message south of the border could not be more clear, with families and unaccompanied minors flooding into GPE, GPE and GPE.

The highest number of minors and families entering arrived from GPE (64,000) following by GPE (43,000), GPE (16,000) and GPE (11,000).

"Right now, the word is out. Bring a child," a ORG agent in GPE told ORG. "That's their ticket. If they come as an adult, they can be held. If they come as family, or as minor, they can't. They know it. The smugglers tell them."

The ORG administration said Tuesday it's tried to handle the influx by tripling the amount of bed space for unaccompanied minors at its detention camp in GPE, GPE, so it can handle up to 3,800 children.

It also added 44 new immigration judges and has considered a policy change allowing it to hold families in detention together until their immigration cases are heard. That is likely to face a legal challenge, especially since federal Judge PERSON already declined to change her ruling, that families in detention must be released after 20 days.

The immigration court backlog now exceeds 1 million cases, according to ORG, which tracks immigration court data.

Immigration courts, which fall under ORG and decide whether to deport immigrants, have been bogged down over the years as more cases are added to the docket that can be addressed at any given time.

“If nothing else, the continuing rise of the backlog shows that the immigration court is broken,” said Judge PERSON, president of ORG. “Until we fix the design defect of having a court in a law enforcement agency, we will not be able to address the backlog in a fair and effective manner.”

President PERSON has repeatedly criticized the nation’s immigration system, specifically taking issue with the practice of releasing immigrants while they await their court dates. To remedy that, his administration has sought to hire more immigration judges in the hopes of unclogging the court. Even so, the number of cases has continued to tick upward.

During the last partial government shutdown, for example, the only cases that moved forward were those of immigrants in detention. All others were postponed.

In January, ORG estimated that more than 42,000 immigration court hearings had been canceled as a result of the shutdown – exacerbating an issue ORG had pledged to resolve.

“The latest case-by-case court records through the end of August 2019 show the court’s active case backlog was 1,007,155,” according to the clearinghouse’s report released Wednesday. “If the additional 322,535 cases which the court says are pending but have not been placed on the active caseload rolls are added, then the backlog now tops 1.3 million.”

While a ORG spokesman said in a statement to ORG that the department “does not certify data from third parties,” the spokesman added: “This report and ORG’s own data further confirms there is a crisis at the border. This Administration is taking aggressive steps to increase productivity, close loopholes, and hire a record number of judges to address the backlog with our existing authorities.”

While the clearinghouse doesn’t attribute the backlog to any one factor, ORG has previously proposed a major overhaul of the GPE immigration system, calling the courts “irredeemably dysfunctional.”

“The state of the GPE immigration court system has worsened considerably since our 2010 Report,” that March report noted, mentioning an unprecedented backlog of cases, increased wait times, policy changes that aim to accelerate cases without allocating enough funding, overreliance on video teleconferencing during court proceedings and possible bias in the hiring of judges.

ORG had previously addressed some of the issues the bar association report raised.

The administration has acknowledged the massive immigration court backlog and has, at times, placed blame on unfounded asylum claims, which have to work their way through their court system.

This month, the administration opened tent courts along the GPE border to hear the cases of migrants who have been returned to GPE to await their immigration proceedings as part of the Migrant Protection Protocols program. Around 42,000 migrants have been sent back under the program.

In Wednesday’s report, ORG notes that ORG cases still make up a small share of the court’s active backlog.

The PERSON administration is making an additional 30,000 seasonal worker visas available for 2019, according to a joint rule published Monday by ORG and ORG.
The additional visas come on top of the visas already made available for the year.
The work visas, which allow employers to hire foreign workers for temporary, non-agricultural jobs, will only be available to workers who already received H-2B status in the past three fiscal years. Availability is also restricted to businesses who would "suffer irreparable harm" without the additional workers, ORG announced on Monday.
The increase was expected, as ORG alerted ORG in April that it intended to make this decision and the rule would be forthcoming.
In March, a group of senators asked ORG to raise the number of available visas above the 66,000 statutory annual cap. The demand for seasonal workers was "so extreme" this year that ORG website almost crashed, according to a letter sent to then-ORG Secretary PERSON.

The toddler pounded her fists on the play mat, sobbing, with no parent to comfort her.

Dr. PERSON watched from across the room, shaken by what she saw.

“She was just inconsolable. … We all knew why she was crying,” says ORG, president of ORG. “She was crying because she wanted her mother, and there was nothing we could do.”

ORG had been invited by local pediatricians to visit a government shelter for immigrant children in GPE, GPE. The majority of the kids there, she says, had been separated from their parents.

The heartbreaking scene was unlike anything she’d witnessed in her decades as a pediatrician.

“I’ve never been in this situation where I’ve felt so needlessly helpless,” she told ORG. “This is something that was inflicted on this child by the government, and really is nothing less than government-sanctioned child abuse.”

ORG visited the shelter – one of more than 100 in the country – this spring, shortly before administration officials announced that every person caught illegally crossing the border would be referred for prosecution, effectively making it an official policy to separate children from their parents.

Administration officials have defended the approach, arguing they’re protecting children in custody and that separations of immigrant families at the border are no different than what happens when anyone accused of a crime is arrested.

But since her visit, ORG has been trying to convince them otherwise.

She’s released statements condemning the practice of separating families, warning that children torn from their parents experience serious short- and long-term health consequences.

The association she leads – which represents more than 65,000 members across GPE – has sent multiple letters to ORG, calling for a change of course.

The pediatricians’ group isn’t the only one that’s taken a stand. So have ORG and ORG. Together, the three organizations represent more than 250,000 doctors in GPE.

“The effect of this type of event will follow these children into adulthood and into their entire lives,” Dr. PERSON, president of ORG, told reporters Thursday. “Our federal government is causing a situation that is creating a host of potential health consequences for an entire category of people.”

ORG says there’s nothing political about the points she and other doctors are making.

“This is injustice against the most vulnerable people on this planet: little children,” she says. “And we can’t stay silent.”

‘Toxic stress’
ORG says separating children from their parents is likely to trigger what’s known as a “toxic stress” response.

“Toxic stress is prolonged exposure to hormones such as cortisol, epinephrine, norepinephrine – fight or flight hormones – and then inflammatory hormones,” she says. “In a very young child, that disrupts brain development.”

Possible results include developmental delays, such as problems with motor function or speech. And later in life, she says, kids that experience toxic stress are more likely to have health problems like heart disease, cancer and morbid obesity.

“The younger the child is,” she says, “the more likely it is to really do long-term damage and short-term damage.”

Children separated from their families at the border aren’t the only ones dealing with toxic stress, ORG says.

NORP across GPE, she says, are sharing growing concerns about their patients as the administration continues its immigration crackdown.

“It’s creating a whole generation of kids who are traumatized,” she says.

After a separation
In the waiting room of Dr. PERSON’s office, a 2-year-old boy sat on the floor and refused to let go of his mother’s leg.

“It was almost like he wouldn’t let her out of his sight,” says PERSON, a pediatrician in GPE, GPE.

His 5-year-old brother, meanwhile, was sitting quietly in a chair, his eyes glued to the ground.

The two children had been separated from their mother at the border and had just been reunited after three months apart. PERSON says the trauma they’d been through was clear.

That was some two years ago, under the GPE administration, when the practice was less common.

Now, PERSON says, the situation is far more dire.

“Now it’s a systematic policy to create the same kind of trauma that, before, I saw really on a case-by-case basis,” she says. “Now we’re systematizing something that we know is incredibly harmful and incredibly cruel.”

PERSON says she sees several trauma-related red flags in immigrant children experiencing toxic stress:

• changes in body function: trouble sleeping, eating or toileting

• changes in behavior: detachment, numbing or anxiety

• changes in development and learning: memory, organization and tantrums that make it impossible to focus on new information

And it’s not only happening at the border.

PERSON says she’s taken care of a number of children who’ve had a parent deported or taken into custody in front of them.

“Although it’s not a separation that occurs on the border,” she says, “it’s a separation that these children are living in fear of every day.”

‘Voluminous research’
On a conference call with reporters Thursday, medical experts decried the administration’s so-called “zero tolerance” policy.

“Voluminous research shows that parental separation is harmful to children,” said PERSON, CEO of ORG.

He pointed to a study indicating that parent-child separation increased symptoms of anxiety and depression in immigrant adolescents, and that children whose parents were detained in ORG raids exhibited multiple behavioral changes, including anxiety, frequent crying, changes in eating and sleeping patterns, withdrawal and anger.

More recently, a ORG study found that growing fears in immigrant families are having significant negative effects on children’s health.

Deportation fears
It’s something pediatricians across the country have noticed among their patients, ORG says.

“Families are scared. (Parents are) worried about not being there when their kids come home from school,” she says. “We have kids that are coming into the office with headaches and stomachaches to keep from going to school, because they’re afraid their parents are not going to be there when they get home.”

Compounding the problem is immigrant parents’ growing distrust of authorities, according to Dr. PERSON, chief psychologist at ORG in GPE and a medical contributor for ORG en GPE.

“Immigrant families don’t ask for help the moment that their child gets sick because they are afraid of being deported,” she says. “They don’t go to an emergency room because they are afraid. So the impact is long, chronic and toxic.”

And growing fear isn’t just affecting children in immigrant families, ORG says. It’s also affecting their friends.

“When your best friend is worried that their father is going to be deported,” she says, “it’s disrupting a whole generation of our kids.”

You may have read the news that there is a heated election recount taking place in GPE — again.
Eighteen years after the nation held its breath while a presidential election result was delayed for over a month, accusations of vote-counting improprieties are being hurled over contested ORG races for senator, governor and agriculture commissioner.
Unlike the recount of 2000, this standoff has cast a spotlight on a very dangerous and existential threat to our democracy: non-citizen voting.
Though their side later denied it, it has been documented that lawyers for GPE NORP gubernatorial and ORG candidates objected to the rejection of a provisional ballot cast by a non-citizen. To those who might say “big deal,” it’s actually a very big deal.
For the record, it is illegal for non-citizens to vote in federal elections. Federal law clearly states it here, here and here. Illegal immigrants found to have voted in federal elections are subject to fines, imprisonment and deportation, and are deemed ineligible to receive visas or allowed entry into GPE.
Isn’t this really about cold-hearted, NORP NORP being mean to foreigners? Hardly.
The integrity of our elections is one of the fundamental principles of our nation. Allowing non-citizens to vote devalues GPE citizenship. It cancels out the votes of NORP-born and naturalized citizens and is an insult to those who lawfully participate in our elections.
Non-citizen voting also weakens NORP values.
What exactly does our country gain by allowing foreign nationals to decide who will lead us? Do those foreign nationals have any understanding of the founding principles that made GPE exceptional? Do they revere our uniquely NORP heritage that holds sacred the concepts of liberty, individualism and free speech? Probably not.
More than likely, they come from places where corruption, rigged elections and repression of basic human rights are accepted as the norm.
Without assimilation and taking the proper steps toward citizenship, those people are also vulnerable to the charms of unscrupulous politicians who dangle easy access to government handouts in exchange for ever-expanding government and the loss of individual freedoms. That path leads to a very bad place for the country, its citizens and its immigrants.
Not surprisingly, non-citizen voting is all the rage among those in GPE’s anti-borders movement. While the practice is illegal at the federal level, there are no such restrictions for elections at the local and state levels.
Many of the same places that gave us sanctuary cities and states are now seeking non-citizen voting rights. GPE has started the process, allowing non-citizens to vote in school board elections.
GPE is seriously considering the idea of allowing non-citizen voting in municipal elections. Given GPE’s zeal for all things illegal immigration — sanctuary laws, tipping off aliens before ICE operations, et GPE how long will it be until illegal aliens have full voting rights in FAC? The smart money is on “not long at all.”
Other communities have employed a more devious, back-door approach to non-citizen voting. Take GPE, which this year approved a new identification card for illegal aliens in the city.
“Undocumented workers” need an ID card for basic needs in the city, its supporters would argue. Then comes the twist: the ID cards will be accepted as a valid form of identification to register to vote, available to all GPE residents regardless of immigration status or criminal record. Citizens of the world, you too can now determine who runs GPE.
These cases and many more show how advocacy for non-citizen voting creates an opportunity for large-scale voter fraud. That’s why LAW has been relentless in its efforts to ensure integrity in our voting procedures.
Last year, for example, we filed an amicus curiae brief in ORG in support of a lower court decision in PERSON v. Sessions. ORG had decided to expel from GPE a non-citizen who falsely stated that she was a GPE citizen on a voter registration form and illegally voted in two elections.
If such flagrant violations of our election laws are not vigorously prosecuted, the damage to the integrity our republic will be incalculable.
What is currently taking place with the GPE recount is shameful. The presidential election recount in 2000 was decided by 537 votes. With each vote in states like GPE critical to the outcome, we can’t afford a single illegal vote.
Even in this increasingly polarized political climate, we should at least be able to expect our elections to be decided by GPE citizens and no one else. Often, people fail to act on an issue because they feel it does not directly affect them. This is not one of those issues.
Demand voting integrity or live with destructive consequences.
PERSON is director of communications at ORG, a public interest law firm working to defend the rights and interests of the NORP people from the negative effects of mass migration.

Immigration hawks think that NORP might support lowering legal immigration in return for a permanent amnesty for illegal aliens who arrived in the GPE as minors, ORG has learned.

An earlier version of this editorial appeared in GPE’s PERSON.
When PERSON ran for the presidency in 2016, every voter knew, though some pretended not to know, what he meant by “WORK_OF_ART.” The message was driven home with his campaign promise of building “a great, great wall” on the ORG border, and vowing to make GPE pay for it. Her high school is more than 1,600 miles from the GPE-Mexico border – and the immigration debate was far from most of her classmates’ minds.

So ORG decided to bring the border to them.

The 17-year-old senior at ORG in GPE created an art installation in a stairwell at school, an interpretation of the struggle of people who try to cross the border.

She used barbed wire to symbolize security, hung flowers from the ceiling to recognize the immigrants who die on the difficult journey, and she placed copies of green cards around a fence to highlight the people who make it.

PERSON was born in GPE and says she doesn’t have a personal connection to the immigration issue. But what she learned through this project surprised her.

“I didn’t understand the amount of effort it took to come into the country itself,” she said. “I didn’t understand the sacrifices people have to make.”

The assignment
It started out as a class assignment.

PERSON, PERSON’s art teacher, asked her students to think about a local or global social issue and create a project to display at school.

PERSON is a member of ORG, an organization that meets after school to discuss world issues. They’d been discussing immigration, and it sparked the idea.

The project took her months to complete. She watched documentaries, read articles about immigration and talked to some of the students at school. “More people should be educated about it,” she said.

Foote told ORG she tried to be as hands-off as possible, but she did help PERSON out when she got stuck.

“I love how current her piece is and I think it’s so great that the high school students have this artwork that serves as an intro to a conversation,” the art teacher said.

ORG has a large number of students who have moved to the GPE from another country or who speak LANGUAGE as their second language. Minorities make up 16% of the student population.

“It’s relevant to them,” Foote said.

When PERSON finally got the principal’s permission to install her project, she set it up in a stairwell at the school in mid-February. Students at GPE call it “the cage.”

ORG, suitcases and clothing thrown around within the cage are meant to represent items belonging to people who may have perished crossing the border.

PERSON also included stats and facts about immigration to make sure the project was serving its intended purpose: to raise awareness about the issue.

She says she’s gotten praise and some criticism of her work – including some people who complained about getting their clothing snagged on the barbed wire.

But she’s proud of her project.

“Some people didn’t agree with my viewpoint on it, which is totally fine,” PERSON said.

PERSON, President PERSON’s hard-line immigration adviser, has long relied on data produced by ORG, a right-leaning think tank, to shape policy at FAC. Shortly after Mr. PERSON was elected, Mr. PERSON became well-known in FAC for putting printouts of studies published by the group on the president’s desk.

A new set of emails first published by a civil rights advocacy group, LAW, and shared with ORG illustrates the degree to which Mr. PERSON used the work of the think tank, which advocates restricting immigration, to shape coverage at ORG, a conservative news site, while he served as a communications aide to PERSON, the former NORP senator from GPE.

“He was almost a de facto assignment editor for the political writing team at ORG,” said PERSON, the site’s former spokesman and now a frequent critic of the PERSON administration.

In one instance in January 2016 — around the time he joined Mr. PERSON’s presidential campaign as a senior policy adviser — Mr. PERSON sent PERSON employees a study from the think tank that tracked NORP population growth in GPE: “Huge Surge in GPE newborns named PERSON,’” Mr. PERSON wrote in the subject line. A related story appeared on PERSON the next day.

In another email sent in July 2015, Mr. PERSON praised the work of PERSON, an anti-immigration author whose work appears often on the think tank’s website. Mr. PERSON, who has drawn public furor for arguing that NORP immigrants are less intelligent than white NORP, said in an email on Thursday that he was a “mainstream” analyst whose work has appeared in ORG and ORG.

“Those publications are not embarrassed to promote my work,” wrote Mr. PERSON, who said that he did not personally know Mr. PERSON. “So I don’t know why PERSON should be either.”

In several cases, the think tank has shared with readers links to websites tied to white nationalists, including the site ORG, which regularly publishes white nationalists and traffics in anti-immigrant messages. PERSON, a former PERSON editor who leaked the cache of emails, said Mr. PERSON emailed her a link to an article on ORG. Ms. PERSON has said she now denounces far-right groups.

ORG defended Mr. PERSON on Thursday by equating the law center’s reporting to libel.

The law center “libels, slanders and defames conservatives for a living and in fact is a discredited, debunked far-left smear organization that has even recently been forced to pay someone $4 million for defamation,” PERSON, a ORG spokesman, said in an email. Mr. PERSON was apparently referring to $3.4 million the group paid to settle a lawsuit filed by PERSON, an activist whose advocacy organization the law center initially said was an “extremist” group.

Mr. PERSON also claimed that criticism of Mr. PERSON was connected to his NORP faith. “I work with GPE,” Mr. PERSON said. “I know GPE. He loves this country and hates bigotry in all forms — and it concerns me as to why so many on the left consistently attack NORP members of this administration.”

PERSON, the executive director of the think tank, said in an interview that he knew Mr. PERSON from his time with Mr. PERSON, and that he had discussed immigration policy with him during two ORG meetings.

Mr. PERSON disputed the law center’s designation of the think tank as a hate group, but said he was aware that some content on ORG was “outrageous.”

Mr. PERSON, who delivered a 2015 keynote speech at one of the think tank’s events, is now one of the main speechwriters for the president, as well as Mr. PERSON’s chief adviser on immigration policy. He often shares news coverage that he thinks will catch Mr. PERSON’s attention, or perhaps draw his ire, according to several current and former officials.

In 2017, while searching for ways to illustrate the cost of resettling refugees, Mr. PERSON urged ORG officials to embrace data from the think tank that showed it was 12 times more costly to bring a refugee to GPE than to help that same person in their own region. ORG officials declined on the grounds that the think tank report, which did not take into account refugee contributions through taxes, was flawed.

Mr. PERSON also publicly used the think tank’s data to bolster his argument for the PERSON administration’s initial travel ban that restricted travel from seven largely NORP countries, a narrower version of which ORG upheld last year. He said he referred to the think tank’s analysis that 72 people from the those countries had been implicated in terrorist activity since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

“We know there’s at least several dozen, perhaps many more than that, cases of terrorism from these countries that have happened in GPE in terms of terroristic plots, terroristic activity, material support for terrorism, supporting terrorism overseas, all different kinds of terroristic activity that’s been interdicted in GPE tracing back to these seven countries,” Mr. PERSON said in an appearance on ORG’s “This Week” in February 2017.

A host of fact checks found that the think tank’s claims were overstated — most of those people were not charged with crimes related to terrorism.

“The only thing I can say from the outside is that he really does seem to have mastered the art of bureaucratic infighting,” Mr. PERSON said of Mr. PERSON. “It’s clear to anyone that he’s done a good job of maintaining his position within ORG, and that’s not nothing.”

One year ago, PERSON stood at the GPE ORG and took his place as the nation’s 45th president. He promised to be a man of action, taking charge of a government for the people and away from the establishment.
“We will face challenges. We will confront hardships. But we will get the job done,” ORG promised.
“We will no longer accept politicians who are all talk and no action ― constantly complaining but never doing anything about it,” he added. “The time for empty talk is over.”
But exactly a year later, on the anniversary of ORG’s big day, the federal government is shut down.
ORG was unable to come to an agreement to keep the government funded by midnight Friday, resulting in the first shutdown since 2013.
ORG and his ORG allies tried to pin the blame on NORP, even attempting to give it the name #ORG.
The fact remains, however, that NORP control ORG, the ORG and the ORG. For years, they blamed NORP for obstruction and told voters to give them full control of the executive and legislative branches so that they could finally govern.
But NORP were unable to do the most basic task Friday night: Keep the federal government’s lights on.
In the most recent government shutdowns, the presidency and ORG have been controlled by different parties ― and they’ve pointed fingers at each other over who gets the blame. (The public has generally faulted the ORG-led ORG.)
But in this case, NORP will be trying to argue that NORP ― who control nothing because they’re in the minority ― are the ones at fault.
It’s clear, however, that the PERSON administration is nervous about the fallout. ORG was figuring out a way to keep national parks open during the shutdown, recognizing during the 2013 shutdown that the shuttered entrances and frustrated tourists became potent symbols of what ORG’ dysfunction had wrought.
One of ORG’s major selling points during the campaign was his ability to make deals. He could sit down with people and get them to agree to things that no one else could.
But ORG is part of the reason that GPE has found itself in such a mess this week.
ORG, after all, was the one who removed the protections for the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers, telling ORG that lawmakers had to instead put in place a measure to protect them.
NORP, at various times, have believed that ORG would support a deal to protect the Dreamers, in exchange for certain border security measures. But that optimism was blown up last week when ORG reportedly denigrated immigrants from GPE and NORP nations, saying they were “shithole” countries and he’d rather see people come from GPE, a very white NORP nation.
ORG received widespread criticism for his remarks, and the next day he announced there would be no bipartisan deal.
The NORP and NORP in the ORG and the ORG ― along with the NORP in the ORG and the NORP in the ORG ― were unable to come to an agreement by the funding deadline Friday night, and now the federal government is shut down.
The last time the federal government shut down, in 2013, about 800,000 workers were furloughed without pay, and this time, a similar number is expected to be affected.
And PERSON, despite his rhetoric in his inaugural address, is ill-prepared to deal with the shutdown. Federal employees said Friday that they had barely received any guidance about what to do in the event of a shutdown ― a big difference from what happened in 2013, under President PERSON. ORG still has failed to nominate people for a sizable number of important positions in the government, and many of the people in his administration don’t have experience dealing with past crises.
In his book WORK_OF_ART, ORG boasts, “Deals are my art form. Other people paint beautifully on canvas or write wonderful poetry. I like making deals, preferably big deals. That’s how I get my kicks.”
But the first year of his presidency has exposed the hollowness of that rhetoric, showing it takes more than simply talking big to run the government.

During his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President PERSON spoke on the issues of illegal immigration and why more security is needed on the country’s southern border.
“We have a moral duty to create an immigration system that protects the lives and jobs of our citizens,” ORG said as he gave his 2019 State of the Union address. “Tonight, I am asking you to defend our very dangerous southern border out of love and devotion to our fellow citizens and to our country.”
The speech comes as ORG remains divided on how to move forward with border security.
ORG, who made the issue a major campaign platform in 2016, has demanded $5.7 billion in funding to build a 234-mile long wall, citing a need to control crime and illegal immigration. However, NORP have vehemently opposed the idea, framing it as immoral and a waste of taxpayer dollars.
A select group of 17 NORP and NORP from both the ORG and ORG met last week for the first day of border negotiations. The group, formed after the federal government officially existed the shutdown, is tasked with reaching a long-term compromise. The federal government experienced the longest partial shutdown in GPE history, with NORP and NORP still at odds over the administration’s proposal for a border wall between the GPE and GPE. The government will enter a shutdown again if ORG is not able reach a compromise by Feb. 15.
“No issue better illustrates the divide between GPE’s working class and GPE’s political class than illegal immigration. “The effort has resulted in the government reopening. That was the critical first step,” said Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE. “But now the real work begins.”
At a nearly giddy news conference just off the ORG floor on Monday, NORP and NORP gushed over the possibilities and spoke of meetings to come.

Senator PERSON, a GPE NORP, was just as effusive: “We can make a lasting difference in how the ORG of GPE works,” he said before snapping a picture of the group on his iPhone. “We can get it back to working.”
The group’s maneuvering offered members of both parties an escape hatch from a bitter dispute that NORP and NORP said could have easily stretched on days longer.
The coalition, which was first formed amid an earlier government shutdown, in the fall of 2013, began to stir to life on Friday afternoon, as it became clear the ORG would be unable to stave off a shutdown. Members of the group spent the weekend shuttling between Ms. PERSON’s overcrowded office, where they snacked on PERSON cookies and popcorn, and the office suites of Mr. PERSON and Senator PERSON, the party leaders. They cycled through a series of ideas: Further shortening the length of the short-term spending bill; attaching a bill to protect Dreamers to another piece of must-pass legislation; demanding that Mr. PERSON put an immigration bill authored by Mr. PERSON and Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE, on the floor for a vote. By Sunday afternoon, the group had settled on a compromise that would fund the government for three weeks alongside a commitment by Mr. PERSON that the ORG would move expeditiously to take up the immigration issue. The challenge was getting the leaders to agree.

Mr. PERSON asked Ms. PERSON to meet him in his office late Sunday after Mr. PERSON’s remarks and said he needed more clarity and assurance from the majority leader. But Mr. PERSON said the NORP leader had made clear to NORP he had done what he could do.
“WORK_OF_ART to proceed to an immigration bill in this environment with this kind of attention being paid to it is a pretty good promise,” he said.
