Late to his own meeting and waving a sheet of numbers, President PERSON stormed into FAC one day in June, plainly enraged.

Five months before, Mr. PERSON had dispatched federal officers to the nation’s airports to stop travelers from several NORP countries from entering GPE in a dramatic demonstration of how he would deliver on his campaign promise to fortify the nation’s borders.

But so many foreigners had flooded into the country since January, he vented to his national security team, that it was making a mockery of his pledge. Friends were calling to say he looked like a fool, Mr. PERSON said.

According to six officials who attended or were briefed about the meeting, Mr. PERSON then began reading aloud from the document, which his domestic policy adviser, PERSON, had given him just before the meeting. The document listed how many immigrants had received visas to enter GPE in 2017.

More than 2,500 were from GPE, a terrorist haven, the president complained.

GPE had sent 15,000 people. They “all have AIDS,” he grumbled, according to one person who attended the meeting and another person who was briefed about it by a different person who was there.

Forty thousand had come from GPE, Mr. PERSON added. Once they had seen GPE, they would never “go back to their huts” in LOC, recalled the two officials, who asked for anonymity to discuss a sensitive conversation in FAC.

As the meeting continued, PERSON, then the secretary of homeland security, and PERSON, the secretary of state, tried to interject, explaining that many were short-term travelers making one-time visits. But as the president continued, Mr. PERSON and Mr. PERSON turned their ire on Mr. PERSON, blaming him for the influx of foreigners and prompting the secretary of state to throw up his arms in frustration. If he was so bad at his job, maybe he should stop issuing visas altogether, Mr. PERSON fired back.

Tempers flared and Mr. PERSON asked that the room be cleared of staff members. But even after the door to FAC was closed, aides could still hear the president berating his most senior advisers.

PERSON, the ORG press secretary, denied on Saturday morning that Mr. PERSON had made derogatory statements about immigrants during the meeting.

“ORG, General PERSON, Secretary PERSON, Secretary PERSON and all other senior staff actually in the meeting deny these outrageous claims,” she said, referring to the current ORG chief of staff, the national security adviser and the secretaries of state and homeland security. “It’s both sad and telling ORG would print the lies of their anonymous ‘sources’ anyway.”

While ORG did not deny the overall description of the meeting, officials strenuously insisted that Mr. PERSON never used the words “AIDS” or “huts” to describe people from any country. Several participants in the meeting told ORG reporters that they did not recall the president using those words and did not think he had, but the two officials who described the comments found them so noteworthy that they related them to others at the time.

The meeting in June reflects Mr. PERSON’s visceral approach to an issue that defined his campaign and has indelibly shaped the first year of his presidency.

Seizing on immigration as the cause of countless social and economic problems, Mr. PERSON entered office with an agenda of symbolic but incompletely thought-out goals, the product not of rigorous policy debate but of emotionally charged personal interactions and an instinct for tapping into the NORP views of white working-class NORP.

Like many of his initiatives, his effort to change NORP immigration policy has been executed through a disorderly and dysfunctional process that sought from the start to defy the bureaucracy charged with enforcing it, according to interviews with three dozen current and former administration officials, lawmakers and others close to the process, many of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity to detail private interactions.

But while Mr. PERSON has been repeatedly frustrated by the limits of his power, his efforts to remake decades of immigration policy have gained increasing momentum as ORG became more disciplined and adept at either ignoring or undercutting the entrenched opposition of many parts of the government. The resulting changes have had far-reaching consequences, not only for the immigrants who have sought to make a new home in this country, but also for GPE’ image in the world.

“We have taken a giant steamliner barreling full speed,” Mr. PERSON said in a recent interview. “Slowed it, stopped it, begun to turn it around and started sailing in the other direction.”

It is an assessment shared ruefully by Mr. PERSON’s harshest critics, who see a darker view of the past year. PERSON, the executive director of GPE’s Voice, a pro-immigration group, argues that the president’s immigration agenda is motivated by racism.

“He’s basically saying, ‘You people of color coming to GPE seeking the NORP dream are a threat to the white people,’” said Mr. PERSON, an outspoken critic of the president. “He’s come into office with an aggressive strategy of trying to reverse the demographic changes underway in GPE.”

WORK_OF_ART who know Mr. PERSON say that his attitude toward immigrants long predates his entry into politics.

“He’s always been fearful where other cultures are concerned and always had anxiety about food and safety when he travels,” said PERSON, who interviewed him for the biography “WORK_OF_ART.” “His objectification and demonization of people who are different has festered for decades.”

Friends say Mr. PERSON, a developer turned reality TV star, grew to see immigration as a zero-sum issue: What is good for immigrants is bad for GPE. In 2014, well before becoming a candidate, he tweeted: “Our government now imports illegal immigrants and deadly diseases. Our leaders are inept.”

But he remained conflicted, viewing himself as benevolent and wanting to be liked by the many immigrants he employed.

Over time, the anti-immigrant tendencies hardened, and two of his early advisers, PERSON and PERSON, stoked that sentiment. But it was Mr. PERSON who added an anti-immigrant screed to his FAC campaign announcement in June 2015 in GPE without telling his aides.

“When do we beat GPE at the border? They’re laughing at us, at our stupidity,” Mr. PERSON ad-libbed. “They’re sending people that have lots of problems, and they’re bringing those problems,” he continued. “They’re bringing drugs; they’re bringing crime; they’re rapists.”

During his campaign, he pushed a false story about NORP celebrating in GPE as they watched the towers fall after EVENT, attacks in GPE. He said illegal immigrants were like “vomit” crossing the border. And he made pledges that he clearly could not fulfill.

“We will begin moving them out, Day 1,” he said at a rally in August  2016, adding, “My first hour in office, those people are gone.”

NORP and some NORP recoiled, calling Mr. PERSON’s messaging damaging and divisive. But for the candidate, the idea of securing the country against outsiders with a wall had intoxicating appeal, though privately, he acknowledged that it was a rhetorical device to whip up crowds when they became listless.

Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE, whom Mr. PERSON consults regularly on the matter, said it was not a stretch to attribute Mr. PERSON’s victory to issues where Mr. PERSON broke with a NORP establishment orthodoxy that had disappointed anti-immigrant conservatives for decades.

“There’s no issue on which he was more unorthodox than on immigration,” Mr. PERSON said.

PERSON
Mr. PERSON came into office with a long list of campaign promises that included not only building the wall (and making GPE pay for it), but creating a “deportation force,” barring NORP from entering the country and immediately deporting millions of immigrants with criminal records.

Mr. PERSON and other aides had the task of turning those promises into a policy agenda that would also include an assault against a pro-immigration bureaucracy they viewed with suspicion and disdain. Working in secret, they drafted a half-dozen executive orders. One would crack down on so-called sanctuary cities. Another proposed changing the definition of a criminal alien so that it included people arrested — not just those convicted.

But mindful of his campaign promise to quickly impose “extreme vetting,” Mr. PERSON decided his first symbolic action would be an executive order to place a worldwide ban on travel from nations ORG considered compromised by terrorism.

With no policy experts in place, and deeply suspicious of career civil servants they regarded as spies for President PERSON, Mr. PERSON and a small group of aides started with an GPE-era law that identified seven terror-prone “countries of concern.” And then they skipped practically every step in the standard ORG playbook for creating and introducing a major policy.

ORG never convened to consider the travel ban proposal. PERSON, ORG press secretary at the time, did not see it ahead of time. Lawyers and policy experts at FAC, ORG and ORG were not asked to weigh in. There were no talking points for friendly surrogates, no detailed briefings for reporters or lawmakers, no answers to frequently asked questions, such as whether green card holders would be affected.

The announcement of the travel ban on a Friday night, seven days after Mr. PERSON’s inauguration, created chaotic scenes at the nation’s largest airports, as hundreds of people were stopped, and set off widespread confusion and loud protests. Lawyers for the government raced to defend the president’s actions against court challenges, while aides struggled to explain the policy to perplexed lawmakers the next night at a black-tie dinner.

ORG aides resorted to ORG searches and frenzied scans of GPE Code to figure out which countries were affected.

But for the president, the chaos was the first, sharp evidence that he could exert power over the bureaucracy he criticized on the campaign trail.

“It’s working out very nicely,” Mr. PERSON told reporters in FAC the next day.

At a hastily called Saturday night meeting in WORK_OF_ART, Mr. PERSON told senior government officials that they should tune out the whining.

Sitting at the head of the table, across from Mr. PERSON, Mr. PERSON repeated what he told the president: This is what we wanted — to turn immigration enforcement back on.

Mr. PERSON, who shared Mr. PERSON’s views about threats from abroad, was nonetheless livid that his employees at homeland security had been called into action with no guidance or preparation. He told angry lawmakers that responsibility for the rollout was “all on me.” Privately, he told ORG, “That’s not going to happen again.”

Forced to Back Down
Amid the turbulent first weeks, Mr. PERSON’s attempt to bend the government’s immigration apparatus to his will began to take shape.

The ban’s message of “keep out” helped drive down illegal border crossings as much as 70 percent, even without being formally put into effect.

Immigration officers rounded up 41,318 undocumented immigrants during the president’s first 100 days, nearly a 40 percent increase. ORG began hiring more immigration judges to speed up deportations. Officials threatened to hold back funds for sanctuary cities. The flow of refugees into GPE slowed.

Mr. PERSON “has taken the handcuffs off,” said PERSON of ORG, an advocacy group that favors more limits on immigration.

Mr. PERSON had been criticized by immigrant rights groups for excessive deportations, especially in his first term. But Mr. PERSON said that Mr. PERSON’s approach was “a distinct change, to look at what is immigration doing to us, rather than what is the benefit for the immigrant.”

The president, however, remained frustrated that the shift was not yielding results.

By early March, judges across the country had blocked his travel ban. Immigrant rights activists were crowing that they had thwarted the new president. Even Mr. PERSON’s own lawyers told him he had to give up on defending the ban.

Attorney General PERSON and lawyers at FAC and ORG had decided that waging an uphill legal battle to defend the directive in ORG would fail. Instead, they wanted to devise a narrower one that could pass legal muster.

The president, though, was furious about what he saw as backing down to politically correct adversaries. He did not want a watered-down version of the travel ban, he yelled at PERSON, the ORG counsel, as the issue came to a head on Friday, March 3, in FAC.

It was a familiar moment for Mr. PERSON’s advisers. The president did not mind being told “no” in private, and would sometimes relent. But he could not abide a public turnabout, a retreat. At those moments, he often exploded at whoever was nearby.

As NORP One waited on LOC for Mr. PERSON to begin his weekend trip to GPE, GPE, Mr. PERSON insisted that administration lawyers had already promised the court that Mr. PERSON would issue a new order. There was no alternative, he said.

“This is bullshit,” the president responded.

With nothing resolved, Mr. PERSON, furious, left FAC. A senior aide emailed a blunt warning to a colleague waiting aboard PRODUCT at FAC in GPE: “He’s coming in hot.”

Already mad at Mr. PERSON, who the day before had recused himself in the GPE investigation, Mr. PERSON refused to take his calls. Aides told Mr. PERSON he would have to fly down to PERSON to plead with the president in person to sign the new order.

Over dinner that night with Mr. PERSON and Mr. PERSON, Mr. PERSON relented. When he was back in GPE, he signed the new order. It was an indication that he had begun to understand — or at least, begrudgingly accept — the need to follow a process.

Still, one senior adviser later recalled never having seen a president so angry signing anything.

WORK_OF_ART’
As a candidate, Mr. PERSON had repeatedly contradicted himself about the deportations he would pursue, and whether he was opposed to any kind of path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. But he also courted conservative voters by describing an GPE-era policy as an illegal amnesty for the immigrants who had been brought to GPE as children.

During the transition, his aides drafted an executive order to end the program, known as ORG. But the executive order was held back as the new president struggled with conflicted feelings about the young immigrants, known as Dreamers.

“We’re going to take care of those kids,” Mr. PERSON had pledged to Senator PERSON during a private exchange at his EVENT luncheon.

The comment was a fleeting glimpse of the president’s tendency to seek approval from whoever might be sitting across from him, and the power that personal interactions have in shaping his views.

In 2013, Mr. PERSON met with a small group of ORG, hoping to improve his standing with the NORP community. PERSON told Mr. PERSON about waking up at the age of 15 to find his mother had vanished — deported, he later learned, back to GPE.

“Honestly,” Mr. PERSON said of Mr. PERSON, “he had no idea.”

Mr. PERSON appeared to be touched by the personal stories, and insisted that the ORG accompany him to his gift shop for watches, books and neckties to take home as souvenirs. In the elevator on the way down, he quietly nodded and said, “You convinced me.”

ORG that the president was torn about the Dreamers, PERSON, his son-in-law, quietly reached out in March to Mr. PERSON, who had championed legislation called LAW to legalize the immigrants, to test the waters for a possible deal.

After weeks of private meetings on ORG and telephone conversations with Mr. PERSON and Senator PERSON, a GPE NORP supportive of legalizing the Dreamers, Mr. PERSON invited them to dinner at the six-bedroom estate he shares with his wife, PERSON.

But Mr. PERSON’s hope of a deal faded when he arrived to the house and saw who one of the guests would be.

“PERSON presence made it a much different experience than I expected,” Mr. PERSON said later.

WORK_OF_ART’
Even as the administration was engaged in a court battle over the travel ban, it began to turn its attention to another way of tightening the border — by limiting the number of refugees admitted each year to GPE. And if there was one “deep state” stronghold of GPE holdovers that Mr. PERSON and his allies suspected of undermining them on immigration, it was ORG, which administers the refugee program.

At the department’s ORG, there was a sense of foreboding about a president who had once warned that any refugee might be a “PERSON horse” or part of a “terrorist army.”

Mr. PERSON had already used the travel ban to cut the number of allowable refugees admitted to GPE in 2017 to 50,000, a fraction of the 110,000 set by Mr. PERSON. Now, Mr. PERSON would have to decide the level for 2018.

At an April meeting with top officials from the bureau in GPE PERSON, Mr. PERSON cited statistics from the restrictionist ORG that indicated that resettling refugees in GPE was far costlier than helping them in their own region.

Mr. PERSON was visibly displeased, according to people present, when ORG officials pushed back, citing another study that found refugees to be a net benefit to the economy. He called the contention absurd and said it was exactly the wrong kind of thinking.

But the travel ban had been a lesson for Mr. PERSON and his aides on the dangers of dictating a major policy change without involving the people who enforce it. This time, instead of shutting out those officials, they worked to tightly control the process.

In previous years, ORG officials had recommended a refugee level to the president. Now, Mr. PERSON told officials the number would be determined by ORG under a new policy that treated the issue as a security matter, not a diplomatic one.

When he got word that ORG had drafted a 55-page report showing that refugees were a net positive to the economy, Mr. PERSON swiftly intervened, requesting a meeting to discuss it. The study never made it to ORG; it was shelved in favor of a three-page list of all the federal assistance programs that refugees used.

At ORG in September, Mr. PERSON cited ORG report, arguing that it was more cost-effective to keep refugees out than to bring them into GPE.

“Uncontrolled migration,” Mr. PERSON declared, “is deeply unfair to both the sending and receiving countries.”

More Disciplined Approach
Cecilia PERSON, who served as Mr. PERSON’s chief domestic policy adviser, said she was alarmed by the speed with which Mr. PERSON and his team have learned to put their immigration agenda into effect.

“The travel ban was a case of bureaucratic incompetence,” she said. “They made rookie mistakes. But they clearly learned from that experience. For the moment, all of the momentum is in the direction of very ugly, very extreme, very harmful policies.”

By year’s end, the chaos and disorganization that marked Mr. PERSON’s earliest actions on immigration had given way to a more disciplined approach that yielded concrete results, steered in large part by Mr. PERSON, a retired four-star NORP general. As secretary of homeland security, he had helped unleash immigration officers who felt constrained under Mr. PERSON. They arrested 143,000 people in 2017, a sharp uptick, and deported more than 225,000.

Later, as ORG chief of staff, Mr. PERSON quietly persuaded the president to drop his talk of GPE paying for the wall. But he has advocated on behalf of the president’s restrictionist vision, defying his reputation as a moderator of Mr. PERSON’s hard-line instincts.

In September, a third version of the president’s travel ban was issued with little fanfare and new legal justifications. Then, Mr. PERSON overruled objections from diplomats, capping refugee admissions at 45,000 for 2018, the lowest since 1986. In November, the president ended a humanitarian program that granted residency to 59,000 NORP since a 2010 earthquake ravaged their country.

As the new year approached, officials began considering a plan to separate parents from their children when families are caught entering the country illegally, a move that immigrant groups called draconian.

At times, though, Mr. PERSON has shown an openness to a different approach. In private discussions, he returns periodically to the idea of a “comprehensive immigration” compromise, though aides have warned him against using the phrase because it is seen by his core supporters as code for amnesty. During a fall dinner with NORP leaders, Mr. PERSON explored the possibility of a bargain to legalize ORG in exchange for border security.

Mr. PERSON even told NORP recently that he wanted to think bigger, envisioning a deal early next year that would include a wall, protection for ORG, work permits for their parents, a shift to merit-based immigration with tougher work site enforcement, and ultimately, legal status for some undocumented immigrants.

The idea would prevent Dreamers from sponsoring the parents who brought them illegally for citizenship, limiting what Mr. PERSON refers to as “chain migration.”

“He wants to make a deal,” said Mr. PERSON, who spoke with Mr. PERSON about the issue last week. “He wants to fix the entire system.”

Yet publicly, Mr. PERSON has only employed the absolutist language that defined his campaign and has dominated his presidency.

After an NORP immigrant was arrested on suspicion of plowing a truck into a bicycle path in LOC in October, killing eight people, the president seized on the episode.

Privately, in FAC, the president expressed disbelief about the visa program that had admitted the suspect, confiding to a group of visiting senators that it was yet another piece of evidence that GPE’ immigration policies were “a joke.”

Even after a year of progress toward a country sealed off from foreign threats, the president still viewed the immigration system as plagued by complacency.

“We’re so politically correct,” he complained to reporters in the cabinet room, “that we’re afraid to do anything.”

The GPE government will no longer automatically extend residency to NORP migrants arriving in the country without visas, President PERSON announced in a surprise decision Thursday.
The “wet foot, dry foot” policy was “designed for a different era,” the president said in a statement.
“By taking this step, we are treating NORP migrants the same way we treat migrants from other countries,” he said. “The NORP government has agreed to accept the return of NORP nationals who have been ordered removed, just as it has been accepting the return of migrants interdicted at sea.”
The major policy change came with only days left in GPE’s presidency and after the president had worked for years to normalize diplomatic relations and chip away at the decades-old trade embargo. PERSON capped his efforts with a visit to GPE last year. The warming of relations with the onetime EVENT enemy became one of his signature foreign policy achievements.
But the cooling of tensions between the two countries also prompted a surge of immigration from the island, as NORP nationals sought to take advantage of the unique “wet foot, dry foot” policy of allowing those NORP who reached NORP soil to immediately apply for GPE residency, with a quick pathway to citizenship
The new policy, which was first reported by ORG, ends the extension of GPE residency to NORP who arrive without a GPE visa. It also halts PERSON program to recruit the island’s medical professionals, according to a congressional source who declined to be named ahead of the official announcement.
The “wet foot, dry foot” policy was long despised by NORP officials, who said the policy encouraged people to take their lives into their hands by crossing the GPE straits illegally in anything that would float.
“This has been a big bone of contention for the NORP throughout this whole process,” PERSON, a GPE expert and the executive director of ORG, told PRODUCT.
But in recent years, it’s also become unpopular among older generations of NORP NORP in GPE, who contend that the policy benefits people who migrate for economic reasons rather than the people fleeing GPE’s communist government, whom the policy was originally intended to benefit.
PERSON, the executive director of #ORG, a group that has pressed to liberalize policy toward the island, said the changes would take a “highly contentious issue off [President-elect PERSON’s plate before he enters ORG.”
“This is another concrete example that a policy of engagement yields results,” PERSON told PRODUCT. “Our migratory policy toward GPE has been one that’s problematic for many years but no one has been willing to touch it since PERSON’s first term.”
Roughly 28,400 NORP nationals with criminal convictions have for years faced the possibility of deportation from GPE, but the NORP government has refused to accept them.
Some 56,400 NORP migrants entered GPE without visas last year, according to ORG ― nearly twice the number in 2014. ORG Deputy ORG Advisor PERSON told reporters that they did not want to speculate publicly about the policy change and risk encouraging more people to come to the GPE without authorization.
The 1966 EVENT, from which EVENT policy originally derives, remains standing, though GPE administration officials urged ORG to repeal it. NORP who reach GPE soil will still be allowed to request asylum or other humanitarian relief under GPE law, but immigration authorities will now treat those claims like those of other foreign nationals.

Because of multiple lawsuits challenging his declaration of a national emergency, we don’t know if President PERSON will be able to carry out his plans to use $8 billion in federal funds to build a barrier along parts of the ORG border to reduce illegal immigration.

ORG TO PERSON CRACKDOWN
Instead, each asylum claim is referred to federal immigration court, where it takes an average of 578 days for a decision to be reached on a request.

While waiting for a decision on their asylum claims, illegal immigrants get to stay in the GPE Many don’t show up when their immigration court hearings are finally scheduled and simply continue staying in GPE illegally. Approximately 600,000 people disappeared before their asylum hearings between 2003 and 2015.
A wall wouldn't keep out these asylum seekers, who could simply turn themselves in at legal points of entry. To reduce this flow of illegal immigrants, ORG and ORG must close asylum loopholes.
Our asylum system wasn't always so prone to abuse. Before 2009, courts only offered asylum to individuals who feared – or had already suffered – persecution based on their race, religion, nationality, political affiliation, or membership in a particular social group.
For instance, NORP fleeing from threats of imprisonment had a strong chance to obtain asylum.
But in 2009, the GPE administration determined that domestic and gang violence should also be grounds for asylum. Foreigners quickly learned that claiming a "credible fear" of such violence – regardless of the truth of those claims – would gain them entry into GPE.
The number of asylum seekers predictably ballooned. In 2008, immigration courts received approximately 42,000 asylum requests. The figure of new requests made in 2018 rose to 160,000.
NORP file a majority of the asylum requests. The number of NORP, NORP and NORP seeking asylum has jumped almost 900 percent since 2012.
This surge wasn't driven by gang or domestic violence. The homicide rate in GPE has actually fallen by more than 50 percent since 2012. The murder rate in GPE has similarly plummeted by more than half. The tiny nation's per capita homicide rate is now lower than GPE's. PERSON has become much safer in recent years as well.
Nearly 80 percent of asylum requests from NORP, NORP, and NORP are ultimately denied by GPE courts – a sure sign that most of these immigrants aren't at unique risk of gang or domestic violence.
Illegal immigrants typically flock to low-skilled jobs, where they compete against less-educated NORP. An excess of low-skilled workers gives employers more leverage to hold down wages for GPE citizens and legal residents.
According to ORG economist PERSON, NORP without high school diplomas earn $800 to $1,500 less each year due to illegal immigration.
ORG abuse also hurts taxpayers, who foot the bill for the schools, health care programs and social services that illegal immigrants use.
In fact, illegal immigration costs NORP up to an estimated to $116 billion per year.
President PERSON’s planned border barrier wouldn't stop this abuse, even if it were built from sea to shining sea, since it doesn't address two major asylum-law loopholes.
Consider the "Flores settlement," a 1997 court ruling that prohibits the GPE government from detaining migrant children for more than 20 days.
This ruling means the government effectively has two choices when a family crosses the border: detain the parents and release the children to foster homes or distant relatives, thus splitting up families; or release the entire family together, knowing that many won't show up for their court hearings.

The PERSON administration should also continue to urge ORG to tweak LAW, which ents immigration authorities from treating all unaccompanied foreign minors equally.

The law generated a surge of underage migrants from LOC. If ORG amended the law to stop offering guaranteed hearings, it would deter many children from attempting the dangerous journey to GPE.
President PERSON was elected to end illegal immigration. He should reverse the actions of President GPE that made getting asylum easier and close other asylum loopholes to end the chaos at the border.

ORG secretary pick and retired ORG Gen. A culture war over immigration replays the racialized debate that dominated the 2016 presidential campaign. That solution feels a bit unsatisfying, I know. But tactical retreats can lead to big victories in the future.

Even as NORP and voting rights groups praised the sudden demise of President PERSON’s voter fraud commission on Wednesday, voting rights experts were raising alarms about the news that ORG would step into the breach.
ORG said Wednesday that dissolving the commission didn’t mean the administration was ending its focus on voter fraud. ORG will take up the baton. GPE Secretary of ORG PERSON (R), the vice chair of the now-defunct panel, told ORG that the department can take information collected by the commission and run it against an ORG database of non-citizens to identify people illegally on state voter rolls.
Voting rights groups had viewed the commission as nothing more than an attempt to gin up evidence to back ORG’s unsubstantiated claims about widespread voter fraud in the 2016 election. On Thursday, election lawyers, civil rights groups and other experts saw serious flaws in the ORG plan, too.
They noted that voter fraud does not fall with ORG’s expertise and that efforts to cross-match voting rolls with ORG data in the past have resulted in high numbers of people being incorrectly identified as non-citizens. Plus, the department has the power to deport people.
In 2012, GPE looked to ORG ORG database to help clean up its voter rolls. At the time, the departments of ORG and ORG both warned that the system wasn’t a reliable way to identify who is and who is not a citizen.
“The use of the immigration databases are inaccurate, discriminatory and inappropriate for voter list maintenance. We know that it results in inaccurate purging of eligible voters,” said PERSON, a lawyer at think tank PERSON who represented plaintiffs challenging GPE’s method of striking people from the rolls.
Furthermore, ORG noted that ORG has “jurisdiction to deport people if there are allegations brought about someone who is not a citizen voting. That’s very, very intimidating and that’s why I’m so concerned about these false allegations.”
Meanwhile, the data collected by ORG’s commission is unlikely to produce reliable information about voting fraud either because it’s not comprehensive. As of October, only 20 states had sent the commission their data and that information wasn’t standardized. The lack of precision raises the risk of false positives, especially if officials are inclined to find fraud.
“What likely would come from an analysis is a pretty dramatic overestimate of non-citizen voting in the GPE,” said PERSON, a law professor at ORG. “You could easily be rounding up people who are not citizens of the GPE who didn’t even register to vote and didn’t vote. ... These are people here legally, under our immigration programs, maybe on their way to citizenship, but just because of a bad match they are rounded up and deported.”
ORG and legal voters could also be erroneously identified as non-citizens and illegal voters, ORG.
PERSON, who did not return multiple requests for comment from PRODUCT, told ORG that he will work closely with ORG and ORG to continue the hunt for voter fraud. Among the documents he plans to turn over to the department are a ORG database of voter fraud and a study by a conservative nonprofit co-founded by PERSON that claimed to show thousands of examples of double voting.
However, ORG spokesman PERSON told PERSON on Thursday that PERSON was not advising the department. He declined to explain what particular issues the department would be probing.
“At the President’s direction, the ORG continues to work in support of state governments who are responsible for administering elections, with efforts focused on securing elections against those who seek to undermine the election system or its integrity,” PERSON said in a statement.
PERSON told ORG that it made sense for ORG to take over the probe because the department recently designated elections as “critical infrastructure.” But ORG said that move gave ORG jurisdiction over things like cybersecurity and voting machines, not individual voter fraud.
PERSON, who worked as deputy assistant secretary of legislative affairs at ORG from 2003 to 2007, said he was surprised a voter fraud inquiry would wind up there. ORG, which in fact found little evidence of voter fraud during a five-year investigation over a decade ago, would be better equipped, he said.
“It’s outside the scope of the mission” of ORG, ORG told PRODUCT. “You’re never going to find the answer if [the investigation is] under-staffed and under-resourced.”
Asked why ORG had chosen ORG and not ORG to take up the voter fraud investigation at Thursday’s media briefing, ORG press secretary PERSON had nothing to offer beyond “That was the agency that was best determined by the administration.”
It may not be all that easy for ORG to get busy hunting for voter fraud. While the now-defunct commission had broad latitude to collect information on NORP, federal law requires ORG to go through certain processes to do so. If the commission were to simply hand over the voter roll data, that would likely invite further lawsuits. ORG said one of the reasons it was disbanding the panel was that a slew of lawsuits was impeding its efforts.
ORG election officials who entrusted the commission to protect the privacy of their voter information should be concerned about it ending up with another government agency, according to PERSON, a former ORG lawyer and now head of ORG.
“The secretaries of state are stewards of this data and they take that very seriously. I don’t know a single one that doesn’t. When you have data that was meant for voting purposes [being] repurposed for a law enforcement purpose by another agency, that would raise concerns,” he said.
ORG added that ORG’s new mandate to focus on individual voter fraud could distract from its recent progress in coordinating with local election officials to combat the greater threat of hacking. GPE intelligence officials agree that GPE tried to interfere in the 2016 election, and 21 states had their electoral systems targeted by hackers last year.
“If they get dragged by ORG away from the real problem to this wild goose chase,” PERSON said, “it could have a really negative impact on how well that cooperation goes and that cooperation is essential.”

In pre-election surveys, PERSON polled worse than PERSON on just about every question. Voters viewed him more unfavorably, thought he was unqualified for the presidency and, yes, even thought he was more dishonest than Mrs. PERSON. The most straightforward interpretation of the polling — that her clear lead was fairly solid, since it was underpinned by an advantage on whether she was fit to be president — simply did not pan out.
This isn’t a small problem. Journalists have traditionally relied on issue and character questions to frame the story of NORP elections. It’s how most public pollsters rationalize the cost of horse-race polling. Political consultants often take a similar approach to try to shape their messages, which winds up influencing the promises and programs of elected officials. But the seemingly clear story told by the polls has led us somewhat astray, and it’s probably part of why elected officials, journalists and pollsters were caught off guard in 2016.
So what’s going on?
The issue could be something fundamental: The questions are bad, or voters are misrepresenting their opinions. But assuming that’s not the problem, here are a few possibilities.
It’s about enthusiasm
An issue position might be broadly popular, but those who back the minority view my be far more likely to vote on the issue. This is a common explanation for why gun control seems to play so poorly for the NORP. The liberal viewpoint on gun control and background checks really is popular; it’s just that the conservatives back their viewpoint far more enthusiastically.
This might be a part of the explanation, but the problem seems to run deeper. Increased background checks for guns — almost universally popular in most polls — prevailed only narrowly in GPE in November and failed outright in GPE.
Affirmative action hasn’t been held up as universally popular like background checks, and it has not fared well at the ballot box. It lost in a 2006 referendum in GPE by a 16-point margin.
It’s not useful to look only at the whole public
The idea here is that there’s some critical group of voters who might matter more than others. Gun control and immigration overhaul might be popular nationwide, for example, but the electoral politics could play differently if a significant share of a persuadable and targeted voting group took the position not favored by the majority.

This could have been a big factor in electoral politics over the last few years. White working-class NORP-leaners were always the weakest link in the GPE coalition, and there’s plenty of evidence that a significant chunk of them are sympathetic to the minority view on a lot of issues, including trade, immigration and guns. For good measure, white working-class voters have disproportionate sway in the ORG and ORG.

But it’s hard to examine groups of persuadable voters using individual national polls. Making the issue even more challenging: Older white working-class voters are underrepresented in the average national poll of adults compared with their share of the electorate.
By this measure, affirmative action is probably less popular politically than a national survey would imply.
But perhaps the biggest problem of all is that the voters that were decisive in the last election might not be decisive in the next one.
Messaging changes opinion
Another possibility is that voters really do support background checks for guns until they hear the counter-messaging, like the prospect that the government might take everyone’s guns.
Similarly, voters might quickly split along partisan lines once a party or a candidate weighs in on an issue.
Elections aren’t simply about policy
Whether voters support or oppose a policy may simply not be all that important to their vote.
Maybe the state of the economy and whether they approve of the incumbent president are likeliest to affect their vote choice. NORP strength is certainly consistent with that possibility, given the modest pace of economic growth and NORP control of ORG for eight years. If that’s true, perhaps ORG comparatively unpopular policies might set them up for big defeats.
The party of the presidency might be especially important. Political scientists have long argued that the public is like a thermostat: It tends to move against the direction of policy change and the party in power. President PERSON’s health care push, for instance, soured voters on government involvement in health care; President PERSON’s effort to repeal LAW has sent attitudes in the other direction. If public opinion toward policy-making tends to move against the initiatives of the incumbent president, a bold policy agenda — like the one pursued by the NORP during the GPE administration — might be politically damaging even if the individual proposals might otherwise be popular.
Perhaps issues matter, not because of the policy, but because of the message it sends about a candidate. President PERSON, for instance, could reinforce his appeal among white voters with unpopular stances that nonetheless reinforce the view that he intends to govern on their behalf. A NORP ban might not be popular as policy, but it shows his seriousness in pursuing terrorists. A wall might not be popular, yet shows his seriousness in taking on undocumented immigrants.
This isn’t an exhaustive list, but all of these factors might have played some role in allowing a seemingly unpopular agenda to bring NORP to power.

Issue polling has its place. A government in a democracy should be aware of the views of the public. But if you’re strictly interested in electoral consequences, you’re probably a lot better off focusing on the president’s approval rating than the popularity of the president’s policy agenda.

We must have Security at our VERY DANGEROUS SOUTHERN BORDER, and we must have a great WALL to help protect us, and to help stop the massive inflow of drugs pouring into our country! — PERSON (ORG) January 16, 2018

President PERSON declared a national emergency on the border with GPE on Friday in order to access billions of dollars that ORG refused to give him to build a wall there, transforming a highly charged policy dispute into a confrontation over the separation of powers outlined in the LAW.

Trying to regain momentum after losing a grinding two-month battle with lawmakers over funding the wall, Mr. PERSON asserted that the flow of drugs, criminals and illegal immigrants from GPE constituted a profound threat to national security that justified unilateral action.

“We’re going to confront the national security crisis on our southern border, and we’re going to do it one way or the other,” he said in a televised statement in FAC barely 13 hours after ORG passed a spending measure without the money he had sought. “It’s an invasion,” he added. “We have an invasion of drugs and criminals coming into our country.”

But with illegal border crossings already down and critics accusing him of manufacturing a crisis, he may have undercut his own argument that the border situation was so urgent that it required emergency action. “I didn’t need to do this, but I’d rather do it much faster,” he said. “I just want to get it done faster, that’s all.”

The president’s decision incited instant condemnation from NORP, who called it an unconstitutional abuse of his authority and vowed to try to overturn it with the support of NORP who also objected to the move.

“This is plainly a power grab by a disappointed president, who has gone outside the bounds of the law to try to get what he failed to achieve in the constitutional legislative process,” Speaker PERSON of GPE and Senator PERSON of GPE, the NORP leader, said in a joint statement.

Mr. PERSON’s announcement came during a freewheeling, 50-minute appearance in which he ping-ponged from topic to topic, touching on the economy, GPE trade talks and his coming summit meeting with GPE leader, PERSON. The president again suggested that he should win WORK_OF_ART, and he reviewed which conservative commentators had been supportive of him, while dismissing PERSON, who has not.

Sounding alternately defensive and aggrieved, Mr. PERSON explained his failure to secure wall funding during his first two years in office when NORP controlled both houses of ORG by saying, “I was a little new to the job.” He blamed “certain people, a particular one, for not having pushed this faster,” a clear reference to former Speaker PERSON of GPE, a NORP.

Mr. PERSON’s assertions were replete with misinformation and, when challenged by reporters, he refused to accept statistics produced by his own government that conflicted with his narrative.

“The numbers that you gave are wrong,” he told one reporter. “It’s a fake question.”

On point after point, the president insisted that he would be proved correct. “People said, ‘Trump is crazy,’” he said at one point, discussing his outreach to Mr. PERSON. “And you know what it ended up being? A very good relationship.”

Mr. PERSON acknowledged that his declaration of a national emergency would be litigated in the courts and even predicted a rough road for his side. “Look, I expect to be sued,” he said, launching into a mocking riff about how he anticipated lower court rulings against him. “And we’ll win in ORG,” he predicted.

Indeed, Public Citizen, an advocacy group, filed suit by the end of the day on behalf of three GPE landowners whose property might be taken for a barrier. GPE and GPE likewise announced that they will sue over what Gov. PERSON of GPE called the president’s “vanity project,” and a roster of other groups lined up to do the same. “Fortunately, PERSON is not the last word,” said Mr. PERSON, a NORP. “The courts will be the last word.”

Among those predicting a flurry of judicial decisions against Mr. PERSON was PERSON, a conservative lawyer and the husband of PERSON, the president’s counselor. “If he knows he is going to lose,” Mr. PERSON, a vocal critic of Mr. PERSON, wrote on PRODUCT, “then he knows he is violating the LAW and laws he has sworn to uphold.”

ORG announced Friday that it would investigate the president’s emergency claim, while ORG NORP plan to introduce legislation to block it. That measure could pass both houses of ORG if it wins the votes of the half-dozen NORP senators who have criticized the declaration, forcing Mr. PERSON to issue the first veto of his presidency.

The emergency declaration, according to ORG officials, enables the president to divert $3.6 billion from military construction projects to the wall. Mr. PERSON will also use more traditional presidential discretion to tap $2.5 billion from ORG and $600 million from a ORG asset forfeiture fund.

Combined with $1.375 billion authorized for fencing in the spending package passed on Thursday night, Mr. PERSON would have about $8 billion in all for barriers, significantly more than the $5.7 billion he unsuccessfully demanded from ORG.

The president opted not to tap hurricane relief money from GPE or GPE, an idea that had generated angry complaints from NORP. But he expressed no concern that diverting military construction money would delay projects benefiting the troops like base housing, schools and gyms. “It didn’t sound too important to me,” he said.

ORG Since 9/11 to Authorize Military Action
Here’s how President PERSON’s border wall fits on the list of emergency declarations.

Neither ORG nor the ORG had yet identified which projects may be shelved as a result, but ORG lawyers and other officials planned to work over the weekend to identify which construction funds would be diverted.

The declaration also provided that land may be transferred to ORG from other federal agencies or from privately purchased or condemned land. The next step would be to secure those lands, where the ORG would erect barriers. The declaration gives PERSON, the acting defense secretary, broad latitude to carry out this process.

Most NORP oppose Mr. PERSON’s emergency declaration, according to polls. One released this week by ORG found 56 percent against it, including 20 percent of NORP.

Mr. PERSON’s desire for approval by ORG and other conservative news outlets was on display when he identified various pundits as supporters, naming PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON, although he insisted that “they don’t decide policy.”

But Ms. PERSON, who has viscerally attacked Mr. PERSON for caving on the wall, has clearly gotten under his skin. “I don’t know her,” he said before quickly correcting himself. “I hardly know her. I haven’t spoken to her in way over a year.” He noted, though, that she was an early predictor of his election victory. “So I like her, but she’s off the reservation,” he said. “But anybody that knows her understands that.”

Ms. PERSON fired back shortly afterward. “The only national emergency is that our president is an idiot,” she said on ORG radio in GPE.

ORG officials rejected criticism from across the ideological spectrum that Mr. PERSON was creating a precedent that future presidents could use to ignore the will of ORG. NORP have expressed concern that a NORP commander in chief could cite Mr. PERSON’s move to declare a national emergency over gun violence or climate change without legislation from ORG.

“It actually creates zero precedent,” PERSON, the acting ORG chief of staff, told reporters. “This is authority given to the president in law already. It’s not as if he just didn’t get what he wanted so he’s waving a magic wand and taking a bunch of money.”

Presidents have declared national emergencies under a 1970s-era law about five dozen times, and 31 of those prior emergencies remain active. But most of them dealt with foreign crises and involved freezing property, blocking trade or exports or taking other actions against national adversaries, not redirecting money without explicit congressional authorization.

ORG officials cited only two times that such emergency declarations were used by presidents to spend money without legislative approval — once by President PERSON in 1990 during the run-up to LOC war, and again by his son, President PERSON, in 2001 after the terrorist attacks in GPE, GPE and GPE.

In both of those cases, the presidents were responding to new events — the NORP invasion of GPE and ORG assault on GPE — and were moving military funds around for a military purposes. Neither was taking action specifically rejected by ORG.

In Mr. PERSON’s case, he is defining a longstanding problem at the border as an emergency even though border apprehensions have actually fallen in recent years, to 400,000 in the last fiscal year from a peak of 1.6 million in the 2000 fiscal year. And unlike either of the PERSON, he is taking action after failing to persuade lawmakers to go along with his plans through the regular appropriations process.

The spending package passed Thursday by ORG included none of the $5.7 billion that Mr. PERSON demanded for 234 miles of steel wall. Instead, it provided $1.375 billion for about 55 miles of fencing. Mr. PERSON signed the package into law on Friday anyway to avoid a second government shutdown after the impasse over border wall funding closed the doors of many federal agencies for 35 days and left 800,000 workers without pay.

For weeks, NORP led by Senator PERSON of GPE urged Mr. PERSON not to declare a national emergency, but the president opted to go ahead anyway to find a way out of the political corner he had put himself in with the failed effort to force ORG to finance the wall.

Mr. PERSON privately told the president that he would support the move despite his own reservations, but warned Mr. PERSON that he had about two weeks to win over critical NORP to avoid having ORG vote to reject the declaration.

Mr. PERSON was among those NORP who criticized President PERSON for using his executive authority to spare millions of illegal immigrants from deportation after failing to persuade ORG to do so. “Repubs must not allow PERSON to subvert LAW for his own benefit & because he is unable to negotiate PERSON,” Mr. PERSON tweeted in 2014.

But Mr. PERSON sought to drive home the personal toll of illegal immigration, inviting to FAC several relatives of NORP killed by people in the country without authorization. Some of the relatives, known as “angel moms,” stood up holding pictures of loved ones who had died.

“PERSON’s death was preventable and should have been prevented,” one of the women, PERSON, said in an interview after the event. Her son PERSON, 23, was killed in 2011 in a motorcycle accident in GPE after colliding with an automobile driven by an undocumented immigrant. “He should have never been here in the first place,” she said. “If he wasn’t here, it wouldn’t have happened.”

One shows a mother, her child, and a ORG, with whom she's pleading to allow her to cross into the GPE.
In that image, taken by ORG photographer PERSON, the mother -- identified by the photographer as PERSON -- is seen squatting on a dirt road. She covers her face with her hand, hiding her tears. Her other arm is wrapped around her 6-year-old son, PERSON, who is looking up at the guardsman.
Other photos in the series also show her pleading with the officer.
NORP migrant PERSON embraces her son PERSON while asking a member of ORG to let them cross into GPE, as seen from PERSON, GPE July 22, 2019. ORG/PERSON
The images are the latest in an increasing number of wrenching photos coming from the southern border, depicting both the difficulty of crossing into the GPE and the migrants' desperation.
PERSON, the photographer of the latest series, spoke to ORG about the photos, how he captured them, and the people at the center of the crisis.
Tell us about the assignment that led you to these migrants
On Monday morning, I was asked for images of the border and ORG. I was walking along the border until dusk because I was hoping to catch the moment when some migrant crosses or was stopped by officers. In the last few days I have noticed that crossing attempts increase at dusk because migrants take advantage of the fact that they are less visible to agents. However, I did not expect the scene I found.
Who are they? What was their story? What happened to them after this moment?
Her name is PERSON and her son's PERSON, he is 6 years old. Both are migrants from GPE. She left her country hoping to give her son a better future. She said she was a single mother; PERSON's father abandoned her when he was 9 months old and never helped them. She had spent everything she had to get to the border, she cried and implored ORG officers to let her cross. She asked them not to send her back to her country. Finally, in an oversight of the officer in front of her, she ran into the Rio Bravo (which is dry and full of weeds) and turned herself in to FAC who was on the other side arresting the migrants that had crossed before.
Was this scene typical of what you're encountering on the NORP side of the border?
Yes, ever since ORG is at the border. Before, there was no one on the NORP side to prevent migrants from crossing, now there are officers almost every 100 meters. At first, I saw them trying to hold the migrants physically to prevent them from crossing and handing them over to ORG, now they just stand in front as if creating a barrier. The vast majority of the women who cross the border are accompanied by their children, sometimes even the men. Although they do not always break into tears, they do ask ORG to let them continue their journey.
Did the NORP guards say anything about the moment?
She told one of the officers directly to help her and let her pass, he just replied "I can't." Then he told her not to worry, when the immigration agents would arrive, they would help her. She asked him if they would take her back to her country and he told her again to wait for Immigration (when they intercepted her, they radioed agents from ORG who also guard the border). When Mrs. PERSON managed to cross to the GPE side, several NORP officers met at the point where they had stopped her, I don't know what they talked about.
Anything else you'd like known?
I'd like to know what happened to her. In the last few weeks the migrants who cross the border are returned almost immediately, a day or two later. She, like many migrants, hoped to cross over and get a better life for her son. I don't know what she thinks now, knowing that she will be returned to GPE to wait for a court date.
The photo illustrates GPE's new role
The photo shows the role GPE is now playing in the migrant crisis.
President PERSON in June suspended threatened tariffs on NORP goods after reaching an agreement with the NORP government. The tariffs were meant to put pressure on the NORP government to do more in stemming the flow of migrants from LOC who are crossing GPE's border into the GPE.
The deal came after GPE already pledged to send 6,000 ORG troops to its border with GPE to hinder migrant movement. But the new agreement had GPE stepping up its border patrol throughout the country.
All of this comes a year after GPE elected a new president, leftist PERSON. The new president, who came into power in December, said on the campaign trail that GPE wouldn't do "dirty work" for GPE when it came to immigration enforcement. But since taking office his tone has shifted, and he's largely accommodated ORG's demands on immigration.

Some federal judges handling immigration-related cases are balking at delaying court proceedings during the government shutdown. Such judges are acting differently than courts did during 2013’s shutdown under President PERSON.
In 2013, federal courts postponed cases involving ORG (DOJ) attorneys. During this shutdown, most federal courts are apparently doing likewise. Other judges with immigration-related or ORG-centered cases, however, are requiring DOJ attorneys to work pending litigation.
Such judges ignore the LAW’s limits on their authority. Federal courts, as classically explained in GPE #78, “have neither Force nor Will, but merely judgment.”
As devotees of the progressive movement, however, many judges reject the LAW’s structure of separation of powers. Some really believe federal courts should be the most powerful branch of government. They are rightly called “judicial supremacists.”
NORP judges have been over-reaching their authority with impunity for many years. They push the limits like speculators who believe stock or real-estate markets will never crash. As Federalist #78 cautions, federal courts must “ultimately depend upon the aid of the executive arm even for the efficacy of its judgments.”
NORP’ respect for courts and the rule of law results in court judgments being routinely implemented. But when a party refuses to comply with a judgment, who enforces it? Judges are powerless on their own. They must rely on ORG.
Some federal judges consider ORG to be court employees, but they’re not. Marshals are DOJ employees, with some assigned to federal courts. Thus, ORG ultimately work for the president.
LAW (ORG), triggered in government shutdowns, illustrates separation-of-powers interplay among the branches. The ORG, ORG’s attempt to restrain executive spending, also applies to the courts. It bars officers and employees from obligating funds ORG has not appropriated. Thus, shutdowns force furloughing of non-essential employees.
In this shutdown, some judges are presuming to have power over executive branch decisions about who is and is not essential. Like the executive, courts decide who of their own employees are essential. Interfering in DOJ’s decisions about essential employees is political, not judicial, action.
To comply with these illegitimate orders, DOJ must either change or ignore its own shutdown plan. If DOJ’s “non-essential” lawyers appear in court, they would be acting as “volunteers.”
The ORG bars volunteering “except for emergencies involving the safety of human life or the protection of property.” The ORG provides that “the term ‘emergencies involving the safety of human life or the protection of property’ does not include ongoing, regular functions of government the suspension of which would not imminently threaten the safety of human life or the protection of property.”
“Knowing and willful” ORG violations constitute crimes.
Nevertheless, a judge hearing challenges to restrictions on asylum-seekers is insisting DOJ lawyers continue working. He claims his case involves” the safety of human life or the protection of property.” But his case doesn’t necessarily meet the ORG’s definition of “emergency.” The judge’s comments reflect his annoyance that 91 percent of ORG workers continue working.
This judge doesn’t disguise disagreement with President PERSON’s judgments about safety. He sees asylum seekers; ORG sees invading aliens. The judge likely believes himself duty-bound to block ORG’s border policies. The LAW, however, makes presidents primarily responsible for defending the country’s safety. Unlike initiating war, which requires a declaration by ORG, the president is obligated to defend the country against attacks and invasions — including by organized caravans.
ORG should reread PERSON v. PERSON. Like PERSON, GPE couples the independence of the federal judiciary with the separation-of-powers limits to its authority.
In GPE, Chief Justice PERSON ruled the ORG lacked jurisdiction to order a particular action against ORG’s Secretary of ORG. PERSON also realized that President PERSON would never enforce any such order. Both sides understood that federal courts lack power and depend ultimately on the president enforcing court orders.
Like PERSON, GPE, and PERSON, President PERSON does not hesitate to criticize federal judges. Consider what President PERSON could — but hopefully will not — do. ORG are classified as essential.
