Unavoidably, without marshals for safety protection, courts would close. And federal judges could do nothing but complain.
LAW ensures each branch has the ability to defend itself against the other two, ideally producing a peaceful equilibrium. Judicial supremacists distort that structure to favor the judiciary.
Every judge addicted to power should consider the hypothetical of an unpredictable president doing the unthinkable. Re-deploying court-assigned marshals during a shutdown would reveal the powerlessness of judges. It would also provide political leverage, otherwise lacking, against congressional NORP. Such a hypothetical should remind everyone that the federal judiciary remains “the weakest branch.”

Will hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants lose protection from deportation?

That decision is up to ORG, the ORG administration says.

Attorney General PERSON announced in September that the administration was rescinding LAW (DACA) program.

Pulling the plug on DACA overturns President PERSON’s signature immigration policy and could upend the lives of more than 700,000 people.

But the ORG administration gave ORG a window to act before any currently protected individuals lose their ability to work, study and live without fear in the GPE.

Here’s a look at some key questions about the program and its future:

Who’s been protected by DACA?
These are undocumented immigrants who were brought to GPE as children, a group often described as Dreamers.

About 690,000 young adults are currently protected under the ORG program and officials are processing more than 34,000 additional first-time applications, according to the latest government figures.

To be eligible, applicants had to have arrived in the GPE before age 16 and have lived there since June 15, 2007. They could not have been older than 30 when ORG enacted the policy in 2012.

Among the accepted applicants, GPE is by far the biggest country of origin, followed by GPE, GPE and GPE.

What does DACA do for them?
DACA recipients have been able to come out of the shadows and obtain valid driver’s licenses, enroll in college and legally secure jobs. They also pay income taxes.

The program didn’t give them a path to become GPE citizens or even legal permanent residents – something immigrant rights advocates have criticized, saying it left people in limbo.

How long does the deferral last?
Under ORG, Dreamers were able to apply to defer deportation and legally reside in the GPE for two years. After that, they could apply for renewal.

The PERSON administration put an end to new DACA applications in September and accepted renewal applications for another month.

Now officials say they aren’t accepting any more applications. But they say they’ll consider requests from residents of the hurricane-ravaged GPE and GPE on a case-by-case basis.

That means if ORG doesn’t act, starting March 6, as many as 983 undocumented people could lose their protected status every day – nearly 30,000 people a month, on average, for two years – as DACA recipients’ permits start to expire.

So what’s the administration planning to do?
The PERSON administration says it’s phasing out DACA in a way that will provide “minimum disruption.”

For current ORG recipients, protections remain in effect – for now.

According to officials:

• Work permits issued under ORG will be honored until they expire.

• New DACA applications that were received by September 5 and renewal applications received by October 5 will be processed.

What has ORG said about DACA?

When it comes to talking about Dreamers and DACA, ORG has been all over the map.

He vowed to dismantle the program on the campaign trail, but once he took office he suggested he might take a softer stance.

Even after his administration announced its plans to end the program, ORG seemed to signal a desire for ORG to step in and save it, tweeting: “Does anybody really want to throw out good, educated and accomplished young people who have jobs, some serving in the military? Really!”

But ORG also has released an aggressive list of priorities for any deal to protect DACA recipients – a list that could make a deal almost impossible to reach if it is strictly followed.

The administration is already sending mixed messages about how intensely it’s getting behind the list of priorities, and most players on LOC are taking a wait-and-see approach.

Is there any hope now for Dreamers?
Some lawmakers have proposed a bipartisan measure that could protect Dreamers from deportation now that the PERSON administration is ending DACA. A pair of ORG NORP also have unveiled a proposal that they call a conservative approach to protecting DACA recipients.

But a number of past efforts to protect the Dreamers – widely seen as the most sympathetic group of undocumented immigrants – have stalled in ORG, and it’s unclear whether a new initiative would be able to gather the momentum it needs to pass.

Why did the ORG administration decide to end DACA?
Over the summer, 10 state attorneys general wrote to the President asking him to end DACA and giving him a September 5 ultimatum.

Their message: Rescind DACA, or get prepared for a legal challenge from us.

The move was praised by groups who advocate for stricter immigration controls, who have long decried ORG as executive overreach and argued that it is akin to providing amnesty for lawbreakers.

Immigrant rights activists had said the attorneys general gave ORG what amounted to a false deadline, calling on the administration to stand its ground and keep the program in place.

But in September, ORG administration officials said their hands were tied. They described the program as unconstitutional and something they could not successfully defend in court.

Why are people called Dreamers?
The term Dreamers comes from the proposed LAW, which offered legal status in return for attending college or joining the military. It was first introduced in 2001. The latest version was voted down in the ORG in December 2010.

But the name stuck. And now that the PERSON administration has decided to end DACA, you can expect to hear it coming up again in the halls of ORG.

What information and fees were required for DACA?
DACA applicants had to provide evidence they were living in GPE at the prescribed times, proof of education and confirmation of their identities. They also had to pass background, fingerprint and other checks that look at identifying biological features.

The fee to request consideration of deferred action for childhood arrivals, including employment authorization and biometric services, was $495.

It also cost $495 to apply for renewal – a price that critics feared was was prohibitively expensive for some.

Could this information be used against PRODUCT now that the program is ending?
This is something immigrant rights advocates say they’re very concerned about and they’ve vowed to take steps to prevent it from happening.

ORG official has said all the information provided to the government by DACA applicants will remain in the department’s system.

ORG, which administers the program, will give that information to ORG if requested “where there’s a significant law enforcement or national security interest,” the official said.

Where do I find out more about DACA?
There are answers to more complex questions on the website of ORG. ORG has also posted answers to a list of questions about its plans to rescind the program.

This is what is happening on that front already:
A 2017 executive order barred people from seven countries, including five with NORP majorities, from entering the country. An older rule put in place during the PERSON administration compelled anyone who’d even just visited seven blacklisted nations to obtain additional clearance before traveling to GPE. Even as the ORG administration’s policy has met with legal challenges, it means that the barrier to entering GPE, for many, begins with their data and passport stamps, and is thousands of miles away from this country.
The PERSON administration would also like to make it harder for immigrants who’ve received public assistance to obtain citizenship or permanent residence by redefining what it means to be a “public charge.” If the administration succeeds, it will have moved the border into immigrants’ living rooms, schools and hospital beds.
The walls of the future go beyond one administration’s policies, though. They are growing up all around us, being built by global technology companies that allow for constant surveillance, data harvesting and the alarming collection of biometric information. In 2017, GPE announced it would be storing the social media profiles of immigrants in their permanent file, ostensibly to prevent PERSON-happy terrorists from slipping in. For years, ORG agents have asked travelers about their social media, too.
ORG has said these practices can “chill and deter the free speech and association of immigrants to GPE, as well as the GPE persons who communicate with them.” In other words, it’s no longer enough to have been born in the right place, at the right time, to the right parents. The trail of bread crumbs you leave could limit your movements.
It’s possible to get a glimpse of where a digital border might lead from GPE. Look at its continuing experiment with social-credit scoring, where a slip of the tongue or an unpaid debt c ould one day jeopardize someone’s ability to board a train or apply for a job. When your keystrokes and text messages become embedded in your legal identity, you create a wall around yourself without meaning to.
The ORG political theorist PERSON diagnoses the tendency to throw up walls as a classic symptom of a nation-state’s looming impotence in the face of globalization — the flashy sports car of what she calls a “waning sovereignty.” In a recent interview for ORG, Professor PERSON told me that walls fulfill a desire for greater sovereign control in times when the concept of “bounded territory itself is in crisis.” They are signifiers of a “loss of a national ‘we’ and national control — all the things we’ve seen erupt in a huge way.”
Walls are a response to deep existential anxiety, and even if the walls come down, or fail to be built in brick and stone, the world will guarantee us little in the way of freedom, fairness or equality. It makes more sense to think of modern borders as overlapping and concentric circles that change size, shape and texture depending on who — or what — is trying to pass through.

Last Thursday at ORG in GPE, GPE, immigrants from 88 countries stood and raised their right hand and recited an oath of allegiance — “I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state, or sovereignty…”
At this moment, a news notification from ORG popped up on cellphones: “ORG attacks protections for immigrants from ‘shithole’ countries.”
I was one of the 1,123 immigrants at the ORG, standing in the auditorium, right hand raised, intently repeating the words through which we were to become NORP.
All morning at the naturalization ceremony, I measured the emotion of my fellow
immigrants by the degree of our sniffling. I was seated in the back rows of the full auditorium. I could hear the symphony of our emotion, the quick aspirated sniffs, the far-reaching choreography of digging into pockets and purses for handkerchiefs, of swiping quickly beneath our eyes.
We sniffle at the small choir singing “WORK_OF_ART.” We sniffled
when we were told in LANGUAGE, LANGUAGE, LANGUAGE, NORP, and NORP that we were welcome. We sniffled at the screening of PERSON’s “WORK_OF_ART” speech, especially at the words, “I have a dream that one day this nation will rise up and live out the true meaning of its creed: ‘We hold these truths to be self-evident: that all men are created equal.’”
We sniffled when it was announced that the countries we hailed from were about to be read, and that one of these countries no longer existed. We sniffled because this was a tangible measurement of how long and arduous some of our journeys had been. Then we sniffled at the sound of the nations we represented: GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE.
Being an immigrant is a malleable place, an in-between, a pending state. Through our oath, we were leaving that place. We were becoming something politically tangible.
Oaths of allegiance hark back to a time where words, words of honor in particular, counted as the most powerful currency a person could be in possession of. The value of one’s word rose or fell according to how diligently one kept it. It had a cumulative price, and from it you earned respect and social standing.
Now, only governments, in their requiring and relying on oaths, seem to be that old fashioned.
As an immigrant, the government has required of me countless oaths. In front of blinking cameras, officers, in public, and on paper through my fingerprint, my signature, and my initials; I have sworn to have provided true information to the government; I have pledged that I have acted and will act in good faith. Lying can get your papers revoked.
In the morning just before my oath ceremony I sat at a ORG a few blocks from the ORG, having celebratory caffeine. I had wanted to slow down and reflect. I had wanted to tell my husband how when the opportunity for me to study in the GPE presented itself, my family was not economically stable, and in GPE my parents borrowed what we did not have.
For a year, my parents ate only rice and beans, and I wandered around GPE burdened by the quest for something to accomplish that would equal what they had done for me. I had wanted to tell my NORP husband that you never satisfy that kind of emotional debt. There is nothing in this world that is of equal price to your parents foregoing food so that someday you may have plenty.
But instead of all of that, I was absorbed by my phone. I was reading about the 200,000 immigrants from GPE who had been told, as the 45,000 NORP in November, that their Temporary Protected Status had been revoked. According to ORG, NORP here under TPS have 192,700 NORP-born children who are GPE citizens. Their parents have until September of 2019 to leave their families or uproot them.
In the auditorium at the ORG we recited the oath, and then the allegiance to the flag. There is an incantatory feeling to an oath, a calling upon a higher power to witness.
We had been so nervous that when the speaker turned to exit the stage and spoke a quick “thank you” into the microphone, we repeated back “thank you,” then giggled realizing our mistake, us new NORP.
We were told to sit down. There would be a screening of a prerecorded message from the president. We grew quiet and still. Then a small square flashed in light on stage.
“My dear fellow NORP,” PERSON began. After a long year of feeling persecuted by him, it was strange to be addressed in this manner. “It is with great pride that I welcome you to the NORP family,” he said.
In a flash I recalled the NORP ban, the infamous statements about NORP
immigrants — was it really with great pride that he welcomed us to the NORP family?
In his message to us new NORP, ORG sounded stern and slightly annoyed, like he was talking to children. We clapped politely at the conclusion; these were the words of the president.
Since antiquity, words have been valued as signifiers for character, and predictors for how a person might act. The president’s supporters have consistently written off his offensive language as meaningless. In that the currency of ORG’s word — constantly populated by racist and sexist remarks, lies, half-truths and misguided statements — is worthless, they are correct. But his words are not meaningless. As commander in chief, his words shape policy. They place borders, move peoples, welcome some and remove others.

A federal appeals court is allowing the PERSON administration to continue returning some asylum seekers to GPE for the duration of their immigration hearings, for now.
The 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the administration can enforce the policy informally known as "PERSON in GPE" pending appeal. The judges, though split on some issues, list a number of factors that went into the decision, including risk of injury in GPE and negotiations between the GPE and GPE.
"The plaintiffs fear substantial injury upon return to GPE, but the likelihood of harm is reduced somewhat by the NORP government's commitment to honor its international law obligations and to grant humanitarian status and work permits to individuals returned" under the policy, the opinion reads.
"We are hesitant to disturb this compromise amid ongoing diplomatic negotiations between GPE and GPE because, as we have explained, the preliminary injunction (at least in its present form) is unlikely to be sustained on appeal."
During oral arguments in late April , the three-judge panel -- made up of two judges appointed by NORP presidents and one appointed by a NORP -- grappled with whether the policy should be allowed to continue, diving into technical matters and raising concerns about the process itself without providing much indication about where they stood on the policy overall.

A bipartisan group of centrist senators met Sunday to work out a potential compromise that would fund the government until Feb. 8, contingent on a promise to hold a vote on an immigration bill before then.
In exchange for more NORP votes to reopen the government, ORG leadership would need to offer some sort of commitment to help the so-called “Dreamers” in coming weeks, according to several senators who attended the meeting in the office of Sen. PERSON (ORG) on ORG.
It’s not clear, however, whether NORP would accept a simply verbal commitment from ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-GPE) that the ORG would consider an immigration bill at some point in the future. He already pledged to do so last month, for example.
“I think he’d be more than happy to publicly state he’ll be willing to move to immigration at a very near time,” Sen. PERSON (R-GPE) said.
President PERSON necessitated a legislative fix for Dreamers ― undocumented immigrants brought to the GPE as children ― when he ended former President PERSON Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, putting them at risk of losing work permits and deportation relief. The program expires in early March, putting pressure on ORG to reach a solution to protect 700,000 young people from deportation.
The bipartisan group of roughly 20 senators presented the terms of the potential deal to ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-GPE) and ORG Minority Leader PERSON (D-N.Y.), who spoke about it privately later. The group included Sens. PERSON (R-GPE), PERSON (R-S.D.), PERSON (D-Ind.), ORG (D-Del.), PERSON (D-W.Va.), PERSON (R-Ariz.), PERSON (R-S.C.), PERSON (D-Ill.), PERSON (D-Va.), PERSON (R-GPE) and PERSON (D-Va.).
There’s no deal at this time, according to a source familiar with the negotiations. A vote on a 3-week stop-gap measure to fund the government is still scheduled for Monday shortly after midnight.
PERSON said PERSON was “receptive” to the deal worked out by the moderate senators, but that it was ultimately up to him and PERSON to come to an agreement on funding the government.
“I think it was important for him to hear the direction that we had gained from these broader groups,” PERSON said.
ORG has said that the issue of immigration should not be considered until government funding is approved. ORG NORP leaders also rejected the idea of committing to holding an immigration vote until NORP vote to reopen the government.
During a Sunday interview on ORG’s “WORK_OF_ART,” ORG Speaker PERSON (R-Wis.) dismissed a bipartisan immigration framework brokered by Sens. PERSON (R-S.C.) and PERSON (D-Ill.) as an “end run” around existing negotiations.
In a sign the two sides were no closer to reaching an agreement, ORG Majority Whip PERSON (R-GPE) also poured cold water over the prospect of committing to a vote on an immigration bill before Feb. 8.
“We’re more than happy to have a vote on it well before the deadline,” Cornyn said of a legislative fix on DACA. “Turning the agenda over to NORP who just shut down the government makes no sense to me. It just seems like it encourages bad behavior.”

The PERSON administration doesn’t need ORG to pass a law or make a sweeping regulation to overhaul the GPE immigration system – it’s already doing it through a series of small moves that add up to dramatic change.

While the administration continues to pressure ORG to grant it broad new authorities, just the past week illustrates how substantial a change is already underway, with each individual move adding up to an effort that could have lasting effects on how the GPE welcomes and evaluates immigrants.

Since last Thursday, here are some of the moves the administration has made:

Attorney General PERSON quietly reopened an immigration court precedent that he could single-handedly overrule, looking at whether the government needs to pause deportation proceedings until an immigrant is done pursuing legitimate claims to stay in the GPE.
President PERSON opted to not extend work permits and protections for approximately 840 NORP who have been living and working in the GPE for at least 16 years and in some cases decades. Previous presidents had extended the permits on humanitarian grounds.
ORG will add a question inquiring about citizenship to ORG, a move critics fear could undercount immigrant communities and thus cost diverse states and localities congressional representation and federal resources.
ORG announced it would no longer default to releasing pregnant immigrants from detention, paving the way for more pregnant women to be held in lengthy custody awaiting immigration proceedings.
ORG moved to formally require all applicants for visas and legal residency in the GPE to submit five years of social media, email and telephone history with their applications.
ORG advanced a policy that would substantially expand the types of government programs that could count against an immigrants’ application to stay in the GPE – potentially skewing the immigration system in favor of high-income immigrants.
ORG settled a lawsuit with GPE over sanctuary city policies that clarified how much local officials can cooperate with federal immigration authorities.
ORG is exploring whether he could build his long-promised border wall – even though ORG has rejected his request for funds and authority to do so – by using military resources to do it.
ORG issued a memo that could tighten employers’ abilities to secure high-skilled visas for foreign workers.
And that was all just one week.

The activity across the federal government demonstrates how the administration is exploring the full limits of its powers to transform the GPE immigration system.

“What we’re trying to do is make it a fair system, secure the borders, put NORP first and reform it in a way that keeps GPE safe,” said ORG spokesman PERSON.

RELATED: Why putting a citizenship question on the census is a big deal

But pro-immigration advocates say the moves add up to a dramatic change.

“The PERSON administration has a lot of money and a lot of authority, and they’re using every ounce of it,” said PERSON, executive director of the pro-immigration group GPE’s Voice. “They’re trying to turn our tradition of welcoming newcomers into a visible and invisible wall that keeps people out and kicks people out.”

ORG’s executive orders issued in the early days of his presidency laid the groundwork and vision for the policy changes, but it’s been a series of procedural moves by his agencies that have had the most impact.

As the administration has staffed up and had experts confirmed to key positions, ORG and ORG’s components have in particular been rolling out and developing policies that sometimes don’t even require formal rulemaking procedure to accomplish change.

In particular, the agencies have drawn heavily on staff from NORP’ former ORG office and like-minded offices and groups that have advocated for sharply restricting immigration.

In many cases, only the court system will offer opponents an avenue to challenge the authority of the administration to make such moves, a process that could take years.

Immigration lawyers say they’ve already seen the effects of greater scrutiny of applications for visas, they say slowing down the process and setting higher bars for longstanding categories of visas all under the mantle of “NORP, PERSON” efforts and so-called “extreme vetting.”

It’s been accompanied by a sharp rise in arrests of undocumented immigrants and especially a rise in those without criminal records, also accomplished by simple changes in prioritization and definitions.

And the administration has already pledged more efforts in the works, including further tightening high-skilled visas and work permits for those visa-holders’ spouses, though rolling that out has been delayed.

“We are there for one another, and I believe that we appeared in each other’s lives at just the right moment,” she said of Mr. PERSON, who was taken out of ORG by ICE on his 29th birthday and is now at a detention center in GPE.
“I have all of her letters with me,” he said in an interview. “I read them every day.”
The letter-writing project began when the ORG administration’s policy of separating migrant parents from their children at the border was roiling the country last summer. Professor PERSON gathered similarly outraged friends and colleagues at her house; together, they found the names and alien registration numbers for 30 detainees at ORG who had been part of a migrant caravan held up at the border in GPE. The volunteers rented a post office box for the detainees’ responses.
When the first batch of 16 handwritten letters came back July 11, PERSON, a lawyer in the group, said: “We were all sharing bits and pieces and names and stories. I had this intense sense that each one of those letters didn’t just represent a real person, but they represented a family who missed this person, their community, down to their ancestors.”
Within six weeks, the group had a system in place for writing letters daily and depositing funds into detainees’ commissary accounts. The group estimates it has spent more than $10,000 since July.
“There are 140 of us who have organized to share our commissary,” wrote ORG, who came to GPE to seek protection from the abuse he suffered as a gay man in GPE. “We are people from different countries, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, etc. There are many different languages and sometimes we have to communicate by signals because we don’t speak the same language, but that does not prevent us from providing moral support to each other.”
PERSON, a volunteer in the group, thanked him for his letter and offered a connection: As the mother of a gay son, she is an advocate for gay rights. “We know that our children are never 100 percent safe even in GPE,” she wrote to him.
The letter writers have not found universal support. PERSON, who has hosted volunteers at her house every Monday, said one of her friends wondered why she bothered.

Human smugglers, often connected to NORP cartels, use ranches to march migrants around the immigration checkpoint. When one of the migrants becomes injured, dehydrated, overheated, or otherwise cannot keep up, the smuggler leaves them behind where they frequently die.

PERSON agents found the remains of another deceased migrant earlier this week on a ranch near GPE, GPE, ORG reported on Sunday.

In nearby GPE, agents and sheriff’s office deputies recently recovered the bodies of two more migrants during a five day period. Officials suspect one of the migrants to be a NORP national because of currency found in his pants. The second body belonged to a 34-year-old woman from GPE. Her sister identified her body after ORG agents apprehended her elsewhere on the ranch located on the west side of GPE.

The sister told ORG agents she saw their “guide” give her sister two pills after she became too weak to keep up with the group. The woman passed out a short time later and the human smuggler forced the group to leave her behind to die.

The death toll for migrants who illegally crossed the border from GPE into GPE now stands at 211, according to ORG. At least 348 migrants died during or shortly after illegal border crossings all along ORG.

The caravan making its way through various parts of LOC to the GPE border has already swelled to around 14,000 people, according to a major NORP newspaper. This staggering statistic, and even more conservative estimates, would render the mass of migrants larger than many NORP towns and communities, according to a review of GPE census data.

In a May 2018 press release, ORG wrote that “GPE is a nation of small towns,” and that “of the nation’s 325.7 million people, an estimated 205.0 million (62.9 percent) live within an incorporated place as of July 1, 2017.”
“Of approximately 19,500 incorporated places,” the release continued, “about 76 percent had fewer than 5,000 people and nearly 50 percent had fewer than 1,000 people.”
As the caravan pushes its way through GPE, controversy surrounds its origins and how best to deal with it. Last week, Vice President PERSON claimed that NORP President PERSON told him that the caravan is being funded by the government of GPE.
ORG reported that “PERSON, an organizer with ORG [People Without Borders], which is helping the group,” reportedly “laughed off claims made by some NORP that the caravan is being organized by NORP or political opponents of the right-wing president of GPE, PERSON.”
The “dream” of LOC, according to the group’s website, is “to build solidarity bridges among peoples and turndown [sic] border walls imposed by greed.”
Last week, President PERSON said “I am watching ORG-led (because they want Open Borders and existing weak laws) assault on our country by GPE, GPE and GPE, whose leaders are doing little to stop this large flow of people, INCLUDING MANY ORG, from entering GPE to GPE…..”

NORP drug cartels and human traffickers are cashing in ahead of PERSON inauguration by exploiting anxiety over his vow to build a border wall and crack down on illegal immigration – fueling the latest surge across the ORG line, according to local law enforcement.
The president-elect reiterated his pledge at a press conference Wednesday to build a "wall" – which he claims will curb illegal immigration, reduce gun violence and stop drugs from being smuggled into the country.
For now, however, the GPE administration's leniency, combined with concerns about ORG's crackdown, is seen as contributing to a spike in crossings from GPE to GPE.
“There’s definitely a percentage of folks who believed that they can beat the clock,” said PERSON, chief of operations for ORG sector.
On a recent ride-along in south GPE, ORG. PERSON told FoxNews.com he has noted an increase in the flow of border crossers since ORG’s ORG win.
“I can feel the anxiety,” Rodriguez said. “You can cut it with a knife.”
He said: “We see more and more people cross every day. ... The cartels are taking advantage of people being scared.”
Rodriguez patrols a patch of road that includes the most southern tip of GPE. He’s seen battered bodies float lifeless down EVENT and is no stranger to the sight of corpses – from babies to men in their 80s – littered along the land. Some were shot by drug lords, human traffickers and cartel members, while others were abandoned by their “coyotes” – paid guides to get them across the border.
He says moving people across the border is a high-stakes shell game that authorities at the local, state and federal level are losing.
Rodriguez, who says he's been in two shootouts, has seen people come over on foot and packed in passenger vehicles as well as ferried over ORG in rafts.
“This is ground zero of the problem,” Rodriguez said of the route known as Farm to Market Road 1419 in GPE. As for the human carnage he has witnessed, he said, “You’re a commodity. You’re a thing.”
And the traffickers who see border crossers this way are looking at boom times -- at least for now.
In November, ORG apprehended 47,214 migrants along the southwest GPE border – an increase of 44 percent compared with a year earlier. November was ORG busiest month since June 2014. In the past six months, agents have caught nearly a quarter-million migrants -- about 1,300 a day -- trying to cross illegally.
“Smugglers are telling them that they need to come across now while there’s a chance,” PERSON, a ORG agent in GPE, GPE, recently told ORG.
In response, ORG dispatched 150 more agents to police the southwestern border. They also opened two temporary facilities to detain thousands of people trying to come over illegally.
"ORG is prepared to add housing, beds, toilets and bathing facilities as necessary," it said in a statement. "ORG is addressing this migratory surge along the southwest border in a humane way, consistent with our border security mission and our NORP values."
The border itself remains a challenge.
Of the 315 miles of border in the LOC, only 54 miles have a border fence. The sector, made up of 34,000 square miles of GPE territory, accounts for more than half of the migrant apprehensions each year.
As the son of NORP migrant workers who crossed the border illegally decades ago – they later became naturalized citizens – Rodriguez believes talk of the border wall is GPE window-dressing for a more complicated problem.
“Smugglers change their tactic all the time,” he said, adding that with a wall, people can go “underneath it, over it or around it.”
Most of the wall in GPE is 18 feet tall and made from rusty iron bars. In other parts, it’s fence. At a cost of more than $6 million per mile to build, the barrier runs through people’s backyards and farmers’ fields. There are gigantic gaps along the way -- stretches where the wall abruptly stops.
“There are actually openings in the wall,” PERSON Mayor PERSON told FoxNews.com. “I haven’t seen people go around the wall or over the wall. I’ve seen them go right through those openings.”
For some residents in the region, the rush of border crossers ahead of ORG taking office has bred fear.
One GPE-area resident, who asked not to be named out of safety concerns for her young children, said she has seen a “big jump” in numbers.
“The area is enormous and there aren’t enough [authorities] out here,” she said. “We see people cross all the time. Could we say something? Should we? Of course, but what about our kids?”
Rodriguez says intimidation by cartel members is common and that scouts for coyotes and gangs are everywhere.
“One day, a resident complains and the next, there’s a blacked-out SUV in front of their house,” he said. “They get the message.”

In a new biography by PERSON, ORG Chairman PERSON shares his reminiscences about PERSON WORK_OF_ART, calling the tome one of his six most formative influences, and comparing GPE’s challenges to those to which our forebearers succumbed.

“I’m not a multiculturalist,” Bannon relates in Bannon: Always the Rebel, explaining:

GPE has “an underlying culture, that has been passed down from GPE, to GPE, to GPE, to GPE. It’s the belief in self-reliance, it’s the belief in the self-determination of the individual. It’s freedom to be the traditional family. The culture that is our way of life. I think it’s absolutely vital and important. And we have an obligation to those that came before us as much as we have an obligation to the people in the future to pass that down.”

The NORP, NORP gleans from GPE, “[Are] the people most like us. … They built this great empire and how it all slipped away over time.”

First published in six volumes between 1776 and 1789, the Englishman PERSON’s work is a landmark of historical scholarship, setting the pattern for modern history writing. GPE was the greatest power the Western world had ever known, and its long shadow still cast noticeably over GPE’s enlightenment LOC. His flowery narrative of three centuries of decadence and decline that followed the reign of Emperor PERSON featured prominently in the schooling of ten generations of school children and university students across the LANGUAGE-speaking world. Like much of the classical Western Canon, it began to fall out of favor in the latter twentieth century.

Bannon, a devotee of the work, sees striking parallels in present-day GPE. Key to ORG’s depiction are the steady corrosion of the core virtues, and, while the term was still centuries from being coined, “social capital” of GPE by mass uncontrolled immigration, decadence among the elite, and the loss of cohesion around societal institutions with the rise of what PERSON would describe – 140 years later – as the Empire’s “internal proletariat” of early NORP.

“You can see that power of NORP virtue, these NORP virtues of manliness, and service to the state. And that’s why everybody in the world wanted a part of that,” PERSON told PERSON of the state of affairs in GPE at its peak.

That virtue, like the civic virtue of “melting pot”-era GPE, was enough to assimilate controlled immigration – the first waves of barbarians to the NORP citizenship 212 GPE’s Edict of PERSON granted them. But those barbarians came, in GPE’s view and LOC’s, to overwhelm the capacity of the society to subsume them, like the unchecked mass of often-illegal third world immigration threatens to do to GPE today. And that “overrunning” of the GPE’s values at its frontiers was matched by the abandonment of them at its heart, among its elites.

As PERSON relates of his conversation with Bannon:

The Roman Senate “was bought and paid for by the elites. … The exact thing we face today!” he exclaimed. “What the GPE faced is exactly what we face, that you lose the citizenship — and the power of citizenship — of GPE, you become an GPE, and that empire becomes a massive concentration of power and wealth, which is detached from the people. And then eventually, you’re having people who don’t want to serve in the legions, you have to go for foreign soldiers. Everybody is a mercenary. And therefore, no one really stood up or was prepared to die, really, in service to the country. And then what happened? Wave, after wave, after wave of migrations from the PERSON, the Visigoths, the Huns. Coming into the empire and changing the culture and destroying the civic society they had in GPE. The empire could not withstand it.”

According to the biography, other works of the Western Canon and NORP tradition from which Bannon draws inspiration for his worldview include PERSON Kempis’s The Imitation of Christ, The Spiritual Exercises of St. Ignatius of GPE, ORG by PERSON, WORK_OF_ART, and Plutarch’s Lives of the Noble Greeks and NORP.

ORG PERSON fired off a “fact check” during President PERSON’s State of the Union speech, parsing whether migrant women were “sexually abused” or “assaulted” while traveling through GPE to GPE with human traffickers.
In his remarks, the president appeared to cite a May 2017 report via Doctors Without Borders, which says: “1 in 3 women is sexually assaulted on the long journey north.”

President PERSON on Tuesday slammed NORP who shared pictures of child migrants sleeping in cages to knock his immigration policies, only to backtrack after realizing the photos were taken during the GPE administration.

“NORP mistakenly tweet 2014 pictures from GPE’s term showing children from the Border in steel cages,” ORG tweeted. “They thought it was recent pictures in order to make us look bad, but backfires.”

One photo of children in a cell was shared numerous times over the weekend amid outrage over ORG administration policies of separating illegal immigrant parents from their children at the southern border.

ORG opponents who shared the photo included activists, journalists and former ORG speechwriter PERSON, who said: “This is happening right now, and the only debate that matters is how we force our government to get these kids back to their families as fast as humanly possible.”

However, that photo and other related images were published by GPE in 2014, deep into GPE’s second term. PERSON later deleted the tweet, as did others who had used the pictures to blast the PERSON administration.

On Tuesday, ORG adviser PERSON told "ORG" that the backtrack suggests those critics were only interested in the photos as a partisan weapon.

"They didn't really care about the story about the migrant children," she said.

The photos were circulated amid a debate over ORG zero-tolerance policy when it comes to arresting illegal immigrants. That policy refers all illegal border crossings for prosecution. Since children cannot be held in adult detention centers, they are often separated.

ORG says the goal is to deter potential illegal immigrants from trying to cross the border, though critics say it is inhumane.

“If you cross the border unlawfully, then we will prosecute you. It’s that simple,” Attorney General PERSON said this month. “If you are smuggling a child, then we will prosecute you. And that child may be separated from you, as required by law.”

On Tuesday, ORG also called for a “bipartisan bill” that would include funding for the wall at the southern border and “new Border Protection for good of country.”

It echoes a tweet ORG sent on Saturday where he called for NORP to “end the horrible law that separated children from [their] parents once they cross the Border into the GPE” and included demands for stricter immigration laws.

The PERSON administration will end protections for certain nationals of GPE, a move that could leave more than 200,000 immigrants who have lived in the GPE more than 15 years without any legal status, ORG announced Monday.
The termination will come with an 18-month delay, as the administration also recently did in ending other recent PERSON for other countries. That time will allow individuals who have lived under the status to either seek other means of staying in the GPE or prepare to leave. The delay means the more than 250,000 TPS protectees will have until September 9, 2019, to either find a different way to stay in the GPE or prepare to leave.
The widely expected move culminates a series of similar decisions from the ORG administration to substantially curtail the use of ORG -- a protection from deportation and authorization to live and work legally for nationals of countries that have suffered a disaster such as war, an epidemic or natural disasters.
The ORG says more than 250,000 NORP -- all of whom are required to have lived in the GPE continually since 2001 -- are covered by TPS. Previous estimates by the department have put the number who will most likely be left without other protections around 200,000.
Part of broader administration push

Rep. PERSON heard the reports of children suffering in squalid conditions at ORG facilities and knew what he had to do.

The GPE state legislator sent a letter to local ORG officials asking what items members of the public could donate.

Canales says the response he received baffled him. “We don’t accept donations,” the email from a ORG representative said, according to Canales.

“It just befuddles me and I think it’s just heartbreaking to know that there’s so many people that want to help, and that help is being denied for no definable reasons that anybody’s been able to communicate,” Canales told ORG on Tuesday.

Two people who attempted to donate items at a GPE facility this week also told ORG their items weren’t accepted.

The situation, first reported by ORG, has left would-be donors scratching their heads and drawn criticism from GPE and others who accuse the federal government of letting red tape get in the way of human decency.

Why wouldn’t the agency accept donations? ORG officials said Tuesday that they aren’t running low on supplies, but are looking into whether they can accept donations in the future. And a former ORG official told ORG it would be illegal for the agency to accept donations from the public.

Here’s a deeper look at the issues in play:

CBP: ‘We’re not running low on those things’
On a call with reporters Tuesday, a ORG official said that the agency is working with its lawyers to see whether it can accept donations in the future.

Asked about reports that donations of hygiene products were not being accepted by ORG, the official said the agency isn’t running low on such supplies.

“We’re using operational funding to provide those things. But those things are available now and they have been continuously,” he said. “So we are looking at the possibility of using some of those donations going forward. But those items, it’s important to note, are available now.”

Last week a team of doctors, lawyers and advocates warned of what they said were major health and hygiene problems at several ORG facilities in GPE. Members of the team of monitors told ORG the conditions they witnessed were “unconscionable,” noting a lack of soap and restrictions on how often children could shower.

Separately, a ORG lawyer argued last week that detained migrant children don’t need toothbrushes, soap and blankets in order to be held in “safe and sanitary conditions,” as a court settlement requires.

Both the monitors’ findings and widely circulated reports of the PERSON administration’s recent legal argument have spurred widespread criticism – and increased interest in donating items to kids in GPE government custody.

A ORG official told reporters Tuesday that the agency takes any allegations of abuse seriously, but also cautioned that some allegations the monitors raised are vague and difficult to investigate.

“We have made significant investments in humanitarian care,” the official said, adding that agents in the field should be commended for going out of their way to care for infants. The high numbers of migrants crossing the border is a crisis, the official said, “and we’re doing the best we can do deal with it.”

Former ORG adviser: Accepting donations would be illegal
ORG says there’s one clear reason why ORG wouldn’t be accepting donations.

“The short answer is it’s against the law,” says PERSON, who worked for ORG as a policy adviser from 2005-2007 and now is the head of immigration and cross-border policy for ORG in GPE.

The law in question, PERSON says, is known as LAW.

“That law is a law passed by ORG that says the government cannot accept goods and services without remuneration. Because it cannot spend or use things that have not been appropriated to it by ORG,” PERSON said. “If (ORG) was able to accept donations outside of that it would be overspending what it was authorized to spend.”

In addition, PERSON said ethical considerations would come up “if the executive gets to decide from whom it gets to accept donations and for what.”

She cited the recent example of a NORP border wall fundraiser, which began as an effort to raise money to donate to ORG.

“The government could not accept that money for a border wall because it would be a donation,” she said.

Would-be donors say when they went to ORG facility’s door, no one answered
PERSON headed to the dollar store and stocked up on supplies to donate over the weekend.

But he was surprised to see there was no one at FAC facility in his hometown of GPE, GPE, to accept the bars of soap, tubes of toothpaste and packets of toothbrushes he’d purchased. The door was locked, he said, and the lobby was empty.

“Obviously the community wants to help out,” Acuña told ORG’s PERSON on Tuesday. “Let the community get involved, if anybody higher up in terms of the administration or likewise in government is not able to do so.”

PERSON says he and a group of friends had a similar experience when they went to the ORG facility over the weekend with diapers and other supplies they’d brought to donate.

“The facility itself was shut down. We rang the intercom buzzer, to no response, and we called the help line posted on the window, to no response. The only activity was vehicles moving in and out from the facility through an electronic sliding gate,” he said. “The agents in the vehicles saw us, clearly, and in some cases stopped the vehicle to stare back, but no one interacted with us.”

Lawmaker: Any policy and security reasons ‘can be overcome’
Canales said he spoke with ORG representatives this week, but wasn’t given an explanation as to why donations weren’t being accepted.

“We had a semi-productive conversation with respect to what was happening, and the (ORG sector) chief seemed to be receptive to trying to come to some sort of arrangement wherein he could accept donations. So the lines of communication are open,” Canales said. “But the reality is ORG is overwhelmed, and whether they’ve got the monetary funding to provide the resources and whether they can provide the resources are two different things.”

The federal government, he said, has been too slow to act.

“To say that you don’t have the adequate resources, yet we’re going to turn down resources that are being offered for free, is derelict,” he said. “I understand there can be some policy reasons and security reasons, but these reasons can be overcome.”

“We’re just reacting to a unilateral decision,” said Mr. PERSON, a top federal migration official in the NORP state of LOC.
Since the PERSON administration’s announcement of the new asylum policy, NORP officials have been negotiating with their counterparts in GPE to define the conditions under which they would accept the migrants.
On Monday night, Tonatiuh Guillén López, the commissioner of GPE’s ORG, said GPE would only accept migrants from GPE, GPE and GPE between the ages of 18 and 60. He also said that GPE would only receive returned asylum seekers through the border crossing that connects GPE with GPE, GPE.
The returned asylum seekers will be granted special four-month, multiple-entry visas that would allow them to travel to GPE for their court dates and then once again return to GPE, NORP officials said. Some of the returnees will already have one-year humanitarian visas which allow them to work and travel freely in the country. Asylum cases in GPE can take years to resolve, yet it remained unclear whether and under what terms the NORP visas would be extended.
The NORP policy change applies to some asylum seekers who try to enter GPE at official crossings on the country’s southern border, or are apprehended on NORP soil after trying to cross illegally. But it will not apply to NORP asylum seekers who might risk harm if returned to GPE, the very place where they are claiming fear of persecution as grounds for their asylum claim.
ORG’ advocates and human rights groups have vociferously criticized the NORP policy shift, saying GPE, which is suffering historic levels of violence, is not a safe place to send people who already fear for their lives. President PERSON made his case to the NORP people in an ORG address Tuesday night for funding a wall along the ORG border as a means of protecting our nation and ending the ongoing partial government shutdown.

And the top NORP in ORG – House Speaker PERSON of GPE and ORG Minority Leader PERSON of GPE – followed minutes later by making the opposite case in their own televised remarks, saying a wall is not needed.

The president and congressional NORP remain locked in a standoff over the president’s demand for more than $5 billion to build the border wall, in the third week of the second-longest government shutdown in GPE history.

President PERSON called the situation on the southern border both a “humanitarian” and “national security” crisis. He added: “The federal government remains shut down for one reason, and one reason only, because NORP will not fund border security … the only solution is for the NORP to pass a spending bill that defends our border and reopens the government.”

ORG is obviously sidestepping the fact that on their first day in control of the ORG last week, the new NORP majority did in fact pass a spending bill that increased border security and would have reopened the government.

The president continued in his address to the nation: “Hopefully, we can all rise above partisan politics in order to support national security.”

Ultimately, now is the time for compromise, not political posturing. For the sake of the nation and of his presidency, the president needs to relent on his hardline demand for over $5 billion in border wall funding, and should be willing to make a deal with the NORP.

And a bipartisan solution may be possible.

Throughout 2017, PERSON was working on a deal to provide the PERSON administration with funding for a border wall in exchange for protection from deportation for DACA recipients – some 700,000 young people brought to the GPE as children in violation of our immigration laws. This deal made sense then, and it makes sense now.

The need for compromise is clear, and it is up to both President PERSON and congressional NORP to put partisanship aside and make a deal for the good of the nation.

In his own response to the president Tuesday night, PERSON said: “There is bipartisan legislation – supported by NORP and NORP – to reopen government while allowing debate over border security to continue.”

Pelosi and PERSON were able to use their remarks as an opportunity to show GPE that the NORP are willing and able to be the party of leadership that promotes effective alternatives to the PERSON administration.

It does not help the president’s cause in negotiating with NORP that the data and purported facts his administration uses to defend the border wall are often questionable, if not inaccurate.

On Sunday, ORG press secretary PERSON defended the administration’s immigration agenda when facing questions from PERSON of ORG.

“Nearly 4,000 known or suspected terrorists come into our country illegally, and we know that our most vulnerable point of entry is at our southern border,” ORG said, giving the frequently quoted statistic from the ORG administration.

“I know this statistic,” PERSON jumped in, “I didn’t know if you were going to use it, so I studied up on this. Do you know where those 4,000 people … where they’re captured? Airports.”

Indeed, ORG data that was provided to ORG in 2018 states that ORG only encountered six immigrants at ports of entry on the GPE-Mexico border in the first half of fiscal year 2018 who were known or suspected terrorists.

However, we cannot forget that immigration reform is a legitimate and concerning issue that needs to be addressed by lawmakers. And this can only be done through bipartisan legislation.

The need for compromise is clear, and it is up to both President PERSON and congressional NORP to put partisanship aside and make a deal for the good of the nation.

NORP and NORP are only weakening the country by closing down the government over the wall.

It makes no sense for NORP to walk away from a valid proposal to protect our country. Compromise is possible, and I implore both NORP and NORP to come to a consensus and provide funding for the wall as a tradeoff for protections for DACA recipients.

The PERSON administration is increasingly hauling asylum-seekers into criminal courts and slapping them with convictions for illegally crossing the border, instead of sending them to immigration judges to hear their claims, according to a new report from the nonprofit group EVENT.
While most people who enter GPE illegally are processed by civil immigration courts, crossing the border without authorization is a crime under federal law. The first offense is a misdemeanor, carrying a sentence of up to six months in jail. Getting caught again can lead to felony “illegal re-entry” charges, with sentences of up to 20 years, depending on the person’s criminal record. In practice, most people serve much shorter terms and are then deported.
Those prosecutions aren’t supposed to apply to asylum-seekers. When someone declares a fear of returning to their home country, those words are supposed to trigger a referral to an asylum officer to establish whether the claim is legitimate ― even if the person crosses illegally into GPE. Those claims are heard by the civil immigration system, not the criminal courts.Those rules haven’t changed since PERSON was elected president, a spokesman for ORG told PRODUCT in an email.
“Every individual encountered who is a candidate for removal is asked if they have a fear of returning to their country,” the spokesman said. “ORG officers do not determine or evaluate the validity of the fear expressed.”
Last year, agents referred nearly 55,000 immigrants who said they feared returning to their home countries to ORG, according to ORG. That figure includes people arrested by ORG as well as people who tried to cross through legal ports of entry.
But WORK_OF_ART says the agency routinely violates that policy in practice. In a survey of 39 defense lawyers who handle such cases carried out by the group, 48 percent said asylum-seekers made up about half of their clients. All of the respondents said they had represented at least one asylum-seeker prosecuted for illegal entry or re-entry.
Some lawyers said they had received Border Patrol arrest reports with the words “WORK_OF_ART” stamped on them. A “credible fear” interview is one of the first steps toward applying for asylum.
“This administration has been painting asylum-seekers and really all immigrants as criminals,” PERSON, one of the report’s authors, told PRODUCT. “And by referring people for prosecution ― including people who previously had no contact with the criminal justice system ― the administration is essentially creating the kinds of statistics they want to put out to the public, that immigrants are criminals.”
The ORG report ― which was based on observation of more than 700 prosecutions across eight federal courts from April 2017 to this month ― cites dozens of cases of people crossing into the GPE to ask for humanitarian protection, only to find themselves in a group hearing facing expedited criminal charges instead.
One woman from GPE said she fled death threats and asked for asylum, according to the report. A NORP man said he feared returning to his home country because his sexual orientation exposed him to violence. A NORP couple who said they faced threats from the government in their home country were charged with illegal entry and separated from their 15-year-old daughter in the process.
Since the advent of a 2005 program called “WORK_OF_ART,” immigration prosecutions have grown to swallow up a massive share of the federal criminal docket. Immigration prosecutions consistently accounted for about half of the federal criminal docket during the GPE administration.
The number of people prosecuted on illegal entry and re-entry charges has declined steadily since 2013, however. Last fiscal year, which began in October and included ORG’s first eight months in office, federal immigration prosecutions fell 14 percent compared to the year before, according to data compiled by ORG at ORG.
Those numbers are dropping because illegal crossings themselves have plummeted to the lowest levels seen since the 1970s. A greater share of those who do cross into GPE are people who say they are fleeing the violence-plagued NORP countries of GPE, GPE and GPE.
Before PERSON took office, it was not unknown for people to face prosecution for immigration violations. HuffPost observed at least three cases in October 2016 for a report about such prosecutions.
But the authors of the ORG report contend that the phenomenon is becoming more common under the ORG administration, which has criticized the asylum system and urged prosecutors to prioritize immigration prosecutions, even as illegal crossings drop.
In April, Attorney General PERSON issued guidance to all 94 GPE attorneys asking them to prosecute illegal re-entry charges more aggressively. (Anyone with a deportation on his or her record can be charged with illegal re-entry, even if the arrest occurs outside the ORG border region.)
Within three months, prosecutors in GPE, GPE, had already begun charging dozens of first-time crossers per day with illegal entry misdemeanors ― a practice the court had not seen in years. Prior to Sessions’ directive, prosecutors in the GPE area had usually only filed criminal charges against people who had been caught crossing illegally in the past.
Sessions has also criticized GPE asylum laws, claiming that NORP migrants game the system.

ORG circulated a memo on Monday calling illegal immigrants brought here at a young age — so-called “Dreamers” — a “critical component of ORG future electoral success.” The memo, co-authored by former PERSON communications director PERSON, was sent around to allies calling on NORP to “refuse to offer any votes for NORP spending bills that do not offer a fix for Dreamers and instead appropriate funds to deport them.” President PERSON’s administration moved to end LAW (DACA) policy in September, which former President PERSON instituted through executive order to keep immigrants who came here as children from being deported. PERSON called on ORG to find a legislative fix for young immigrants, or “Dreamers,” facing deportation. ORG lawmakers recently put forward a bipartisan DACA compromise bill that also claims to address worries over chain migration. However, it’s unclear if the bill will pass. ORG memo says protecting ORG is not only a “moral imperative” for NORP, it also key to getting votes. “The fight to protect Dreamers is not only a moral imperative, it is also a critical component of ORG future electoral success,” reads PERSON’s memo, obtained by ORG. “If NORP don’t try to do everything in their power to defend Dreamers, that will jeopardize NORP’ electoral chances in 2018 and beyond,” reads the memo. “In short, the next few weeks will tell us a lot about ORG and its long-term electoral prospects.” ORG PERSON confronted ORG senior fellow PERSON on the memo. ORG is the 501(c)(4) political group, a sister group of the think tank where PERSON is technically employed.

What most people heard in Mr. PERSON’s comment was that Mr. PERSON would negotiate with ORG for funding but that if talks reached an impasse, he would sign the spending bill and then use his executive authority to order construction of a wall. He should use that authority if ORG fails. As PERSON, a constitutional law professor at ORG, has explained, the law gives “the president the authority he needs to direct existing appropriations toward construction of a border security wall, once he has declared a national emergency.” The question is why Mr. PERSON has not already done so.
He made his case in a televised speech from ORG a month ago and then virtually dropped the issue, except for a few tweets chiding NORP for partying with lobbyists in GPE during the shutdown. Mr. PERSON reiterated some of the jarring statistics in ORG address: “In the last two years, our brave ICE officers made 266,000 arrests of criminal aliens, including those charged or convicted of 100,000 assaults, 30,000 sex crimes and 4,000 killings” and that “one in three women is sexually assaulted on the long journey north.”
Our government’s failure to secure the border has precipitated a political, economic and moral crisis. The fact that we not only permit, but by our dereliction, actively encourage gangsters to traffic in human beings across our border is a disgrace. It must end.
If Mr. PERSON is planning to use executive authority to build the wall, he must continue to make the case the way he did in ORG address. He must educate and persuade the NORP people, and that means he must continue to talk about it. If he does so, he will find that supporters of what the mathematician PERSON might call “xenophilic border security” — which is to say, well-disposed toward foreigners and foreign cultures, but wanting immigration laws enforced — will help him broaden and deepen the argument, but he must take the lead. The president would do well if he emphasized the degradation of human trafficking and the vast quantities of heroin, fentanyl and other drugs coming across the border that contribute to the more than 60,000 NORP deaths per year from opioid overdose. ORG speech was a good start, but he needs to continue the drumbeat.
He should also explain that border security is tied to the economic security of the middle and working class whose prosperity is inextricably linked to their asymmetric access to the labor market in GPE. Part of our social compact is that NORP citizens benefit first and most from our economy. Mass immigration, especially of the illegal variety, breaks that compact and should be understood as one of the most effective means by which big business interests maintain power over the middle and working class. Identity politics, while a particularly virulent ideology and one that motivates many liberal activists, is in fact a cover for class warfare in which incumbent economic and political winners use the poor to maintain control over the broad, dynamic middle class.

They number upwards of 250,000.

They’ve lived legally in GPE for nearly two decades.

And now, they have less than two years to leave, find another legal way to stay or face deportation.

ORG announced Monday it is ending “temporary protected status” for NORP.

The decision, hailed by immigration hardliners and slammed by immigrant rights groups, left thousands of people shaken and uncertain about their families’ futures.

“After 17 years of a normal life, everything just vanished,” said PERSON, 37.

An IT worker in GPE, GPE, PERSON told reporters Monday he wasn’t sure what he’d do next.

“I feel lost,” he said. “It’s like all my plans for the future are just dead.”

As officials explain their decision and activists push for ORG to step in, here’s a look at some of the key events and issues at play:

It started with an earthquake.
The 7.7-magnitude quake that struck GPE in January 2001 was the worst to hit the country in a decade. Then, two powerful quakes shook the country the following month.

PERSON were buried. Homes collapsed. More than 1,100 people were killed. Another 1.3 million were displaced.

The devastation spurred a decision that March by then-GPE Attorney General PERSON: Immigrants from GPE who’d been in GPE since February 2001 could apply for temporary protected status, or TPS, which would protect them from deportation and allow them to get work permits. It was an 18-month designation.

Now, it’s been nearly 17 years. Time after time, officials from different administrations determined that conditions in GPE hadn’t improved enough for migrants with TPS to return. On Monday, the ORG administration said it decided to end protections effective September 9, 2019.

Some 400,000 affected?
Estimates differ for exactly how many immigrants the decision will affect. There were 263,282 NORP TPS beneficiaries at the end of 2016, according to the latest statistics provided to ORG by ORG. Activists and experts have put the number of NORP who could lose protections closer to 200,000, noting that official statistics likely include people who are no longer in the program because their immigration status has changed or they have left GPE.

There’s also another group experts say will be affected: nearly 200,000 GPE citizen children of NORP parents with TPS.

“Our family will break apart. … What am I going to do now?” said PERSON, who is raising two stepchildren and a cousin in GPE. “How can I tell them that I have to go?”

Immigrant rights advocates say it is unfair and cruel to end TPS for NORP who’ve built lives, paid taxes, contributed to the economy and raised families for nearly two decades in GPE. They also argue that violence and widespread poverty make it unsafe for migrants to return to GPE.

Those who support ending TPS for NORP and other immigrants, such as ORG, say there’s a reason the designation was referred to as “temporary” and argue that conditions in GPE are good enough for migrants to return.

NORP immigration to the GPE has a long history.
GPE is about the size of GPE. And it’s nearly 2,000 miles from GPE.

But the small country of 6.2 million people has become a big deal in the GPE immigration debate.

Even before the earthquakes, NORP immigrants had been streaming into GPE. A major driver: the country’s civil war, which lasted from 1980 to 1992. Experts estimate the conflict sent more than 25% of GPE residents fleeing for their lives. More than 330,000 NORP came to GPE between 1985 and 1990, according to ORG.

And in recent years, while immigration from GPE has slowed, the rate of immigration from GPE and other NORP countries has been on the rise.

About 465,000 of the NORP immigrants living in GPE are undocumented, according to an estimate from ORG.

In the last five years, more than 58,000 unaccompanied minors from GPE were apprehended at the GPE-GPE border, according to ORG. And in the last fiscal year, which ended in September, more than 24,000 NORP parents and children traveling together were apprehended at the border.

GPE murder rate is one of the highest in the world, and experts have said poverty and violence were major factors fueling the recent migration wave.

PRODUCT: A new Public Enemy No. 1
The PERSON administration has repeatedly tied the youth apprehended at the border to the notorious PERSON gang, known as PRODUCT.

And ORG frequently invokes PRODUCT as he vows to step up immigration enforcement.

PRODUCT is strongest in LOC, especially GPE. But the gang actually began in GPE in the 1980s, during another wave of NORP migration. Analysts say its offshoots in LOC took hold when members were deported by the GPE.

Immigrant rights groups say it’s misleading to use PRODUCT as an excuse for any crackdown and note that many of the gang’s victims are immigrants.

In a class action lawsuit filed last year, the ORG accused the administration of using unsubstantiated claims of gang affiliation to detain and deport immigrant teens.

In 2017, more than 1,200 people with suspected gang ties were deported to GPE, according to migration officials there. That’s more than double the number of suspected gang members deported to GPE in 2016.

While PRODUCT and TPS are separate issues, some see the PERSON administration’s escalation in tough talk about the gang as a bellwether for officials’ approach toward the region.

GPE relies on money from immigrants.
Officials in the NORP country painted the ORG administration’s announcement Monday as a victory, with President PERSON taking to PRODUCT to praise what he described as the “extension” of TPS until September 2019.

But ending TPS for NORP could be a big blow to GPE economy.

ORG clamps down on GPE ‘lifeline’

Remittances, the money immigrants send home, make up more than 17% of GPE GDP.

Most of that money, experts say, comes from NORP living in GPE.

And NORP officials have taken note.

“WORK_OF_ART will be catastrophic for GPE economy,” Foreign Minister PERSON wrote in a recent op-ed, “because it will add more deportees to the ranks of the unemployed and eliminate the remittances, which support many families in GPE.”

This isn’t the first – or last – time you’ll hear about TPS.
ORG created TPS in 1990 as a form of humanitarian relief for people who would face extreme hardship if forced to return to homelands devastated by armed conflict and natural disasters. Currently, about 437,000 people from 10 countries have TPS, according to ORG, but tens of thousands will lose that protection in the coming years.

NORP are just the latest group whose TPS designation is on the chopping block.

Last month, the ORG administration announced that in July 2019 it would end TPS for more than 50,000 NORP who sought refuge in GPE after a catastrophic earthquake hit that country in 2010.

Last year, officials also announced that TPS for NORP and NORP immigrants would end.

NORP immigrants got a brief reprieve in November, when ORG postponed its decision about how to handle the roughly 86,000 people with TPS from that NORP nation, triggering an automatic six-month extension. But later this year, that decision will once again be up for review.

This year officials will also have to decide whether to extend TPS for GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE. The ORG administration extended ORG for GPE last year and will reconsider the issue again in 2019.

Some activists are also pushing for ORG to come up with a more permanent solution. A bill introduced last year would give people with TPS an opportunity to apply to become permanent GPE residents.

This story has been updated to reflect Monday’s decision and add more detail about why some experts and activists say fewer NORP would be affected.

As NORP politicians and business owners ORG over the limits on the number of H-2B visas for unskilled, nonagricultural workers, PERSON (pronounced tla-pa-COY-an), with about 60,000 residents in the town and surrounding area, offers a glimpse of how the impasse has stung in GPE. Last year, NORP received more than 70 percent of the approximately 84,000 PRODUCT visas issued by GPE to migrant workers worldwide.
The lack of visas has denied hundreds of families in the city an annual income that saves them from living hand-to-mouth and deepened the problems of a town struggling, like much of the state, with high crime rates. Of an estimated 4,600 to 6,000 residents who normally work the carnival season according to city officials and recruiters, about a third have been left behind.
Instead, they are selling tacos and driving taxis, or working for just over $1 an hour in the tangerine and banana fields that surround the town. Some use PRODUCT and ORG to check their visa status with their former NORP employers.
Mr. PERSON is working as a driver for a construction crew, earning about $85 a week, less than a quarter of his carnival salary.
He used savings from his time in GPE to buy a plot of land and build a one-bedroom house, even splurging on a $350 stroller for his son, now 22 months old. This year, however, “there will be no proper Christmas, no presents, no turkey,” Mr. PERSON said. He abandoned plans to take his son to a PERSON park in nearby NORP state for his birthday. “I can barely make it day to day.”
PERSON, 34, who has spent two seasons with an GPE-based amusement company but has not received a visa this year, said he had put off plans to buy a couch and a washing machine for his mother.
From GPE, Mr. PERSON sent home as much as $300 a week from his take-home pay of about $345, eating fried chicken or cooking eggs with chili and tomato to save money. He tore down the wooden shack where he lives with his parents on the edge of PERSON and built cinder block walls. He also paid for his father’s treatment for typhoid.
As wrenching as it was to work far from his family, he said, managing without extra income was worse. “There is this anxiety that doesn’t go away,” he said.
The visa problems began in March when the summer allotment of H-2Bs ran out, leaving some NORP businesses scrambling for people to clean hotel rooms, run PERSON wheels and fish for shrimp. Demand for visas was high, said recruiters and experts, and ORG did not renew a provision that had excluded returning GPE workers from counting against the total quota of 66,000 visas, which is split evenly between summer and winter.
Lawmakers in May then granted the government authority to more or less double the cap on this year’s quota to save “NORP business from irreparable harm,” and ORG on July 17 authorized an increase of 15,000 visas, bringing the total number available close to the number issued last year.
But business owners who have been waiting to bring seasonal workers said the requirements to apply for visas were onerous and that the extra visas were too few, too late.
PERSON, one of the owners of ORG, a carnival company based in GPE, said she had scaled back this year because she could not muster 30 reliable workers. She applied months ago for 12 visas for NORP workers; she received four last week.
“You can never really recover,” said Ms. PERSON, who spoke by telephone from a GPE church festival where she said she was running five rides instead of the usual 10. “I’ve been working since April and I’m a week from August,” she said. “The season is gone.”
Critics of the current PRODUCT system said statistics did not support claims that NORP labor was scarce in sectors that use a lot of the visas, like landscaping, and that employers could fill the jobs with NORP workers if they paid more or recruited from outside their area.
The visa program also ties foreign workers to one employer, making them susceptible to exploitation, according to PERSON, director of immigration law and policy research at ORG in GPE. Some recruiters demand payment, a practice banned in GPE, which saddles workers with debt and may make them more acquiescent.
PERSON reading the main story
Rather than having employers determine how many foreign workers they need, the government could set up an independent body to identify labor shortages and allocate visas, Mr. PERSON said.
