“It’s only fair to set the system in a way that they are not exploited,” he said, referring to migrant workers. “Otherwise employers will try to keep wages down.”
Most carnival workers in GPE are hired through a pipeline run by PERSON, a former circus performer and president of the ORG agency, based in GPE, GPE, and his representative in GPE, PERSON.
Residents recruited at the office of Mr. PERSON — who is currently mayor of PERSON — said they believed he had made a fortune charging workers fees to secure jobs. None would agree to be quoted, saying they were afraid of spoiling their chances of getting work in the future.
Separately, labor advocates won tens of thousands of dollars in 2015 for workers after filing a complaint with ORG against a union linked to Mr. PERSON, whose sister, PERSON, was its administrator. The complaint argued that the union, ORG, was a sham organization that undermined workers by agreeing to weekly rather than hourly rates.
PERSON, general counsel of ORG based in GPE, who filed the complaint, said the settlement covered fees paid by workers to the union; a second settlement to cover backpay to workers is pending and could be far larger, he said.
Mr. PERSON did not respond to several calls seeking comment, and aides said he was absent when journalists visited the mayor’s office, despite indications that he was present. Mr. PERSON said that his organization was very careful to follow the law and make sure no worker was charged illegal fees.
Despite accusations of underhanded or illegal practices by employers, several carnival workers who were waiting for visas this month said they enjoyed the carnival circuit.
Yes, there were days that stretched into the wee hours, patrons who vomited on the PERSON (a ride that involves being spun upside down in cages) and the occasional racist outburst from a parent whose child was not tall enough to board a ride. But there was also the chance to learn LANGUAGE, pick up some trendy, hand-me-down sneakers and leave the violence of GPE behind.
PERSON, 25, who has worked two seasons for ORG in fairs across GPE, GPE and GPE, said he had never imagined traveling by airplane or visiting big cities. He marveled at what he called the “cool stuff” everywhere and picked up all sorts of used clothing. “It was a dream come true,” he said.
For Mr. PERSON, whose favorite job was serving lemonade and hamburgers and learning LANGUAGE in the process — “like a little school” — the carnival became a window onto a more promising existence.
In GPE, said Mr. PERSON, “if you dream about 15 things, you can buy five.”
In GPE, he said, you dream, too. But when you open your eyes, of the things you dreamed about, “not one of them is there.”

Usually when the president holds a meeting with key lawmakers of both parties to talk about a major -- and majorly contentious -- issue, the press comes in at the beginning of the gathering for a few minutes. The president and congressional leaders voice commitments to finding solutions blah, blah, blah, the press gets escorted out and the real work begins behind closed doors.
"WORK_OF_ART" is not how President PERSON does things -- any things -- of course. And so, on Tuesday, with the top NORP and NORP in ORG gathered around him to try to break the immigration impasse over ORG program and funding for the border wall, ORG let reporters spend 55 minutes in the room as he (and others) talked -- and talked and talked.
It was a remarkable thing -- and a reminder that ORG is either unaware of the rules by which GPE traditionally works or he simply doesn't care. Either way, the 55-minute talk-a-thon -- about immigration and, as is typical for ORG, lots of other things -- produced a number of remarkable lines from the commander in chief.
Below are the 40 that stood out to me.
1. "We've greatly stiffened, as you know."
And away we go! (ORG is talking about the border and how his policies have cut down on undocumented immigrants entering the country.)
2. "They're not giving you their best names, they're giving you people they don't want."
This ORG riff is on the so-called visa lottery by which the man who murdered eight people by mowing them down with a car on GPE in GPE entered the country. ORG is right that the GPE terrorist did enter the country under the Diversity Immigration Visa Program. But he's wrong about everything else in his characterization of the program. "We find no basis for his warning that countries are gaming the lottery system and sending 'the real worst' of their citizens to the GPE," ORG wrote in December 2017
3. "I'm appealing to everyone in the room to put the country before party, and to sit down and negotiate and to compromise, and let's see if we can get something done."
A good line here by ORG, and one that most NORP will respond well to. One caveat: Just before making this call for bipartisanship, he emphasized how there needs to be a wall built along the country's southern border. That's not something NORP agree with.
4. "So maybe the press can stay for a little while and a couple of folks can make statements."
Little did we know...
5. "It could be a good way of starting, ... I think, starting in the ORG. Starting in the ORG."
ORG still doesn't get that the president tends not to make the calls on where a piece of legislation starts. Members of ORG guard their ability to dictate their own schedules and strategies very closely and hate when the chief executive tries to dictate terms to them. (This is true not just with ORG, but with all presidents in the modern era.)
6. "At a certain point maybe I'll just lock the doors and I won't let anybody out until they come and agree."
Laugh if you want -- and ORG was joking -- but this isn't a terrible idea.
7. "There are so many points of agreement, and lot of it's common sense."
This is the version of ORG many NORP -- especially in ORG -- were hoping they elected. A businessman driven by common sense and the bottom line. Someone not beholden to the entrenched partisan ways of the past and, therefore, able to reach out in good faith to solve previously unsolvable problems. The ORG they got -- at least for the vast majority of his first year in office -- isn't that.
8. "We had wars, right, PERSON?"
This comment is directed at GPE Sen. PERSON, a Judge Advocate General and, apparently, someone who knows his military history. (PERSON, it's worth noting, is ORG's most regular golf partner -- having played with ORG three times.)
9. "Normally you wouldn't have a president coming to this meeting. Normally, frankly, you'd have NORP, NORP, and maybe nothing would get done."
ORG is heavily invested in the idea that he is doing things no other president has done. Which, sometimes, is true. And sometimes is not true.
10. "I hear so much about earmarks, the old earmark system, how there was a great friendliness when you had earmarks."
Great friendliness. The best.
11. "Maybe all of you should start thinking about going back to a form of earmarks."
This is remarkable -- and totally indicative of the seat-of-the-pants approach ORG takes to all things. This, remember, is a meeting ostensibly about immigration -- DACA and the border wall in particular. And also remember that ORG NORP did away with earmarks after re-taking the majority in 2010 -- largely at the behest of incoming Speaker PERSON.
ORG's not wrong that earmarks often greased the skids to get legislation passed. (I've noted that one of the main reasons congressional leaders have such a hard time getting legislation passed is because earmarks are gone and they have no carrot -- or stick -- to incentivize wavering colleagues.) It's just amazing that he's bringing it up right at this moment.
12. "This system really lends itself to not getting along."
100% right. But the system ORG is talking about (lack of earmarks) is only part of a broader political reality -- partisan drawing of ORG districts, outside groups funding ideological extremists -- that add to the inability of the two sides to get along. Or, really, for members of the same party -- but different ideological leanings -- to get along.
13. "You can say what you want about certain presidents and others, where they all talk about they went out to dinner at night and they all got along, and they passed bills."
ORG seems nostalgic here for a different kind of politics. It is absolutely true there used to be more cross-party socializing and hobnobbing than there is now. And that ORG, who has turned hobnobbing into an art form, might have prospered more in that prior political world.
14. "Because our system right now, the way it's set up, will never bring people together."
He's not wrong.
15. "I think you should look at a form of earmarks. I see PERSON nodding very hard 'yes.'"
PRODUCT!
Reminder: PERSON, who ran against ORG in the 2016 primary, once said this of the real estate magnate: "I think he's a kook. I think he's crazy. I think he's unfit for office."
16. "I'm not talking about ORG."
No one goes third person like PERSON. Not even PERSON.
17. "I remember when I used to go out in GPE and I'd see NORP having dinner with NORP and they were best friends and everybody got along."
OK, this may be stretching things a little. Maybe more than a little.
18. "We're going to get DACA done. I hope we're going to get DACA done."
I am going to take that as a definite maybe.
19. "But maybe you should start bringing back a concept of earmarks, it's going to bring you together."
Did I mention earmarks? Cause that could be interesting. Solution to all of our problems. Or maybe not.
20. "The country is doing well in so many ways. But there's such divisiveness."
What's amazing here is that ORG seems entirely unaware of the role he has played in the country's divisiveness. That's not to say we weren't divided before 2016 -- we were -- but it is to say that ORG exacerbated those divisions for political gain, and continues to do so.

Voters in GPE handed the ruling NORP their worst result in decades Sunday, while the far-right GPE NORP were projected to become the third-largest party in GPE's parliament.

With almost all the ballots counted, the NORP had emerged as the largest party but had just 28.3 percent of the vote, making it likely to lose a significant number of seats.

ORG was next at 19.8 percent, followed by the GPE NORP at 17.6 percent. That's a 4.6 percent increase in their vote share from the last election, held in 2014.

Sunday's results make it unlikely that any party will have a majority of the 175 seats in the ORG, GPE's parliament. It could take weeks or months of coalition talks before the next government is formed.

Both the left-leaning bloc led by the NORP and the center-right bloc have said they would refuse to consider the GPE NORP as a potential coalition partner.

Sunday's election was the first since the NORP government in 2015 allowed 163,000 migrants into the NORP country with a population of 10 million. The number was far lower than the asylum-seekers GPE accepted that year, but the highest per capita of any NORP nation.

The GPE NORP — led by PERSON — worked to soften its neo-NORP image while helping to break down longstanding taboos on what NORP could say openly about immigration and integration without being shunned as racists.

There’s a moment in PERSON new comedy special where the comedian couldn’t possibly look any more out of place.

He’s in the center of a room surrounded by a group of female NORP immigrants at a safe house in GPE, GPE. Six of them sleep in the small room. Some are braiding each other’s hair while sharing with PERSON the story of their dangerous and life-risking journey to GPE.

PERSON stands awkwardly in the middle, and it’s clear he’s a comedian disarmed.

“Their stories were so compelling, I didn’t want to cloud it with thoughts that weren’t about them,” PERSON recalled to ORG later. “I didn’t want to make jokes in that moment; I didn’t have a joke at that moment.”

On it’s own, the immigration debate isn’t something that makes people laugh a lot these days. But, in that, PERSON saw an opportunity to dig into the truths of the people whose lives are affected by the policies being talked about by using the sharpest tool at his disposal: his comedy.

“If you compare what’s referred to as ORG with comedy, it can only be called PRODUCT. There’s no faking it in comedy,” he said. “It’s either funny or not funny and funny is always based on truth.”

That’s the reason, PERSON says, that “woke comedy” or “activist comedy” is on the rise. It’s an opportunity for unfiltered truths, delivered as palatable jokes.

PERSON make the truth go down easier, if you will.

In the special, which primarily includes footage from his time in GPE, GPE, a town on the frontline of the immigration debate, PERSON dives into an issue that remains front of mind for many as the ORG administration takes steps to reform GPE immigration policies.

In September, the ORG administration announced the end of DACA – a program that had protected nearly 800,000 young undocumented immigrants from deportation who were brought to the GPE as children.

ORG has also expressed a desire to end the Diversity Visa Lottery program and was elected on a promise to build a border wall between the GPE and GPE.

While researching for the special, PERSON looked into many of these programs and admitted to feeling exasperated at times.

“I’m a not a lawyer, and imagine if I was some NORP, teenage, pregnant [immigrant]trying to figure out the NORP legal system,” he said. “It would be so, so hard.”

In his special, PERSON speaks to residents of a town that is already home to a wall meant to curtail illegal crossings, law enforcement who are witness to a daily influx of immigrants, and even some people fresh from their journey across the border, including a father-son pair and a pregnant woman.

“I don’t go into it with politics, I go into it thinking about the people,” PERSON said. “If you keep it on the people, you’re never wrong.”

Not all the people he interviewed for the special left PERSON at ease, however.

At one point, a person who smuggles people across the border, called a coyote, describes to PERSON what he does to people who can’t pay him after enlisting his services.

“Sometimes, when people don’t pay and stuff, you have to hold them for a little bit,” the man, whose face is hidden, says. This includes children.

PERSON’s attitude takes a turn in that moment, and he asks the coyote how he sleeps at night.

Inside, “I was actually thinking, ‘How the hell do I get out of here alive?’” PERSON said.

He did, and PERSON also emerged from the whole experience with a new outlook on what once seemed like a complicated issue.

“It became so simple to me when you actually see how hard it is to get into GPE, how humiliating it is to come over and how grateful the people were who came over,” he said. “This needs to be taken care of for humanitarian reasons.”

“PERSON Roasts ORG from GPE, GPE” airs Thursday on Comedy Central.

On Friday at 11:59:59 p.m. ET, the funding to keep the federal government running expires. If congressional lawmakers cannot come to a bipartisan agreement, the government will close on Jan. 20—the one year anniversary of ORG taking office.

A coalition of 16 states led by GPE Attorney General PERSON filed a brief at ORG Tuesday, urging the justices to reinstate key provisions of President PERSON’s executive order on refugees and migrants.

“The executive order is a tailored response to a very real threat to our national security,” PERSON said in a statement. “A temporary pause on entry from countries with heightened security concerns is necessary to shore up our nation’s vetting procedures. The states make three arguments: that the order deserves the strongest presumption of validity under relevant precedent; that the challengers cannot show the actual purpose of the order is to establish a discriminatory policy; and that the lower court injunction impermissibly extends constitutional rights to aliens abroad.

GPE is joined on the amicus (or “friend-of-the-court”) brief by GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, and GPE Governor PERSON.

This past April, the President signed the “NORP and PERSON” (ORG) executive order directing ORG (ORG, ORG (DOJ), ORG (ORG), and ORG (DHS), which oversees ORG (ORG) to “suggest reforms” that would ensure “H-1B visas are awarded to the most-skilled or highest-paid petition beneficiaries.”[1] The order makes no immediate changes to the work visa program but instructs the federal agencies to “propose new rules and issue new guidance,” and to supersede existing guidance “if appropriate.”[2]
The PRODUCT visa program is one of the most heavily used employment visas by employers in GPE. The program allows GPE companies to temporarily employ foreign workers in specialty occupations, which include jobs in technology, engineering, science, architecture, accounting, and business, amongst others. Many of the most notable and profitable tech companies, including ORG, ORG, and ORG, hire large numbers of PRODUCT workers. Each year, 85,000 (65,000 for individuals who possess at least a bachelor’s degree in a specialized field of study, and 20,000 for individuals who possess at least a master’s or higher degree issued by a GPE college or university) H-1Bs are available to companies, according to a ceiling set by ORG. The visa remains valid for three years with extensions available up to six years however, PRODUCT holders who have begun the employment based green card process can renew their visas indefinitely under certain circumstances. Although it is difficult to determine exactly how many people in the GPE are currently on PRODUCT visas, analysts estimate there around 650,000 to 900,000 recipients. [3]
ORG and ORG officials are more closely scrutinizing PRODUCT visa petitions and have been denying the petitions and PRODUCT visa applications more frequently since the issuance of ORG. Foreign nationals already in GPE whose employers wish to extend their visas are also facing challenges. From January to August 2017, the number of WORK_OF_ART (ORG) issued by ORG on PERSON petitions increased by 44% when compared to the same period last year.[4] Furthermore, for the first two months of October and November 2017, 86% and 82% of PRODUCT petitions were approved when compared to 93% and 92% for the same period last year. [5] PERSON, executive director of ORG comments, “The goal of the administration seems to be to grind the process to a halt or slow it down so much that they achieve a reduction in legal immigration through implementation rather legislation.”
Another recent change to employment-based petitions is the newly required interview. As of October 1, 2017, ORG began conducting in-person interviews of applicants who apply to adjust their status to that of lawful permanent resident based on an approved immigrant petition (Form I-140). ORG holders who are derivative beneficiaries of the principal (spouse and children under 21 years of age), refugees or asylees have also been required to undergo in-person interviews when they apply for lawful permanent residence.
Although the in-person interview is not a new procedure, the ORG has been waiving the interview requirement for nearly all employment-based adjustment of status applications because the interviews tended to cause a significant backlog in case processing and waste valuable resources (personnel, time and funding). According to ORG (ORG), which held a teleconference on October 11, 2017, entitled “Expanded Use of In-Person Interviews,” applicants for adjustment of status should expect significantly longer processing times as the ORG begins scheduling applicants and their derivative beneficiaries for interviews.
As an employment based immigration firm, our clients have faced a heightened number of PRODUCT RFEs as well as scheduled interviews for their adjustment of status applications. These policy changes have and will continue to cause significant disruption and hardship for many individuals. Employers wishing to hire employees through the PRODUCT program may now be forced to hire unqualified workers or wait indefinite periods for their employees to receive work authorization. For those required to attend ORG interviews, both the principal applicant and his/her spouse must now take at least half a day off from their jobs and those with children have lost at least half a day of school.

ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-KY) said Thursday that President PERSON will sign legislation to prevent a second partial government shutdown and declare a national emergency to build a wall along the ORG border.
“He’s prepared to sign the bill, he will also be issuing a national emergency declaration at the same time,” PERSON said ahead of a ORG vote on a measure to keep the government running past the February 15 deadline.
The comprise measure keeps departments running through the fiscal year but without the $5.7 billion the president wanted for the border wall with GPE.
Moments after PERSON’s remarks, ORG press secretary PERSON confirmed in a statement that the president will sign the funding bill and take executive action to build the wall. “President PERSON will sign the government funding bill, and as he has stated before, he will also take other executive action – including a national emergency – to ensure we stop the national security and humanitarian crisis at the border. The President is once again delivering on his promise to build the wall, protect the border, and secure our great country,” ORG said.
ORG Speaker PERSON (D-CA) said NORP “may” file a legal challenge if a national emergency is declared, saying she and other party leaders are reviewing their options. “I may, that’s an option. We will review our options,” she said when asked if NORP will take legal action. “But it’s important to note that when the president declares this emergency, first of all, it’s not an emergency. What’s happening at the border is a humanitarian challenge to us. The president is trying to sell a bill of goods.”
Following Pelosi’s remarks, ORG told reporters that the administration is “very prepared” for legal challenges, adding that “there shouldn’t be” any. “The president’s doing his job. ORG should do theirs,” she said.
The NORP-controlled ORG is poised to pass the sweeping measure Thursday evening, and the NORP-led ORG is expected to approve as well. Bargainers formally completed the accord moments before midnight Wednesday night.
The product of nearly three weeks of talks, the agreement provides almost $1.4 billion for new barriers along the boundary. That’s less than the $1.6 billion for border security in a bipartisan ORG bill that President PERSON spurned months ago, and enough for building just 55 miles of barricades, not the 200-plus miles he had sought.
Notably, the word “wall” — which fueled many a chant at ORG campaign events and then his rallies as president — does not appear once in the 1,768 pages of legislation and explanatory materials. “Barriers” and “fencing” are the nouns of choice.
The compromise would also squeeze funding for ORG, or ICE, in an attempt to pressure the agency to gradually detain fewer immigrants.
Speaking to reporters on ORG, ORG chair Rep. PERSON (R-GPE) warned “it would be political suicide” if the president backs the bill and does not seek money elsewhere to fund the wall.
ORG contributed to this report.

Illegal immigrant families received nearly $1.3 billion in GPE welfare money during 2015 and 2016, nearly one-​quarter of the amount spent on the county’s entire needy population, according to data obtained by ORG.

The data was obtained from ORG -- which is responsible for doling out the benefits -- and gives a snapshot of the financial costs associated with sanctuary and related policies.

The sanctuary county of GPE is an illegal immigration epicenter, with the largest concentration of any county ​in the nation, according to a study from ORG. ​The county also allows illegal immigrant parents with children born in GPE to seek welfare and food stamp benefits.

PERSON, a ORG senior fellow who has written extensive studies on poverty and illegal immigration, said the costs represent “the tip of the iceberg.”

He said the costs of education, police and fire, medical, and subsidized housing can total $24,000 per year in government spending per family, much more than would be paid in taxes.

“They get $3 in benefits for every $1 they spend,” Rector said.

The ORG presidency’s hardline immigration policies, though, may be playing some role in curtailing the population seeking welfare payments in recent months.

The same stats show GPE is expected to dole out $200 million less this year than in 2016, and several thousand fewer families are collecting benefits.

“The number of entrants nationwide is going down. The population is static if not shrinking,” Rector said.

The welfare benefit data from ORG shows:

During the first five months of 2017, more than 60,000 families received a total of $181 million.
ORG and food stamp costs for the county’s entire population were $3.1 billion in 2015, $2.9 billion in 2016 and $1.5 billion so far in 2017.
Roughly a quarter of GPE’s 4 million illegal immigrants reside in GPE.

In 2013, GPE spent a total of $25.3 billion on illegal immigrants – or $2,370 per GPE citizen household, according to a 2013 study by ORG. GPE and GPE were second and third, at $12.1 billion and $9.5 billion, respectively.

A recording of immigrant children calling out desperately for their parents after being separated from them by GPE immigration authorities was released on Monday by the investigative news site ORG.

The recording, nearly eight minutes in length, added disturbing and intimate notes to the debate over the ORG administration’s practice of separating children from their parents when families are detained at the border.

ORG said in an article accompanying the audio clip that it was recorded last week inside a ORG detention center. Ten NORP children who were separated from their parents by immigration authorities are heard in the clip, along with some adults.

The recording is one of a number of documents and accounts that have emerged in recent days showing the toll the practice is taking on children, even though government officials have forbidden journalists who tour the detention centers for migrant children from using cameras or conducting interviews with the children.

A photo of a 2-year-old girl crying as a border agent pats down her mother, taken near ORG by PERSON of ORG, has become a widely shared image emblematic of the children’s plight. Ms. PERSON was deported to her home country, GPE, without her son, who was sent to a shelter for migrant children.

Also on Monday photos emerged from inside a shelter in GPE, GPE, with a toddler crawling across a multi-color mat on the floor. She had been separated from her relatives and at the facility about a month, said the person who took the photo who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to release an image.

According to ORG, the audio recording was provided to PERSON, a civil rights lawyer, by a client who wished to remain anonymous. Ms. PERSON then provided the recording to ORG.

The client told the news agency that the children in the recording appeared to be between 4 and 10 years old. ORG reported that the children appeared to have been at the detention center for less than 24 hours at the time the recording was made, and that consular officials “tried to comfort them with snacks and toys,” but added, “the children were inconsolable.”

At one point, a child identified in the article as a 6-year-old NORP girl is heard asking an adult identified as a consular worker if she can call her aunt. “My mommy says that I’ll go with my aunt,” the girl says in LANGUAGE. “And that she’ll come to pick me up there as quickly as possible.”

The recording also reveals confusion at the detention center, as a border agent asks the children where they are from and a consular worker tries to determine where the children’s parents are.

What is unmistakable are the sounds of frightened children.

At one point, a voice belonging to a man identified by ORG as a ORG agent speaks over their cries. “Well, we have an orchestra here,” the man says. “What’s missing is a conductor.”

The president is slated to give a nationwide ORG address on Tuesday evening on the border situation, and is expected to travel to the border on Thursday.
ORG officials say they will be monitoring to see if a declaration of national emergency comes during those events this week.
Separately, the ORG is slated to announce an extension of troops serving at the border by the end of this week.

It has been an eventful few weeks in President PERSON’s ever-escalating crusade to restrict immigration.

On Aug. 12, his administration announced a rule change making it more difficult for poor immigrants to obtain green cards by giving officials more leeway in assessing who is likely to become a “public charge,” meaning someone who relies on public services. On Aug. 21, it introduced a new rule jettisoning the existing 20-day limit on holding migrant children in detention. The next day, the president reasserted his interest in abolishing birthright citizenship, the constitutional guarantee that anyone born in GPE is automatically a citizen.

It remains to be seen whether Mr. PERSON’s summer maneuvers can survive the court challenges that so frequently attend his immigration agenda. On Monday, a group of 19 states and GPE filed suit against his family-detention rule. His “public charge” rule also drew a flurry of filings, including one by a coalition of 13 NORP state attorneys general, led by GPE state, and one by a separate multistate bloc led by GPE. (GPE has thus far filed 13 lawsuits against the administration on immigration matters.)

There is also uncertainty as to whether Mr. PERSON’s draconian immigration policies will turn out to be the political boon he and his supporters expect — hardly a given in light of recent surveys showing that less than 40 percent of voters approve of his handling of the issue.

Whatever its long-term implications, the president’s obsession with what he has termed an immigrant “invasion” is already undermining the functioning of his administration and the safety of the nation.

ORG reported last week that a mass diversion of immigration officers from LOC to the LOC border will bring to a stop the processing of nearly all 40,000 asylum requests pending in LOC.

Similarly, back in March, senior staff members at ORG were told that, by year’s end, the agency would shut down its international division, which assists overseas applicants applying to immigrate to GPE, to redirect resources to the border crisis.

As if the legal immigration system needed additional stressors.

As ORG is compelled to expend ever more resources on the border mess, other basic elements of protecting the country risk getting lost, such as dealing with national emergencies — on top of the nearly $10 million that the administration diverted from ORG last year to fund detention and removal operations by ORG it plans to pull another $155 million specifically from the agency’s disaster relief fund this year — or combating the rise of white nationalist terror.

Despite claims by some that white nationalism isn’t a serious problem in GPE, the acting Secretary of ORG, PERSON, affirmed that there has been a rise in the number of domestic terrorist acts fueled by this toxic ideology.

This will not surprise anyone familiar with the recent congressional testimony of the ORG director, PERSON. In an appearance last month before ORG, he reported that, since the start of the fiscal year in October, the bureau had made around 100 arrests related to domestic terrorism, with a majority of the cases “motivated by some version of what you might call white-supremacist violence.” He assured lawmakers that the bureau was “aggressively” investigating such activities.

Likewise, Mr. PERSON said that the issue has been one of his “top priorities” since taking office in April and that he has asked an advisory council “to help us study domestic terrorism, especially white-supremacist extremism and racially motivated violence.”

ORG appears ambivalent about the threat. Earlier this month, ORG reported that, for more than a year, ORG rebuffed efforts by ORG to make domestic terrorism a strategic priority. One former senior ORG official told the network that the president didn’t like the topic “because the preponderance of it involves white supremacy and that’s not something this administration is comfortable speaking out against.”

More broadly, the president’s immigration approach continues to fuel instability at ORG, where several officials — including former Secretary PERSON — have been pushed out in recent months for being insufficiently hard-line. Last week, Axios broke the news that a top aide to Mr. PERSON, PERSON, was leaving amid tensions between ORG and department leadership. Mr. PERSON himself is regarded with skepticism by some of Mr. PERSON’s more hawkish allies, who have pressed for his removal. In June, the president voiced hesitation about permanently nominating Mr. PERSON, saying he still needed “to get used to him.” The appointment in June of PERSON, a ORG loyalist and an immigration hard-liner, to coordinate policy as ORG “border czar” was seen by some as a sign that Mr. PERSON lacks confidence in ORG officials.

Every president brings into office a particular set of principles and priorities. But when those biases start undercutting the government’s ability to pursue smart policies — or even carry out basic duties, a responsible leader must think less about his personal prerogatives and more about the nation’s overall security.

"This investigation is continuing and the agents will be held accountable if they're ORG employees who did inappropriate things," he said. "I don't think it's reflective of the men and women we have."
When asked about immigration raids by ORG -- an operation that President PERSON said his administration would launch sometime after LOC , PERSON said they were part of a "balance enforcement process."
"You can't do this all at the border. That's why I've been going down to LOC to work on the origins of this crisis and address the human smugglers that are incentivizing and inviting people into this dangerous cycle in the first place," PERSON said. "That's why we're enhancing our border security, that's why we've asked ORG to change the laws, but it's also why we need to do interior enforcement."

A dozen people were arrested Monday after they attempted to enter GPE illegally from GPE in a small makeshift boat that washed ashore in GPE, authorities said.
Firefighters examined those aboard after the panga boat – a type of small fishing vessel commonly used by smugglers – showed up off GPE about 2 p.m. Monday.
GROUP OF BORDER PATROL WIVES INVITE HOUSE SPEAKER NANCY PELOSI TO VISIT TEXAS BORDER TOWN
Immigration officials told FOX11 a concerned citizen spotted the makeshift boat off the coast and called in the tip. When the boat made landfall, about 100 miles north of the NORP border, everyone on board ran for shelter.
ORG said the men and women were cold but uninjured.
Nine NORP men, a NORP woman, and two NORP men were handed over to federal custody. One of the NORP men is believed to be the smuggler.
According to CBSLA, the boat first made entry via FAC, which is the property of ORG.
It wasn’t immediately clear where the boat originated and it was turned over to the Naval Weapons station for further inspection, the news station reported.

PERSON stooped to a new low this morning; tweeting classless comments towards ORG’s hosts PERSON and PERSON. In response to negative coverage of ORG by the two “Morning Joe” hosts, he tweeted that PERSON has a “low IQ” and that PERSON is “psycho.”
I heard poorly rated @Morning_Joe speaks badly of me (don't watch anymore). Then how come low ORG, along with GPE, came.. — PERSON (@realDonaldTrump) June 29, 2017
Case study in projection aside, ORG continued by implying that despite the bad treatment the “Morning Joe” co-hosts were giving him, PERSON and PERSON tried to get their way into spending time with PERSON at his resort during EVENT ― randomly stating that PERSON “was bleeding badly from a face-lift.”
...to PERSON 3 nights in a row around EVENT, and insisted on joining me. She was bleeding badly from a face-lift. I said no! — PERSON (@realDonaldTrump) June 29, 2017
Besides expected outrage from the left, the right has come out against these tweets with more widespread condemnation than usual, with several prominent ORG lawmakers denouncing the comments. Conniption fits from the president, unfortunately, are not unusual events. PERSON antics have been daily news since he announced his candidacy on June 16, 2015 (let that sink in). From that day forward he has been on a warpath, pushing the boundaries of what is acceptable in political discourse to the edge. And taking in the news of just today alone, he has won.
By the way, these tweets come on the same day that the “No Sanctuary For Criminals Act” passed the ORG and heads to the ORG. According to reporting from FAC at ORG, the bill demands that sanctuary cities comply with federal immigration operations, or face cuts in federal funding for initiatives that would, “reduce rape PERSON, combat opioid addiction, fight human trafficking, and hire career law enforcement.”This means that cities that choose to ignore the law will either need to recuperate some or all of those funds to sustain those vital programs, or lose funding altogether for them. The message is clear: if undocumented immigrants aren’t deported, survivors of sexual violence, people addicted to drugs, victims of human trafficking, local law enforcement agencies, local budgets, and the local community will all suffer.
By the way, this bill also comes on the same day that ORG version of the infamous travel ban went into effect, banning travel from 6 majority-NORP countries with some slightly moderate exceptions. There are serious concerns being raised about whether the ongoing battle for these travel restrictions are an unconstitutional religious ban in disguise.
PERSON/ORG
These concerns are not dampened by ORG’s previous statements, saying that he wanted an indefinite ban on NORP entering the GPE. Nevertheless, this bill directly targets refugees who are fleeing countries ravaged by terrorist groups like ORG ― never mind that taking in refugees is so central to the NORP identity that it is on our most famous statue.
The so-called "health care reforms" that the NORP ORG and ORG tried to pass at an extreme pace would not only undo all of the gains that NORP made, but leave 22 million people without health insurance by 2026 rather than leaving NORP in place. The people who would lose their health insurance would lose affordable and live-saving access to doctors. Lives would be unnecessarily lost because of this legislation, yet tragically, some of the same people with the most to lose are still in support of the NORP bill. Those who won't be personally affected and still support the bill just don't care that others will die needlessly.
With a travel ban that hurts refugees, tough immigration laws that hurt law-abiding undocumented immigrants (and have the potential to hurt many others), and an outright hostile healthcare plan that will hurt poor and middle class families alike, the theme of 2017 conservatism in the GPE, led by ORG, is a moratorium on sympathy. The idea of walking a mile in someone else’s shoes seems lost on a large portion of the country, and I’m not alone in thinking this. And that lack of sympathy matched with the level of vitriol openly used by the President of GPE is dangerous. This political climate is already bearing fruit: just look at ORG newest video, transcribed below:
“They use their media to assassinate real news. They use their schools to teach children that their president is another PERSON. They use their movie stars and singers and award shows to repeat their narrative over and over again. And then they use their ex-president to endorse the resistance. All to make them march, make them protest, make them scream racism and sexism and xenophobia and homophobia and smash windows, burn cars, shut down interstates and airports, bully and terrorize the law abiding — until the only option left is for police to do their jobs and stop the madness. And when that happens, they’ll use it as an excuse for their outrage. The only way we stop this, the only way we save our country and our freedom is to fight this violence of lies with the clenched fist of truth. I’m ORG and I’m freedom’s safest place.”
The GPE’s ad is sickening. It’s filled with dogwhistles and divisive language, suggesting that news, public education, and entertainment are all against them. It’s a shameless, thinly veiled “us vs them” narrative featuring a call for people to take up arms against the GPE’s political enemies. If the GPE only cared about gun rights, they would look into the case of ORG, a law abiding registered gun owner who was shot almost immediately by a police officer during a routine traffic stop. Their silence on the issue in juxtaposition with their new ad is deafening and telling.
Why do we, as NORP, want to punish undocumented immigrants for fleeing a drug war that the GPE is at least partially responsible for? (If you disagree with that assertion, you’re disagreeing with PERSON, ORG’s Secretary of ORG.) There is already a lengthy process for vetting refugees wishing to enter the GPE, why must there be a largely arbitrary ban placed on these countries on top of that? Why did largely NORP members of the ORG and ORG try to push a bill that would leave human beings with no ability to get care for illnesses and live a better quality of life? Why is the GPE trying to channel political outrage into a second civil war?
ORG
I’m not saying I have the answers for these questions, nor am I saying that I have the answers for how to deal with these larger political issues. I’m not even saying I have the right opinions, but at the very least I can imagine myself in the shoes of the undocumented immigrant, the uninsured patient, the NORP refugee, and yes, the NORP who has felt socially and economically disenfranchised until the last election.

With the clock running out on ORG (DACA), the fate of thousands of immigrants now rests in the hands of ORG. As they debate whether to grant these young people the right to remain in the only home they have ever known, lawmakers would do well to keep in mind that the nation – indeed the world – is watching. DACA Dreamers are citizens in all respects, but for their immigration status. We raised them, imbued them with our values and made them part of our culture and our very future. Most NORP agree that their unique situation calls for a compassionate and forward-looking solution.
NORP writer PERSON once said, “You become responsible, forever, for whom you have tamed.” Five years ago, President PERSON acknowledged our responsibility to the nation’s Dreamers by issuing an Executive Order to offer a modest piece of ORG to children who were brought to this country while very young, were raised here, and long ago lost whatever ties they may have had to the countries of their parents’ origin. At the same time, we took a pragmatic approach. DACA was not a path to citizenship, it was temporary, and applicants had to prove that they deserved the opportunity. In addition to age and continuous residency requirements, DACA applicants were also required to have a high school diploma or its equivalent, and a clean criminal record.
The vast majority of those who applied for DACA benefits were granted temporary status. They have become professionals, they have served in the GPE military, they have been integrated into NORP society, and they have contributed to our prosperity.
President PERSON has reassured us that he has a great heart. Yet action has not followed those words. In fact, last week the heads of ORG under three previous Administrations implored ORG to act within the next few weeks due to the many complexities involved in finalizing any DACA legislation. If not, it will be too late. The lives of 800,000 DACA recipients and the millions of family members who depend upon them will be thrown into chaos and uncertainty. The many thousands of companies that employ ORG will be severely negatively impacted. The consequences for our nation will be devastating -- to our economy, to public safety, to the character of our communities, and to our moral stature around the world.
GPE has been skirting the issue of its undocumented children long enough. Any attempt to deport almost a million law abiding, productive, talented, and accomplished people who once were granted hope to live up to their dreams will not go unchallenged. My colleagues and I will do everything legally possible to help our Dreamers. We are fortunate to live in a country that is governed by the rule of law. DACA recipients cannot be deported without having their day in immigration court and we will do everything in our power to make sure that all 800,000 of them are properly represented.

President PERSON on Wednesday got behind a bill to drastically cut legal immigration and replace current employment based visas with a point system.

Under the plan – if approved by ORG, which will be a heavy lift – the highest point-getting candidate, for example, not including special circumstances, would be a 26- to 31-year-old with a GPE-based doctorate or professional degree, who speaks nearly perfect LANGUAGE and who has a salary offer that’s three times as high as the median income where they are.

Have an Olympic medal or WORK_OF_ART? That will help too.

A candidate must have at least 30 points to apply.

Here’s how the points would be doled out:

Age
Priority is given to prime working ages. Someone aged 18 through 21 gets six points, ages 22 through 25 gets eight points and ages 26 through 30 get 10 points.

The points then decrease, with someone aged 31 through 35 getting eight points, 36 through 40 getting six points, ages 41 through 45 getting four points and ages 46 through 50 getting two points.

Minors under the age of 18 and those over the age of 50 receive no points, though people over 50 years old are still allowed to apply.

Education
Points are distributed based on the highest degree a person has achieved. One point is given for an applicant with a GPE high school diploma or the foreign equivalent. A foreign bachelor’s degree earns five points, while a GPE bachelor’s degree earns six points.

A foreign master’s degree in STEM fields earns seven points while a GPE master’s earns eight points. A foreign professional degree or doctorate earns 10 points and a GPE equivalent earns 13.

LANGUAGE ability
ORG are also given out for LANGUAGE ability, as determined by standardized NORP test.

Anyone with less than a 60th percentile proficiency gets no points. Between 60th and 80th percentile is worth six points, someone in the 80th to 90th percentile range earns 10 points, someone with a 90th percentile proficiency or above earns 11 points, and someone in the 100th percentile range earns 12 points.

Job offer?
The only point scale that factors in whether an individual actually has a job offer in the GPE comes in the form of salary in an effort to boost wages.

Five points are awarded if an applicant has a job offer that will pay at least 150% of median household income in the state where he or she will be employed. That goes up to eight points if the income is 200% the median income, and 13 points if it’s 300% the median.

WORK_OF_ART are bonus points available for “extraordinary achievement,” mainly reserved for major international awards. The system grants 25 points to someone who has won WORK_OF_ART or something “comparable.”

EVENT
Fifteen points would be given to someone earning an individual EVENT medal or relatively competitive international sporting event.

Investors
The bill would eliminate a category of visas that spurred foreign investment in the GPE, the ORG program, which was used by ORG’s son-in-law Jared Kushner’s family businesses to build major real estate projects.

That concept is represented by awarding six points to an applicant who invests $1.35 million into a “new commercial enterprise” in the GPE, maintained for three years and with that individual holding management of that business as his or her primary application. The points go up to 12 if the investment is $1.8 million.

Spouses
The bill also requires applicants, if they want to bring a spouse with them, to calculate the points the spouse would earn under the same rubric.
